Subject: Re: [sfraves] SPINAL INVASION

damn welcome back apollo, wasn't sure if you were going to make it  
back but i'm glad you did and thanks for sharing the reason you were  
in the hospital with the whole list.  i think that's definitely a  
healthier way of dealing with an illness than others i've known in  
the past, not that it's a bad thing to have privacy, i just think at  
some point talking about it helps the healing process.  so for those  
of you that watched the secret DVD you'll know what i'm talking  
about, i'll go down and write 'HEALTHY APOLLO' on my dream board next  
to 'WAR WITH IRAN POSTPONED INDEFINITELY'.  that stuff works, btw,  
other things on it have come true for me, and i encourage others to  
do the same!

-d

Subject: Re: [sfraves] beer favorites?

i agree that i don't like hung over or too drunk beer, so i guess i'd  
have to say i'm willing to pay more.  in my travels in europe this  
summer, so far my favorite was the polish local beer called Tao.  and  
with our exchange rate still favorable in poland, you'll pay about  
$1.50 a pint, maybe $2.  carlsberg on tap is real good too.  plus  
there's a bar on practically every street corner, poland seems to be  
a pretty big drinking town, and the clubs are open late too ... i  
really would like to go back.


On Jun 20, 2007, at 8:17 AM, John B wrote:

> I like beer, but I don't like getting drunk or hung over on beer.
>
> So when I'm out and about and in a beery mood, I usually go with a  
> good stout.  Guinness is always a good choice and is pretty  
> ubiquitous, so that's what I usually get.  But I'm always up to try  
> new kinds.
>
> The advantage being:  Not only do I just like them better than  
> lighter beers; but (getting back to my initial point) when you're  
> drinking a nice thick stout, no one thinks you're a killjoy when  
> you nurse it along for a good while.  It's just too thick to drink  
> quickly anyway.  So I can still go and be beery and sociable, but  
> actually wind up drinking much less and not getting drunk or hung  
> over.
>
>
> cya,
> john
>
>
> On Jun 18, 2007, at 6:07 PM, Sean G wrote:
>
>> What's your favorite ghetto beer for a night out on the town/dusty
>> sub-basement? Mickeys? The High Life?

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: Dyn-O-Might! 2 - Tonight! @ Mighty

It's tonight people.  Get out and dance!


Dyn-O-Might RETURNS!!!!!!!
Tuesday, July 3rd, 2007
@ Mighty (119 Utah)
10pm-4am
Presales: Limited $7 (SOLDOUT), then $10 - groovetickets.com until 4pm on 7/3
Door tickets: $10 b4 11:30 & $15 afterwards
21+ w/ID


Evil Breaks, Sister SF, In Deep, along with the new addition, the
Ambient Mafia, will be teaming up to bring you a 4th of July party
celebration you're not going to forget. And since everyone has the
following day off, why not come and spend your Tuesday night in
debaucherous style with us at one of the best venues in the city??

Many of us know and love the music of our headliner, Carbon Community,
but noone has seen him do his Live show in SF since we brought him out
waaaay back in December of 2005. Dave will also be bringing out his
drummer Pete who will be playing on his full drum kit, along with Dave
bangin away on his synths & hanging drums. Carbon Community Live has
been constantly compared to Uberzone's Live show, and with the
addition of the hanging, light-up drums, it just might be taking it
one step further. If you missed seeing Carbon Community Live the last
time they were out here you really need to come see how amazing a Full
Live PA can be.




Carbon Community - FULL LIVE PA!! (w/Cradlerock on drums)
(Re:Connect/Sober Music/Bless Records/Beats & Lyrics/Blue Plasma) - Dallas, TX


Evil Breaks dj's:

Aaron Jae
Bam
M.O.D.
Athena


In Deep dj's:

Clark Hamon
Shooey
Zach Moore


Sister SF dj's:

Forest Green vs Seraphim
Samira vs Icon
Melyss vs Amber


Ambient Mafia dj's:

Sixtyuk vs Redstickman
Peek vs Speakeasy Ray
Squelchy vs Olde Nasty
Cubik vs Rafiq (Live!)
The Captain


Timeslots:

Main Room:

10-11 Zach Moore
11-12 Forest & Seraphim
12-1 Clark Hamon
1-2 Carbon Community Live w/Pete on drums
2-4 E.B. mashup (Aaron Jae, Bam, M.O.D.)



Back Room:

11-12 Athena
12-1 Melyss & Amber
1-2 Shooey
2-3 Icon & Samira


Z Bus:

11-12 sixty4k vs. redstickman
12-1 peek vs. speakeasy ray
1-2 boomerang fidget vs. rafiq (live!)
2-3 squelchy vs. olde nasty
3-4 the captain


Happy B-Day Dave & Carribbean.....



--

< Brandon / DJ Bam >

Message-ID: <262987.27466.qm@web36803.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] so. . .

Ever wonder ....

1) Creepy peeps like Cheney know that they are
constantly pressing against the line of social and
political unrest. They move the line little by little
and thus people never get outraged enough at one time
to step up and say THIS HAS GOT TO STOP!

2) Remember when Bush said whoever was responsible for
leaking Vallerie Plame would be dealt with?

3) Did you know Hitler used nationalism and propoganda
campaigns to ease into the holocaust? He killed the
retards first. Then started putting down dissenting
politicians (ie: the attorney general scandal), then
gypsies, then Jews...

4) Did you know that we rounded up all Japanese people
and put them in camps 50 yrs ago? Does that seem
anything like Gitmo to you? You think that maybe Gitmo
is in Cuba because it would seem a little too much
like the Angel Island internment camp if it wasn't?

5) Do you think more people would be outraged if the
papers and 24 hour news agencies were alllowed to take
phgotogs of the 4000 soldiers killed in Iraq? Think
the feds don't know that? What aboput the 25,000 +
vets missing arms and legs? Think they'll be
successful and happy about their service in 10 yrs
when this mess is trying to be forgotten?

6) Imagine being an Arab today. Can you imagine how
scary it would be to try and speak up? What list does
that get you on?

Happy 4th of July. I am quite sure what we have today
is not what anyone from the developing years of this
nation had in mind.

E

PS.... The "Moran" photo helps to explain a lot. The
people least likely to be affected by terrorists are
the ones most affected by it. WHY? ... because not
only are they most open to nationalistic propoganda,
they are also the most likely to join the military,
and thus die.

relatives to accept such a disgrace.
Want to dance?

On 3 July 2007, Eric Spire wrote:

> Ever wonder ....
>
> 1) Creepy peeps like Cheney know that they are
> constantly pressing against the line of social and
> political unrest. They move the line little by little
> and thus people never get outraged enough at one time
> to step up and say THIS HAS GOT TO STOP!

I'll borrow a quote to respond to this:
"If people will pay for water bottled in plastic, they will suffer any 
indignity."
- Derrick Jensen

Listen to more here:
http://www.indybay.org/uploads/2006/04/11/derrickjensen032906part1.mp3

>
> 2) Remember when Bush said whoever was responsible for
> leaking Vallerie Plame would be dealt with?

:)  He was.  Just NOT in the way that was implied at the time.

>
> 3) Did you know Hitler used nationalism and propoganda
> campaigns to ease into the holocaust? He killed the
> retards first. Then started putting down dissenting
> politicians (ie: the attorney general scandal), then
> gypsies, then Jews...

The jews that stood up in the Warsaw uprising had a higher survival rate 
than those that didn't.

>
> 4) Did you know that we rounded up all Japanese people
> and put them in camps 50 yrs ago? Does that seem
> anything like Gitmo to you? You think that maybe Gitmo
> is in Cuba because it would seem a little too much
> like the Angel Island internment camp if it wasn't?
>
> 5) Do you think more people would be outraged if the
> papers and 24 hour news agencies were alllowed to take
> phgotogs of the 4000 soldiers killed in Iraq? Think
> the feds don't know that? What aboput the 25,000 +
> vets missing arms and legs? Think they'll be
> successful and happy about their service in 10 yrs
> when this mess is trying to be forgotten?
>
> 6) Imagine being an Arab today. Can you imagine how
> scary it would be to try and speak up? What list does
> that get you on?
>
> Happy 4th of July. I am quite sure what we have today
> is not what anyone from the developing years of this
> nation had in mind.
>
> E
>
> PS.... The "Moran" photo helps to explain a lot. The
> people least likely to be affected by terrorists are
> the ones most affected by it. WHY? ... because not
> only are they most open to nationalistic propoganda,
> they are also the most likely to join the military,
> and thus die.
>

On Tue, 3 Jul 2007, Van Mundegaarde wrote:
-&e->No, I just know that drawing lines in the sand over something as retarded
-&e->as burning a flag is for knee-JERK reactionaries, and "arm-chair general"
-&e->types.

I've really reached the point where just punching someone is pretty much 
only instigated by violence on someone else's part first.  It's a pretty 
stupid way to resolve things, I have occasional visual/balance problems 
cause of a bat I took across the head when I was in high school, and a 
scar on my leg from a cheap piece of shit that pulled a knife in a fight 
(where he started it!) and didn't like the fact that I dropped him.

Burning a flag bugs me, but I'm pretty sure we have the right to do it.  
On the other hand, beating someone down over a philosphical difference is 
just downright bullydom.  Scott, you're smart enough to realize the people 
you mentioned didn't sacrifice, fight and possibly die for that flag but 
rather what it represents and the people they care for.  If someone tried 
to burn the people I care for, that's a totally different story... it 
becomes a matter of a violent address to violence because of immediate 
threat.  People sell out America every day, but they tend to be pretty 
damn sneaky about it.  A flag burning politico trying to get heard about 
some point is usually not the enemy here.

-&e->You're so gung-ho and pro-America, shut the fuck up and go defend our flag
-&e->in Iraq.

Eh, that's just stirring shit... and while I empathize and support our 
soldiers and non-miltary contractors doing what they do out there, the 
administration who called the shots in Iraq has done a horrible disservice 
to not just our future but global geopolitics for the life of oil as a 
commodity and islamic extremism.  If you were to play degrees of 
seperation, GW Bush is a lot closer to Bin Laden by various metrics..., 
contacts, history and even philosophy than I am to either of them.  When 
you think about things that way, unquestionable American nationalism 
doesn't make quite the sense it does in a vaccuum.  Both use what power 
they have to advance religious agendas, both are controversial leaders in 
their communities because of questionable methods and justifications, etc.  
I'm just a schmuck who likes to write long emails...

I love this place, but a big part of that love is tolerance (tolerance, if 
you think about it is the other half of freedom... you take freedoms, you 
take liberties, but only by other people granting you the tolerance and 
understanding to do so even when they don't agree).  I think if I saw 
somweone burning a flag, I'd play into what they're wanting... namely 
asking them why they're doing it.  And then, I'd remind them that they're 
fucking morons cause there aren't many viable reasons for doing so.  But 
if I was like, a UPS guy who drove off a road and was stranded, and I went 
in the back and I had a big shipment of American flags in the back, you'd 
best believe they'd be my blanket, toilet paper and firewood.

andyw

p.s. Also, sore subject for me today, 5 douchebags tried to mug me and a 
friend last night right outside the Powell street BART last night.  
Really difficult to make ok with the whole might makes right thing when 
you're on the wrong end of a really unfair situation.

> -&e->No, I just know that drawing lines in the sand over something as
> retarded
> -&e->as burning a flag is for knee-JERK reactionaries, and "arm-chair
> general"
> -&e->types.
>
> I've really reached the point where just punching someone is pretty much
> only instigated by violence on someone else's part first.  It's a pretty
> stupid way to resolve things, I have occasional visual/balance problems
> cause of a bat I took across the head when I was in high school, and a
> scar on my leg from a cheap piece of shit that pulled a knife in a fight
> (where he started it!) and didn't like the fact that I dropped him.
>
> Burning a flag bugs me, but I'm pretty sure we have the right to do it.
> On the other hand, beating someone down over a philosphical difference is
> just downright bullydom.  Scott, you're smart enough to realize the people
> you mentioned didn't sacrifice, fight and possibly die for that flag but
> rather what it represents and the people they care for.  If someone tried
> to burn the people I care for, that's a totally different story... it
> becomes a matter of a violent address to violence because of immediate
> threat.  People sell out America every day, but they tend to be pretty
> damn sneaky about it.  A flag burning politico trying to get heard about
> some point is usually not the enemy here.
>
> -&e->You're so gung-ho and pro-America, shut the fuck up and go defend our
> flag
> -&e->in Iraq.
>
> Eh, that's just stirring shit... and while I empathize and support our
> soldiers and non-miltary contractors doing what they do out there, the
> administration who called the shots in Iraq has done a horrible disservice
> to not just our future but global geopolitics for the life of oil as a
> commodity and islamic extremism.  If you were to play degrees of
> seperation, GW Bush is a lot closer to Bin Laden by various metrics...,
> contacts, history and even philosophy than I am to either of them.  When
> you think about things that way, unquestionable American nationalism
> doesn't make quite the sense it does in a vaccuum.  Both use what power
> they have to advance religious agendas, both are controversial leaders in
> their communities because of questionable methods and justifications, etc.
> I'm just a schmuck who likes to write long emails...
>
> I love this place, but a big part of that love is tolerance (tolerance, if
> you think about it is the other half of freedom... you take freedoms, you
> take liberties, but only by other people granting you the tolerance and
> understanding to do so even when they don't agree).  I think if I saw
> somweone burning a flag, I'd play into what they're wanting... namely
> asking them why they're doing it.  And then, I'd remind them that they're
> fucking morons cause there aren't many viable reasons for doing so.  But
> if I was like, a UPS guy who drove off a road and was stranded, and I went
> in the back and I had a big shipment of American flags in the back, you'd
> best believe they'd be my blanket, toilet paper and firewood.
>
> andyw
>
> p.s. Also, sore subject for me today, 5 douchebags tried to mug me and a
> friend last night right outside the Powell street BART last night.
> Really difficult to make ok with the whole might makes right thing when
> you're on the wrong end of a really unfair situation.
>

your right to your opinions and your wacko-loony lifestyles, but when
you mess with the American flag, you've gone too far, sir.  You can
have all your tolerance and homosexual agendas with Nancy Pelosi and
the far left liberal ring of the Democratic Party - all financed by
George Soros - but when you come here, to the No Spin Zone, and talk
about burning the flag, that's just too much.  I think many factor
viewers out there will join me in saying, Andy W, you've gone too far.

And that's tonight's Talking Points memo...

On 7/3/07, AndyW <andy@saturn5.com> wrote:
>
> On Tue, 3 Jul 2007, Van Mundegaarde wrote:
> -&e->No, I just know that drawing lines in the sand over something as retarded
> -&e->as burning a flag is for knee-JERK reactionaries, and "arm-chair general"
> -&e->types.
>
> I've really reached the point where just punching someone is pretty much
> only instigated by violence on someone else's part first.  It's a pretty
> stupid way to resolve things, I have occasional visual/balance problems
> cause of a bat I took across the head when I was in high school, and a
> scar on my leg from a cheap piece of shit that pulled a knife in a fight
> (where he started it!) and didn't like the fact that I dropped him.
>
> Burning a flag bugs me, but I'm pretty sure we have the right to do it.
> On the other hand, beating someone down over a philosphical difference is
> just downright bullydom.  Scott, you're smart enough to realize the people
> you mentioned didn't sacrifice, fight and possibly die for that flag but
> rather what it represents and the people they care for.  If someone tried
> to burn the people I care for, that's a totally different story... it
> becomes a matter of a violent address to violence because of immediate
> threat.  People sell out America every day, but they tend to be pretty
> damn sneaky about it.  A flag burning politico trying to get heard about
> some point is usually not the enemy here.
>
> -&e->You're so gung-ho and pro-America, shut the fuck up and go defend our flag
> -&e->in Iraq.
>
> Eh, that's just stirring shit... and while I empathize and support our
> soldiers and non-miltary contractors doing what they do out there, the
> administration who called the shots in Iraq has done a horrible disservice
> to not just our future but global geopolitics for the life of oil as a
> commodity and islamic extremism.  If you were to play degrees of
> seperation, GW Bush is a lot closer to Bin Laden by various metrics...,
> contacts, history and even philosophy than I am to either of them.  When
> you think about things that way, unquestionable American nationalism
> doesn't make quite the sense it does in a vaccuum.  Both use what power
> they have to advance religious agendas, both are controversial leaders in
> their communities because of questionable methods and justifications, etc.
> I'm just a schmuck who likes to write long emails...
>
> I love this place, but a big part of that love is tolerance (tolerance, if
> you think about it is the other half of freedom... you take freedoms, you
> take liberties, but only by other people granting you the tolerance and
> understanding to do so even when they don't agree).  I think if I saw
> somweone burning a flag, I'd play into what they're wanting... namely
> asking them why they're doing it.  And then, I'd remind them that they're
> fucking morons cause there aren't many viable reasons for doing so.  But
> if I was like, a UPS guy who drove off a road and was stranded, and I went
> in the back and I had a big shipment of American flags in the back, you'd
> best believe they'd be my blanket, toilet paper and firewood.
>
> andyw
>
> p.s. Also, sore subject for me today, 5 douchebags tried to mug me and a
> friend last night right outside the Powell street BART last night.
> Really difficult to make ok with the whole might makes right thing when
> you're on the wrong end of a really unfair situation.

When I was growing up there was a lot of fuss over flag burning those crazy kids wearing flags on their clothes.  Taht was about 40 years ago.  There were actually a lot of people that were upset about all of those sorts of items.  You certainly couldn't go into Disneyland wearing anything with a flag on it or even a flag fragment back in the sixties or seventies for example.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] so. . .

On Tue, 03 Jul 2007 15:54:25 -0700, AndyW <andy@saturn5.com> wrote:

> Scott, you're smart enough to realize the people
> you mentioned didn't sacrifice, fight and possibly die for that flag but
> rather what it represents and the people they care for.

You're entirely correct, and I apologize for being too brief-
But to me I see a difference between burning the flag and say, burning an  
effigy of Bush.
One is a statement about the current state of things, the other is a much  
larger statement...
Like hanging my flag upside down as a signal of dire national distress (as  
it is hung now)-
Versus burning the flag and all that it has represented through history  
and disgracing everything that we as a nation have accomplished-

I'll defend your right to do either, but one will be met with capital-P  
Protest.

-- 
Scott Solmonson
V: 408.718.6290
scosol@scosol.org

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] bsp: 07.07.07 [KONTROL] w/ Bruno Pronsato, Drumcell, and JamesPatrick!

Highly recommended show!

Bruno Pronsato, as he's known, is bad bad bad ass. He's dared to take
electronic music into dark, swampy soul cranking waters that
consistantly blow me away. What else can I say but don't miss a chance
to see him while he's on his U.S. tour.

Also, look forward to James Patrick aka JP. This man has created many
techno miracles in Minneapolis and is hugely respected by all. Ask him
about 'the pocket' parties they're throwing in a parking garage! (an
idea worth imitating, I think).

We had JP perform his style of "detail oriented dance music" at the
Dark Room back in September and he had a pretty wide range of the
minimal side of techno, including a lot of older material from the
first expressions of this genre.

-Solekandi

> Flyer back:
> http://www.kontrolsf.com/K25/K25B.jpg
> Poster:
> http://www.kontrolsf.com/K25/K25P.jpg
>
> ____________________________________________________
>
>
> BRUNO PRONSATO
>
> Seattle via Berlin producer Bruno Pronsato (aka Steven Ford) took several
> giant steps in 2005 toward the peak of the experimental techno mountain.
> Both on vinyl and onstage, Pronsato kept up a hectic pace of production a=
nd
> performance, catalyzing listeners and crowds in Germany, Switzerland,
> Turkey, Mexico, throughout the United States, and a triumphant set at
> Montreal's MUTEK festival. Twelve-inches on esteemed labels like Orac,
> Musique Risqu=E9e, Milnor Modern, Philpot, and Telegraph further elevated=
 his
> stature and built his international fan base.
>
> A sound scientist whose work is equally playful and rigorous, Pronsato
> deploys a canny use of space and idiosyncratically fashioned rhythms to
> disorient and build suspense=97like some 21st-century Miles Davis or Eric
> Dolphy of the laptop. Despite being a minimal-techno artist, Pronsato off=
ers
> a palette that's as full of unexpected patterns and meticulously rendered
> textures as a Wassily Kandinsky painting.
>
> Pronsato's compositions unsettle in original ways, yet they also slyly
> tickle funnybones. Often both humorous and erotic, his cuts are the wild
> cards that adventurous DJs pull out when they want to take the dance floo=
r
> to strange new levels of motion. Therefore, Pronsato's releases have beco=
me
> elite selectors' secret weapons of beguilingly baffling quirkiness that
> still move asses.
>
> Unsurprisingly, 2006 is promising to be as eventful as last year. As dema=
nd
> for his music has waxed, Pronsato has accordingly increased his productiv=
ity
> while maintaining his usual exacting quality control standards. March wil=
l
> bring Pronsato's debut 12 for Hello? Repeat while summer 2006 will see EP=
s
> issued by Orac and Telegraph (watch for the last two editions of the
> four-part Limeworks series), plus another collaboration with Argentinean
> Franco Cinelli for Milnor Modern (Picaro, their first joint effort from l=
ate
> '05, contains some of Pronsato's most flavorful club bangers). A temporar=
y
> residence in Holland will enable Pronsato to spend even more time in 2006
> devastating European audiences with his uniquely psychedelic and funky
> techno live sets.
>
>
> Discography:
> http://www.discogs.com/artist/Bruno%20Pronsato
>
> Website:
> http://www.undosounds.com/
>
> Exclusive interview w/ Bruno on mnml.nl:
> http://www.mnml.nl/phpBB2/viewtopic.php?t=3D7908
>
>
> ________________________________________________
>
>
> DRUMCELL
>
> Founder of Droid Recordings and co-founder of Droid Behavior, Drumcell (a=
ka
> Mohamed "Moe" Espinosa) has been one of techno's greatest allies in South=
ern
> California in recent times. A graduate of the Musician's Institute and a
> long-time performer at parties in Southern California, Drumcell has been
> influenced by music from his earliest years. After being exposed to raves=
 in
> the early 90s, He grew addicted to the sounds of acid house, techno, in i=
ts
> many forms, and industrial.
>
> It was not long before he was copping turntables to satisfy his vinyl
> fetish. By the early age of 14 he was playing in various local bands, and
> through out the rest of his teenage years, cut his teeth-producing hip ho=
p
> records, dub and various forms of electronic music on Los Angeles based
> underground labels. By combining his production, DJing and networking ski=
lls
> and focusing in on his more mature musical tastes he soon established
> himself as one of the major players in LA's growing techno scene.
>
> Associating with the members of Acid Circus to form Droid Behavior as an
> event production group and record label was the next logical step to rais=
e
> awareness for techno in the city and to help expose local Artists,
> established djs, and performers from around the country.
>
> Over the last 5 years Drumcell has rocked parties from big to small on a
> weekly basis in LA as well as gigs all over the U.S alongside such names =
as
> Kenny Larkin, John Tejada, Tim Xavier, Daniel Bell, Ben Sims, Adam Beyer,
> Jeff Mills, Speedy J, Ritchie Hawtin, Mathew Dear, etc. and has also
> released quite a few heavy tracks on labels Omniscient, Remains, Heavy
> Industries, and his own DROID Recordings imprint.
>
> Drumcell has been known to keep on the edge of technology and continuousl=
y
> pushing the limits to what the future has to offer.He is always in the
> process of developing homebrew software as well as cutting edge hardware
> solution to bring a fresh innovative taste to his production and
> performances. When performing, Drumcell can be seen blurring the lines
> between a live and a DJ set by utilizing tools such as FX processors,
> samplers, drum machines and other devices  to weave a thick blend of acid=
ic
> techno and aggressive but funky minimalist groove to ensure a frenzy amon=
gst
> his listeners.
>
> With the state of electronic music in North America leaning towards strip=
ped
> down funk rather then progressive fluff these days, Droid has become the
> center for LA techno and Drumcell remains steadfast in his mission of
> putting this city on the global map.
>
>
> Website:
> http://www.droidbehavior.com/drumcell.html
>
> Discography:
> http://www.discogs.com/artist/Drumcell
>
> MySpace:
> http://www.mypsace.com/drumcell
>
> Live Recording:
> http://www.rotfest.com/droid/mp3/Drumcell_Live@Avalon_R.Hawtin-J.Mills.mp=
3
>
> Most Recent Studio mix :
> http://www.rotfest.com/droid/mp3/drumcell%20mix%202.mp3
>
>
> _____________________________________________________
>
>
> JAMESPATRICK
>
> JamesPatrick promotes and plays detail oriented dance music for the feet =
and
> the mind.  Directing a movement of minimal/dub techno in the Midwest, JP
> pushes the definitions of "forward thinking media" into new realms.
> "Improvising with music and technology" has become the manifesto of his
> lifelong journey.
>
> JamesPatrick has enjoyed 10+ years of playing music around the world, and
> throwing parties with, and playing alongside likewise innovators in the
> genre;  Bruno Pronsato, Someone Else, Miskate, Ezekiel Honig, Sutekh, Sam=
my
> Dee, Jay Haze, Magda, Richie Hawtin, Algorithm, Ben Nevile, Randy Jones,
> Jake Fairley, Dapayk, Baby Ford, Mike Shannon, Deadbeat/Crackhaus, Barem,
> Butane, Richard Devine, and many more.
>
> JP has for the last few years also been one half of the Klikmusik project
> with fellow Minneapolis techno afficionado Mike G.  Their two man extende=
d
> cooperative dj+laptop+fx sets have captivated listeners throughout the
> Midwest while pushing the boundaries of a traditional DJ set to new level=
s.
>
> Currently, JP teaches software music production at Minneapolis' Institute=
 of
> Production and Recording, and he directs the websites www.microphono.com,
> www.vitalvinyl.com, and www.secrettechno.com.
>
>
> MySpace:
> http://www.myspace.com/microhouseminneapolis
>
> DJ sets:
> http://secrettechno.com/jamespatrick/geologic1.15.05/jamespatrick-geologi=
c7.17.2005.mp3
>
> http://secrettechno.com/jamespatrick/natspill1.27.07/jamespatrick@natspil=
l1.27.07.mp3
>
> More DJ sets:
> www.secrettechno.com/jamespatrick
>
>
> _____________________________________________________
>
> http://www.kontrolsf.com

but first, a few questions...

Can a multidimensional penis get busy with a wormhole and would it change 
my claimed sexual orientation?  Can a pan dimensional schlong be expressed 
using an n-by-n matrix?  Do traditional scalar metrics still hold?  Do 
women who are sensitive to these additional dimensions still claim certain 
linear measurements are of little merit?  How does the "motion of the 
ocean" plot against non-newtonian spacetime?  If I whip it around, can 
this still be mathematically modeled using a sum of vectors approach?  
>From a string theory point of view, would this increase the heretofore 
considered constant Planck length of my jizz missle?  Could they just turn 
my pocket rocket into a Lorentz gun instead... (cause shooting plasma 
channels rather than baby batter would be pretty damn cool)?

Brilliant job on their part throwing off the buzzword searches though.

Subject: [sfraves] videos of dancing?

hey sfraves list,

i'm working on an art project (4kb production for a demo party) and
want to do some vectorized silhouette's dancing (if you're familiar w/
"the scene" you'll remember these styles from some amiga demos)

don't have a video camera of my own, but i'd like to use all original
material. so if you have any videos of yourself or friends dancing, or
similar videos from parties you've been too ... and wouldn't mind the
things being vectorized for this project ... please get in touch!

thanks much
j.ordan aka k9d/nd

Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Wed)

Happy 4th of July.  I propose you take a moment to reflect on what the =20
Founding Fathers fought and died for.  If they were here today, what =20
would they think of us?  May we last another 230 years.

Today's quote was inspired by a thread on the DCRaves list asking your =20
version of the American Dream.  I looked up the term on Wikipedia, =20
curious of how far back that term goes, and it suggests this term was =20
first used when this book was written.  I find it ironic it was =20
written in the middle of the Great Depression.  So no matter how hard =20
the bankers try to destroy our country, they can never destroy the =20
dream.  We may be kind of down and out right now but I believe we'll =20
bounce back and that will spread around the world.

I don't want to ramble on too much more.  Go enjoy your tofu barbeque.


--

If, as I have said, the things already listed were all we had to =20
contribute, America would have made no distinctive and unique gift to =20
mankind. But there has been also the American dream, that dream of a =20
land in which life should be better and richer and fuller for every =20
man, with opportunity for each according to his ability or achievement.

- James Truslow Adams, "The Epic of America" (1931)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] so. . .

Err, well that was supposed to be a humorous response to the flushing the toilet comment from pinkko.  But ok.

I agree and I support your right to say and do what you want even if I don't like it.  But realistically if you burn a flag in front of someone's house you are not only exercising free speech you are doing something purposely inflamatory (heh) with the intention of offending them. I don't care if you call it free speech or not, the intention is to offend.  

The question I have is whether flag burning can ever be constructive in any conceivable way.  

Scott has already said what he'll do to anyone that burns a flag near him, and while I certainly don't support his threatening people here or actually beating them because they burned a flag, now that he's announced his feelings about flag burning we know where he stands.  Burning a flag in front of his house should be expected to produce a bad result.   I wouldn't do it.

Does burning a flag in front of him make the world a better place?  I say no, it just really pisses him off.  And the world needs less anger in it not more.

Regards,

Peter

sarilion

>Err, well that was supposed to be a humorous response to the 
>flushing the toilet comment from pinkko.  But ok.
>
>I agree and I support your right to say and do what you want even if 
>I don't like it.  But realistically if you burn a flag in front of 
>someone's house you are not only exercising free speech you are 
>doing something purposely inflamatory (heh) with the intention of 
>offending them. I don't care if you call it free speech or not, the 
>intention is to offend.
>
>The question I have is whether flag burning can ever be constructive 
>in any conceivable way.
>
>Scott has already said what he'll do to anyone that burns a flag 
>near him, and while I certainly don't support his threatening people 
>here or actually beating them because they burned a flag, now that 
>he's announced his feelings about flag burning we know where he 
>stands.  Burning a flag in front of his house should be expected to 
>produce a bad result.   I wouldn't do it.
>
>Does burning a flag in front of him make the world a better 
>place?  I say no, it just really pisses him off.  And the world 
>needs less anger in it not more.
>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] so. . .

SARCASM ALERT!!!

Whats wrong with burning a cross? As a Jew, it is part
of our secret Friday Night Sabath Rituals. When the
Gollum is let out of the basement of the synagogue, we
all remove our yarmulkas exposing our horns, and burn
a cross while running around the synagogue speaking in
toungues. You probably think that "tounges" is hebrew,
but boy are you wrong. And yarmulkas are not worn out
of respect for god, but rather to cover our horns,
which we grind down each week after they magicallly
reapppear during the cross-burning ritual.

SARCASM OFF!!

Simmer down folks. Whats great about SFR is we can all
believe in totally different shit, have different
ideals, philosophies, etc... But at the end of the
day, we all have one thing in common... We know what
it is like to have a collective experience associated
with dance music. Don't forget that all this politics,
religion, philosophy shit gets left at the door when
you go out for a night of dance and music.

Eric

>Whats wrong with burning a cross? As a Jew, it is part

>Gollum is let out of the basement of the synagogue, we
>all remove our yarmulkas exposing our horns, and burn
>a cross while running around the synagogue speaking in
>toungues. You probably think that "tounges" is hebrew,
>but boy are you wrong. And yarmulkas are not worn out
>of respect for god, but rather to cover our horns,
>which we grind down each week after they magicallly
>reapppear during the cross-burning ritual.
>
>SARCASM OFF!!
>
>Simmer down folks. Whats great about SFR is we can all
>believe in totally different shit, have different
>ideals, philosophies, etc... But at the end of the
>day, we all have one thing in common... We know what
>it is like to have a collective experience associated
>with dance music. Don't forget that all this politics,
>religion, philosophy shit gets left at the door when
>you go out for a night of dance and music.

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: 'BACK ON TRACK' - SATURDAY 7.7.7

BACK ON TRACK

SATURDAY JULY 7th
FAT CITY
314 11th Street
San Francisco


So, whether you know it or not, I have not played a
gig in SF since 2001. I am really excited to be coming
back this weekend to play with and for people that
have been part of the SF scene since the 90's. The
line-up is top notch, I have heard incrediblle things
about the decor, and with Terry doing visuals you know
it is going to be an incredible display.

On top of this, I am bringing my Fiance Tiffany, who
has only heard the stories, the tales, the rumblings
of the great times we used to have. I truly want her
to have a complete experience... So please come out
and show her what a party can be like. All she knows
is pimped out clubs with table service and bad music.
I WANT TO CHANGE ALL THAT.

I know chuck is going to post the line-up soon, but
regardless, we are coming down to see old faces and
new, smile, dance and enjoy ourselves, so we'll be
there most of the night. Come find us and say hi.

Regardless, I know the music is going to ROCK. Lots of
your favorite locals, a couple of great
out-of-towners, and a Holiday weekend your SUPPOSED to
party on.

So lets do it old skool, bring back THAT vibe, and get
BACK ON TRACK.

Eric

PS... If you come talk to me and tell me you are from
SFR, I'll make sure you get a funny Silver Pearl T-Shirt

Flyer: http://www.kittyblunts.com/caligrown/graphics/flyer_back_v2.jpg


Saturday, July 7th 2007 (7.7.7) San Francisco, 9:30 PM - 6:00 AM:

CaliGrown Events proudly presents BACK ON TRACK, featuring world-class acts from Belgium, Chicago, Las Vegas, and San Francisco. Party all night while grooving to:

CONGA SQUAD aka C-MOS (Holographic Music, Belgium)
Known to many as Conga Squad, Olivier Abbeloos also produces under names such as C-Mos, Goldbumpers, Dynetic, Bio-nic, Inferno, Quadrophonia, T99, and Kretek. Over the past 15 years, this Disco House master has developed a signature sound that is like no other in House music. His style of pumpin, steppy, driving Disco House has made Olivier a huge success with many of the most influential DJ's from around the world. Not only a successful music producer, Mr. Abbeloos is also a successful DJ with over 18 years of experience.
Olivier Abbeloos performs all over the world, and has several residencies in his home country of Belgium including La Rocca. Abbeloos is also the founder & primary artist of legendary House labels Holographic Music & E.P.O.S, and has released over fifty (50) tracks to date! DO NOT UNDER ANY CIRCUMSTANCES MISS CONGA SQUAD!
MORE INFO: WWW.HOLOGRAPHICMUSIC.COM
http://www.myspace.com/abbeloosolivier

HIGH CALIBER: DJ BRYAN JONES & MIKE GILLENWATER (Control Recordings, Chicago)
Wrapping up his international Step Back 2007 Tour, DJ Bryan Jones joins Mike Gillenwater as High Caliber, originally formed in late 2002. Both artists hail from Chicago where theyve independently established themselves as icons in the Funky House scene. Five years and nearly 20 chart-busting EPs later, High Caliber is releasing their biggest project to date: Old School Sessions, a four-part all-digital mix series that was too long to condense into one album. Catch tracks from this new groundbreaking series along with other HC classics for a floor-rocking experience San Francisco will surely not forget!
MORE INFO: WWW.MYSPACE.COM/HIGHCALIBERCHICAGO

JENO (WICKED,SF)
A name that needs no introduction in SF House Music, Jeno has been organizing legendary underground parties and rocking dance floors around the world since the mid-eighties. As one of the Wicked DJs, Jeno helped define an eclectic and soulful musical style that was the original sound of San Francisco.
MORE INFO: WWW.DJJENO.COM
http://www.myspace.com/jeno

ERIC SPIRE (Silver Pearl Records / Sony Records / QUEST , Bay Area & Las Vegas)
The owner & founder of Silver Pearl records, world-famous DJ, and founding father of Quest; Eric Spire has spent the past 7 years in the studio producing major label acts, television themes, movie soundtracks, video game sound bytes, and quite of bit of Dance Music. Missing the excitement of the crowd, Eric is returning to the decks to grace his fans with another masterful & soul-moving set that they have been craving since 2000!
MORE INFO: WWW.SILVERPEARL.COM
http://www.myspace.com/silverprl1

WITH SPECIAL GUESTS:

THE MARIO BROS. - TAG SET (OtherWorld / Tech Funk Alliance / Midnight Sons / Essential Breaks West, SF)
What can we say about these guys? They're fucking awesome! The Mario Bros. is made up of one part "daniella downs", one part "Marc(O)" and a whole lot of pimp juice. They are best served straight up in a highball glass...
http://www.myspace.com/the_mario_bros
http://www.themidnightsons.com

THE FINGERMONSTERS - LIVE PA (SHAZBOT, ORIGAMI, ANDREW PHELAN, and CUBIK , SF)
The Fingermonsters create maximal floor-magnet tracks with tongue firmly in cheek and hands firmly on knobs. Theyve been tearing San Francisco and the Bay Area a new one with a 4-person live laptop/drum machine PA assault that is not to be missed!

DJ HEADCASE - LIVE PA - CD RELEASE PARTY (CaliGrown , SF)

JAYSON KINCAID (Grooves-in-the-Park / Culture / Om Records , SF)
http://www.myspace.com/jaysonkincaid

DEAN KROH (Seedless Music, Liquid Graf-X-209)

SF's own SPACE COWBOY DJS:
AARON JAE (Space Cowboys/XM/Evil Breaks)
KAPTN KIRK (Space Cowboys/Panda Rejects)
EVINRUDE (Space Cowboys/NetAmp)

CHILL HOURS HOSTED BY: THE AMBIENT MAFIA (www.ambientmafia.com)
MO CORLEONE (Want It/:am)
SQUELCHY (The Extra Credit/:am)
OLDE NASTY (Butterzone/:am)
REDSTICKMAN (BCC:/:am)


Additional Attractions:
Visuals, Set & Atmosphere by Eyezmind & Viberation.
Sexy GoGo Dancers by GOGO pro.
Rockin Sound System by Know:Audio!
Free CD & Shirt giveaways!

General Info:

VENUE:
FAT CITY (formerly Studio Z)
314 11th St.
San Francisco, CA

AGES:
21+ ID Required

ENTRY:
$10 LIMITED PRESALES (groovetickets.com) & BEFORE 11:00 PM: $15.00

DRESS CODE STRICTLY NOT ENFORCED!

More Info:
www.myspace.com/caligrownevents
www.caligrownevents.com

WTF are CaliGrown Events?

Were a spin-off of a former Central Valley UG rave crew called Elysium from the
late 90s - early 00s. Elysium produced several events in the Central Valley, and
some in the Bay Area including a residence at the now infamous Hotel Ibiza in
2001. We produce events out of love for the music and the vibe its followers carry.

Subject: [sfraves] DJ Sonix - King Of The Jungle (Upbeat summer Drum & Bass mix)

here's an upbeat dnb mix to get you started in the
proper summer fiesta mood. cheers!


DJ Sonix - King Of The Jungle
Duration = 60:10 mins.

01. Tester - The Lion
02. Mythology - Untouchable
03. Matrix & Futurebound - Skyscraper
04. Matrix & Futurebound - The Edge
05. Matrix & Futurebound - Universal Truth
06. Blame & The Pedge - Avalon
07. Mazzini - Freak
08. State Of Mind - Sun King (Chris Su Remix)
09. Mythology - Stuck In A Rut
10. Danny Byrd - Under The Sea
11. Klute - We Control The Vertical

14. CLS - Their Names Were Trot & Melon
15. Matrix & Futurebound feat. Louis Smith - Coast To
Coast
16. Klute - Hell Hath No Fury
17. Clipz - Download

Subject: [sfraves] Movement for the Emancipation of the Niger Delta

------=_Part_149029_19949201.1183668910439
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

The *Movement for the Emancipation of the Niger
Delta<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Niger_Delta>
* ("MEND") is a militant <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Militant> indigenous
people's movement dedicated to armed struggle against the exploitation and
oppression of the people of Niger Delta and the degradation of their natural
environment by foreign multinational corporations involved in the extraction
of oil <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oil> in their homeland.

It's also a new drum and bass mix by none other than yours truly.

http://pestilence.short-b.us/mp3/01%20Movement%20for%20the%20Emancipation%20of.mp3


Discuss.
<http://pestilence.short-b.us/mp3/01%20Movement%20for%20the%20Emancipation%20of.mp3>

------=_Part_149029_19949201.1183668910439--

Subject: [sfraves] [KONTROL] Saturday, July 7 with Bruno Pronsato, Drumcell and James Patrick

Saturday, July 7th, 2007
 
[KONTROL]
 
minimal techno + avant-house
every 1st Saturday @ The Endup
 

featuring from Berlin: 
 
BRUNO PRONSATO : live pa
 
( Hello?Repeat . Orac . Telegraph . Perlon . Musique
Risquee )
 
Over the last few years Bruno's steady stream of
quality releases
on some of the world's most esteemed labels, coupled
with his
rigorous international touring schedule, have brought
him to the
pinnacle of the experimental techno world.  Prepare
for a deep and
adventurous musical voyage into the mind of a truly
unique artist.
 

and from Los Angeles:
DRUMCELL : decks + fx
 
( Droid Behavior . Omniscient )
 
Founder of Droid Recordings and co-founder of LA's
most
respected techno crew Droid Behavior, Drumcell will be
showcasing
his energetic and driving take on minimal that has
been winning
over crowds and is helping to put LA on the global
map.
 

plus special guest from Minneapolis:
 
JAMESPATRICK
 
( Secret Techno . Klikmusik . Vital Vinyl . Microphono
)
 
Minneapolis' minimal honcho and devoted "tesh" (sexy
techno)
advocate JamesPatrick has been one of the most
important DJs
and promoters in the Midwest for the better part of a
decade. 
Tonight you'll hear why.
 

with the [KONTROL] all-star residents:
 
CRAIG KUNA   ( Concept SF . ESDJCO )
ALLAND BYALLO   ( Liebe*Detail . Floppy Funk )
NIKOLA BAYTALA   ( Robsoul . Junior Boys Own .
S.W.A.T. )
SAMMY D    ( Classic . Dirtybird . Utensil )
 
____________________________________________________
 
The ENDUP
401 6th St @ Harrison, SF
10pm - 6am / 21+ / $15
http://www.theendup.com
 
FREE until 11pm!
 
____________________________________________________
 
Full bios, pics and FREE music:
http://www.kontrolsf.com
 
[KONTROL] on MySpace:
http://www.myspace.com/kontrolsf
 
[ground.KONTROL] on Western Addition Radio:
http://www.westaddradio.com/kontrol/
 
Flyer front:
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K25/K25F.jpg
Flyer back:
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K25/K25B.jpg
Poster:
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K25 /K25P.jpg
 
____________________________________________________
 
 
BRUNO PRONSATO
 
Seattle via Berlin producer Bruno Pronsato (aka Steven
Ford) took several giant steps in 2005 toward the peak
of the experimental techno mountain. Both on vinyl and
onstage, Pronsato kept up a hectic pace of production
and performance, catalyzing listeners and crowds in
Germany, Switzerland, Turkey, Mexico, throughout the
United States, and a triumphant set at Montreal's
MUTEK festival. Twelve-inches on esteemed labels like
Orac, Musique Risqu&#65533;e, Milnor Modern, Philpot,
and Telegraph further elevated his stature and built
his international fan base
 
A sound scientist whose work is equally playful and
rigorous, Pronsato deploys a canny use of space and
idiosyncratically fashioned rhythms to disorient and
build suspense&#65533;like some 21st-century Miles
Davis or Eric Dolphy of the laptop. Despite being a
minimal-techno artist, Pronsato offers a palette
that's as full of unexpected patterns and meticulously
rendered textures as a Wassily Kandinsky painting.
 
Pronsato's compositions unsettle in original ways, yet
they also slyly tickle funnybones. Often both humorous
and erotic, his cuts are the wild cards that
adventurous DJs pull out when they want to take the
dance floor to strange new levels of motion.
Therefore, Pronsato's releases have become elite
selectors' secret weapons of beguilingly baffling
quirkiness that still move asses.
 
Unsurprisingly, 2006 is promising to be as eventful as
last year. As demand for his music has waxed, Pronsato
has accordingly increased his productivity while
maintaining his usual exacting quality control
standards. March will bring Pronsato's debut 12 for
Hello? Repeat while summer 2006 will see EPs issued by
Orac and Telegraph (watch for the last two editions of
the four-part Limeworks series), plus another
collaboration with Argentinean Franco Cinelli for
Milnor Modern (Picaro, their first joint effort from
late '05, contains some of Pronsato's most flavorful
club bangers). A temporary residence in Holland will
enable Pronsato to spend even more time in 2006
devastating European audiences with his uniquely
psychedelic and funky techno live sets.
 
 
Website:
http://www.undosounds.com/

Discography:
http://www.discogs.com/artist/Bruno%20Pronsato
 
Exclusive interview w/ Bruno on mnml.nl:
http://www.mnml.nl/phpBB2/viewtopic.php?t=7908

________________________________________________
 

DRUMCELL
 
Founder of Droid Recordings and co-founder of Droid
Behavior, Drumcell (aka Mohamed "Moe" Espinosa) has
been one of techno's greatest allies in Southern
California in recent times. A graduate of the
Musician's Institute and a long-time performer at
parties in Southern California, Drumcell has been
influenced by music from his earliest years. After
being exposed to raves in the early 90s, He grew
addicted to the sounds of acid house, techno, in its
many forms, and industrial.
 
It was not long before he was copping turntables to
satisfy his vinyl fetish. By the early age of 14 he
was playing in various local bands, and through out
the rest of his teenage years, cut his teeth-producing
hip hop records, dub and various forms of electronic
music on Los Angeles based underground labels. By
combining his production, DJing and networking skills
and focusing in on his more mature musical tastes he
soon established himself as one of the major players
in LA's growing techno scene.
 
Associating with the members of Acid Circus to form
Droid Behavior as an event production group and record
label was the next logical step to raise awareness for
techno in the city and to help expose local Artists,
established djs, and performers from around the
country.
 
Over the last 5 years Drumcell has rocked parties from
big to small on a weekly basis in LA as well as gigs
all over the U.S alongside such names as Kenny Larkin,
John Tejada, Tim Xavier, Daniel Bell, Ben Sims, Adam
Beyer, Jeff Mills, Speedy J, Ritchie Hawtin, Mathew
Dear, etc. and has also released quite a few heavy
tracks on labels Omniscient, Remains, Heavy
Industries, and his own DROID Recordings imprint.
 
Drumcell has been known to keep on the edge of
technology and be continuously pushing the limits to
what the future has to offer.  He is always in the
process of developing homebrew software as well as
cutting edge hardware solution to bring a fresh
innovative taste to his production and performances.
When performing, Drumcell can be seen blurring the
lines between a live and a DJ set by utilizing tools
such as FX processors, samplers, drum machines and
other devices  to weave a thick blend of acidic techno
and aggressive but funky minimalist groove to ensure a
frenzy amongst his listeners.
 
With the state of electronic music in North America
leaning towards stripped down funk rather then
progressive fluff these days, Droid has become the
center for LA techno and Drumcell remains steadfast in
his mission of putting this city on the global map.
 

Website:
http://www.droidbehavior.com/drumcell.html
 
Discography:
http://www.discogs.com/artist/Drumcell
 
MySpace:
http://www.mypsace.com/drumcell
 
Live recording:
http://www.rotfest.com/droid/mp3/Drumcell_Live@Avalon_R.Hawtin-J.Mills.mp3
 
Most recent studio mix :
http://www.rotfest.com/droid/mp3/drumcell%20mix%202.mp3

_____________________________________________________
 

JAMESPATRICK
 
JamesPatrick promotes and plays detail oriented dance
music for the feet and the mind.  Directing a movement
of minimal/dub techno in the Midwest, JP pushes the
definitions of "forward thinking media" into new
realms.  "Improvising with music and technology" has
become the manifesto of his lifelong journey.
 
JamesPatrick has enjoyed 10+ years of playing music
around the world, and throwing parties with, and
playing alongside likewise innovators in the genre; 
Bruno Pronsato, Someone Else, Miskate, Ezekiel Honig,
Sutekh, Sammy Dee, Jay Haze, Magda, Richie Hawtin,
Algorithm, Ben Nevile, Randy Jones, Jake Fairley,
Dapayk, Baby Ford, Mike Shannon, Deadbeat/Crackhaus,
Barem, Butane, Richard Devine, and many more.
 
JP has for the last few years also been one half of
the Klikmusik project with fellow Minneapolis techno
afficionado Mike G.  Their two man extended
cooperative dj+laptop+fx sets have captivated
listeners throughout the Midwest while pushing the
boundaries of a traditional DJ set to exciting new
levels.
 
Currently, JP teaches software music production at
Minneapolis' Institute of Production and Recording,
and he directs the websites www.microphono.com,
www.vitalvinyl.com, and www.secrettechno.com.

http://www.klikmusik.com/artists/index.html

http://www.myspace.com/microhouseminneapolis

More DJ sets:

Subject: [sfraves] Happy 5th of July/ My 4th Review

So I hope y'all had a Groovy 4th & sooooooooo sooo sooo sorry I couldn't
make it Mighty... i mean... school is back in session for me & I kinda
gotta cut back on some off the yummy.. but not all :)  Biggups to EB &
everyone who went!!  Sounded fuckin' Dope :)  YAAAY

So on the 4th,i was kinda confuzed on what to do 'cause it was either
Happy Hardcore @ Blakes or like see my Homies Warner Drive perform @
Rockit Room in the Richmond... I was 80% set on goin' to the City, but
last minute decided on Blakes... so my Lil Homie Rauol came along & we
kicked it...

OK.. so sets went like this... Gozingzzingzzibah played a strait scarry
ass mondo wicked hardcore set that oooh YUM!! Ummmm... Joshua & DJ OMB
strait spun this yummy Jungle set which was Groovy & all & I dmao during
this set, but i dunno, their track selection kinda blew 'cause they played
alota tunes w/ these hella long ass instrmental break downs & i dunno...
after the like 7th time that happen, it was like wtf... i mean... & that
OMD DJ girlie.. she was hella bad ass & stuff, but kinda kept wrecking &
yada yada yada...

after taht, No Left turn spun this yummy HHC set w/ alota his own OG
tracks & WOW!!!  Reese got on next & switched it up w/ the Jungle & the
HHC, so that was like WOW!!  Again... i danced harder to this set 'cause
of the Jungle!  CrackerJack was up last & strait played thius Anthem
Cheese filled HHC set... I swear... i never heard sooo many 80s SLow Jams
& Power  Ballads done HHC style!!  LoL.. it was fun!!  The whole night i
pretty danced & danced more..

So like there was a good 50-60 people that showed up & grooved!!  Saw
alota old Homies & made friends w/ the newbies i met.. LOL.. OK.. like i
have not seen that many Candy kids @ Blakes since Ascension was a monthly
& it went to 6 in the morning in the Basement :P  But it was Cute!!!  I
mean... like everyone there brought this Awesome vibe w/ them & the music
& dancing just made it yummy... there were oooh... i need to explain
somehting....

So i kinda came up w/ this like term for like well.. so I call these
certain bread of like Candy kid Girlies.. i call them the Brenda Raver
Girls 'cause like they're like the ummm... glammed out, retro candy kids 
ya konw, like kinda costume lookin' tryin to hard to be over dressed 
candy kids chicas dealie...

so there were like groups of Brenda Raver Girl Candy Kids there last
night... then this huge group of hippy raver stoner boy candy kids were
there too... it was fun.. Rauol had a good time & said it was the most fun
he's had in a long time!!! :)  YAAAY!@!!

After Transmision was over @ Blakes, we kicked it for a bit then like
wandered the streets of Berkeley waiting for BART to open!  We met these 2
Awesome drunk Girls waiting for BART to open too, so since we were all
headed the same direction... we just all kicked it.. it was fun!!! :) 
Their names are Janessa & Britney!!  They just came from an impromtu 4th
of July HOuse party by Blakes... LoL.. I've never laughed that hard in
sooo long!!  So Fun!!  Oooh.. & fun time takin' pictures soon whick I'll
have all updated soon!!!  OK.. Heeeeeeeeello 2Day.. there's more to my
after the party, waiting for bart to open adventure than that.. but I
can't talk about it right now.. LOLOLOLMAO~~~~@@@@@@!!!!!

OK.. that's is for now!!  Love U all!  I'll be seein' alota y'all on Sat
night/ day/ something.. so YAAAAY!!!
-- 
Take Care <3
Peace=->Jus' Me =-> O§bY {8O)

  Flyer: http://www.kittyblunts.com/caligrown/graphics/flyer_back_v2.jpg

Saturday, July 7th 2007 (7.7.7) San Francisco, 9:30 PM - 6:00 AM:

CaliGrown Events proudly presents BACK ON TRACK, featuring world-class acts from Belgium, Chicago, Las Vegas, and San Francisco. Party all night while grooving to:

CONGA SQUAD aka C-MOS (Holographic Music, Belgium)
Known to many as Conga Squad, Olivier Abbeloos also produces under names such as C-Mos, Goldbumpers, Dynetic, Bio-nic, Inferno, Quadrophonia, T99, and Kretek. Over the past 15 years, this Disco House master has developed a signature sound that is like no other in House music. His style of pumpin, steppy, driving Disco House has made Olivier a huge success with many of the most influential DJ's from around the world. Not only a successful music producer, Mr. Abbeloos is also a successful DJ with over 18 years of experience.
Olivier Abbeloos performs all over the world, and has several residencies in his home country of Belgium including La Rocca. Abbeloos is also the founder & primary artist of legendary House labels Holographic Music & E.P.O.S, and has released over fifty (50) tracks to date! DO NOT UNDER ANY CIRCUMSTANCES MISS CONGA SQUAD!
MORE INFO: WWW.HOLOGRAPHICMUSIC.COM
http://www.myspace.com/abbeloosolivier

HIGH CALIBER: DJ BRYAN JONES & MIKE GILLENWATER (Control Recordings, Chicago)
Wrapping up his international Step Back 2007 Tour, DJ Bryan Jones joins Mike Gillenwater as High Caliber, originally formed in late 2002. Both artists hail from Chicago where theyve independently established themselves as icons in the Funky House scene. Five years and nearly 20 chart-busting EPs later, High Caliber is releasing their biggest project to date: Old School Sessions, a four-part all-digital mix series that was too long to condense into one album. Catch tracks from this new groundbreaking series along with other HC classics for a floor-rocking experience San Francisco will surely not forget!
MORE INFO: WWW.MYSPACE.COM/HIGHCALIBERCHICAGO

JENO (BACK2BACK,SF)
A name that needs no introduction in SF House Music, Jeno has been organizing legendary underground parties and rocking dance floors around the world since the mid-eighties. As one of the Wicked DJs, Jeno helped define an eclectic and soulful musical style that was the original sound of San Francisco.
MORE INFO: WWW.DJJENO.COM
http://www.myspace.com/jeno

ERIC SPIRE (Silver Pearl Records / Sony Records / QUEST , Bay Area & Las Vegas)
The owner & founder of Silver Pearl records, world-famous DJ, and founding father of Quest; Eric Spire has spent the past 7 years in the studio producing major label acts, television themes, movie soundtracks, video game sound bytes, and quite of bit of Dance Music. Missing the excitement of the crowd, Eric is returning to the decks to grace his fans with another masterful & soul-moving set that they have been craving since 2000!
MORE INFO: WWW.SILVERPEARL.COM
http://www.myspace.com/silverprl1

WITH SPECIAL GUESTS:

THE MARIO BROS. - TAG SET (OtherWorld / Tech Funk Alliance / Midnight Sons / Essential Breaks West, SF)
What can we say about these guys? They're fucking awesome! The Mario Bros. is made up of one part "daniella downs", one part "Marc(O)" and a whole lot of pimp juice. They are best served straight up in a highball glass...
http://www.myspace.com/the_mario_bros
http://www.themidnightsons.com

THE FINGERMONSTERS - LIVE PA (SHAZBOT, ORIGAMI, ANDREW PHELAN, and CUBIK , SF)
The Fingermonsters create maximal floor-magnet tracks with tongue firmly in cheek and hands firmly on knobs. Theyve been tearing San Francisco and the Bay Area a new one with a 4-person live laptop/drum machine PA assault that is not to be missed!

DJ HEADCASE - LIVE PA - CD RELEASE PARTY (CaliGrown , SF)

  with SPACE COWBOY DJS:
AARON JAE (Space Cowboys/XM/Evil Breaks)
KAPTN KIRK (Space Cowboys/Panda Rejects)
EVINRUDE (Space Cowboys/NetAmp)
   
  JAYSON KINCAID (Grooves-in-the-Park / Culture / Om Records , SF)
http://www.myspace.com/jaysonkincaid

DEAN KROH (Seedless Music, Liquid Graf-X-209)

CHILL HOURS HOSTED BY: THE AMBIENT MAFIA (www.ambientmafia.com)
MO CORLEONE (Want It/:am)
SQUELCHY (The Extra Credit/:am)
OLDE NASTY (Butterzone/:am)

Additional Attractions:

General Info:

San Francisco, CA

  DRESS CODE STRICTLY NOT ENFORCED!

More Info:
www.myspace.com/caligrownevents
www.caligrownevents.com

WTF are CaliGrown Events?

Were a spin-off of a former Central Valley UG rave crew called Elysium from the
late 90s - early 00s. Elysium produced several events in the Central Valley, and
some in the Bay Area including a residence at the now infamous Hotel Ibiza in
2001. We produce events out of love for the music and the vibe its followers carry.

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: 'Reasons Unknown', by Tim Daly 

Reasons Unknown

When Tony met Georgie
He saw blood in his eye
And knew in that instant
That Iraq had to die
So the challenge was made!
The gauntlet was thrown!
The fighting was started
For reasons unknown

They went through the motions
Like dung beetles of war
They were deaf to the people
And blind to the law
What harvest was reaped?
What seeds had been sown?
What faith was abandoned?
For reasons unknown

So they played with their soldiers
As boys often will
Turned lovers to fighters
And forced them to kill
What arrogance this!
Egos overblown!
To have placed themselves high
For reasons unknown.

Written by Tim Daly
(108 words):
Friday 6^th July 2007

I would like to extend my greatest appreciation to those that turned out last night; hope you like what we're about and will return to our
next event.

I also have to throw some serious props down to Eyezmind, Jazette, Terry & the  the Viberation Crew, along with KNOW:AUDIO, David @ Radiant Atmosphere, just Osby, Josh, Aubrey, GOGO pro, and  the rest of the DJ's & staff that went above & beyond the call of duty in name of the party. 

An extra token of gratitude as well to Olivier Abbeloos for accepting our invitation to visit San Francisco, not to mention flying half-way across world to play AND producing a special track just for the party! Extra thanks as well to High Caliber for showing up and reppin' some jacked-up, old skool Chicago Funky House, and Eric Spire for the "surprise offer" when he heard about the party.

EVERY set rocked, and thank you again to those of you that showed up.

Sincerely,

chuck_G
CaliGrown Events (*since 7.7.7)

Subject: [sfraves]  WR: My BBQ, Funky Groovy, Donut Chocolate Milk Sat/Sun

So like Saturday started out goin' to a house warming BBQ shindig.. Groovy
house, oooh... food so good, drink here & there, & what's funny is that i
used to work like 2 block away from where they live... it was good seein'
alota Familia chillin'!  Good seein' people i ain't seen in a while...
Congrats again BTE :)  Oooooooh.. the funny thing about the new pad is
that it's next door to a preschool & I just wanted to hop over the fence &
play in their lil black top park :)

OK... there was alota yummy events in SOMA alone on Sat night... but i
kinda forgot about all them when i got to Fat City!  I serioulsy kept
reminding myself to say hi to the Jungle & Techno & Anu & End up... but i
just totally forgot man... soorry Techno & Jungle :(  But yeah... it was a
fun night @ Fat City!!  Seeing alota Familia there & old skool faces who
ain't been out in forever was So Yummy!!!

Aaaaaall the DJs totally tore it up!  I mean... I danced alot!!  Ummm... I
remember when Congo Mongo started spinning, his like 2nd, 3rd song was
this tune that had samples of this Disco song from the 70s/ early 80s
called "Dancing In My Sleep" like it had alota the music all chopped up &
made house & melodic... it was Dope! :)  I remember Eric Spire's set was
this Yummy kinda Disco-ie-ish, sometimes kinda dark & triballie House & it
was Ill!!  I remember like dancing to exuastion to his set 'cause i was
sooo tired already kinda but his beats were sooo damn yummy!!  Jeno spun
like this Dope Deep house set then like got all crazy from the middle to
end & I swore, he even dropped this electro ch00nz in his set, & I tried
to call him out on it, but he said he didn't & it w3as all house!  Grrr..
Hello 2day!  OK... all the music in the main room was good, & all the DJs
tore it up... but those are the specifics I can recall atm :)

In the side room... like ok ... from what i remember... Mario Brothers
tore it up!! I danced for a while in that room when they wre on 'cause it
was just woooo!!  Ooooh yeah... Aaron Jae started out the night in that
room & fucki'n brought it so hard w/ his yummy!!!  OK.. Finger Monsters
fuck shit up w/ their techno, electro, breaks, mashie, yummy live set!!! 
The Ambient Hip Hop after from the Mafia really was Dope too!!!  I mean...
i usual don't remember to sit when well... like lately anyway when i 'm @
a party, i forget to sit & I'm always like dancing or standing & talking..
but it was nice to sit for the Mafia playing just nice Chill tunes!

OK... I have to say... Hello 2day... it was soooooo fuckin' Awesome
meeting Eric Spire.. you fucker.. LoL :P  Like alota the night was spent
like kickin' it w/ ERic & talkin' about eeeeeeeeeeeeeverything!! 
Seriously man... I got Bigt Love for you Homie!!!  It was sooo fuckin'
Dope like fuck.. Hello 2Day.. just strait kickin' it!!  His fiance Tiffany
was really fuckin' Sweet Too!! :)  YAAAAAAY!!  Love U Guys lots!!

Oh yeah.. so i finally got to officially like officially meet fuckin'
Chuck G!!  OK... he's not a Chinese person like i thought he was when i
met him @ Tonal... which kinda led to the fact that i went up to all the
Asain guys @ Tonal & why none of them were him... 'cause he's not Asain! 
Hello 2Day! But it was just Dope meeting him, hangin' out, & just
YAAAAAAAAY!!! LOLOLMAO.. ok.. hyper.. kinda late right now to post, but
I'm hella stuck on weekend hours right now...

It was fun hangin' w/ everyone who was there all night long!  Ranger :P 
But yeah.. morning came, helped out, then waited in Chuck's car for
another car to come which was fine 'cause I hella needed to kill time b4
BART opened.. LOL.. it was hella fun man 'cause the sleep dep & mondo
hella tired from dancing caught up to me @ that moment that morning & I
just started getting silly fuckin' hyper & laughing sooo much!!

So they all left, we left the club, i walked down Harrison to like just
take the long way & decided that a donut & chocolate milk @ All Star would
totally hit the spot & it sooooo Did!!!  YUM!!!  I hella had to go pee & @
Allstar, you need a key to use the bathroom outside & the bathroom lock
was sooo busted & couldn't get in.. oh well!  But i made it home by 10AM
like i usually do after my gypsy raver adventures.. but there was really
no adventure that Sunday Morn...

Ooooooooooooh... i forgot to mention... so like there was a VIP Lounge in
the loft thingie @ the club & YUM!!  There were food platers & I pigged
out on Swiss Cheese like the whole night.. infact...i stole all the Swiss
Cheese for myself :)  Well.. & Roni wanted some too :)  But yeah... lol...
so Dope!!!

Thanks Chuckie for a Dope fuckin' time man!!!  {{{HHC HUGZ}}} :)

Oooooooh... OK.. i'll be sure to get the pictures fixed soon... so many of
y'all were there & it was sooo Fun just bein' w/ y'all!!  Peter :)  OK..
getting way to like i shouhld be tryin' to get back on normal weekday
sleep hours!!!  Love U SFR!!  Love U Chuck & Eric!!  WE serioulsy gotta
kick it w/ you in Vegas man!!! :)

Take Care <3

Subject: [sfraves] Almost there....

And now for something completely different....

Not a Star Wars post, sorry.

I'm glad I didn't take the bet that Barry Bonds was gonna break Aaron's
home run record before the All-Star break, but man, oh, man, did he come
close.

751, with only 4 more to go.

So what if he's not a nice person, neither was John Lennon.

Let's show him the love that he's earned.

It's a damn shame, and bullshit, that he's being rail-roaded for using
performance enhancing drugs, as if half the country isn't loaded up on
prescriptions of one kind or another to enhance their performance or
otherwise improve their lives.

I would give Lance Armstrong's left testicle to end this nonsense and
completely ban all drug testing in every major league sport.

It's be cool to see someone run a 100 meter dash in 5 seconds, jump 50+
feet and run a 3 minute mile.

I'm sure a lot of people would pay mucho dinero to see that, too.


---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

in Vegas, except when there are big conventions like G2E and you 
can get in when they have open bars :-)

Olympic Gardens, hehe, yeah that place is great in the early 
afternoon, no cover.

Paula and I will be there 1st week of August, you may find us 
at:

Pure (Caesars)
Baby's (Hard Rock)
Scores & Sapphire (Boobies :-)
Ghostbar (Palms)
I also hear Palms has a really cool nighttime pool party.

Drai's was cool but it's afterhours only, not sure what it's 
like since Barbary Coast became Bill's.

We'll probably be having dinner at the Wynn, only been to their 
buffet so far. The rest of time we'll be eating on the super 
cheap.

Vegas...wheeeee!!!

-terry

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Solar variations not behind global warming: study

------=_Part_13227_22691994.1184190400538
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

By Ben Hirschler

LONDON (Reuters) - The sun's changing energy levels are not to blame for
recent global warming and, if anything, solar variations over the past 20
years should have had a cooling effect, scientists said on Wednesday.

Their findings add to a growing body of evidence that human activity, not
natural causes, lies behind rising average world temperatures, which are
expected to reach their second highest level this year since records began
in the 1860s.

There is little doubt that solar variability has influenced the Earth's
climate in the past and may well have been a factor in the first half of the
last century, but British and Swiss researchers said it could not explain
recent warming.

"Over the past 20 years, all the trends in the sun that could have had an
influence on Earth's climate have been in the opposite direction to that
required to explain the observed rise in global mean temperatures," they
wrote in the Proceedings of the Royal Society....
Complete article here:
http://www.reuters.com/article/scienceNews/idUSL101501320070710

------=_Part_13227_22691994.1184190400538--

was dope, sound was nice, and everyone I met that had

bunch of different technologies being sync''d and

welcome.

Subject: [sfraves] this saturday - it's the end of the world... (BSP)

THIS Saturday!!
WHAT: Apocalypse!
WHAT: Fandango's End-of-the-World Party
WHERE: The Pr0n Palace, 415 Jessie St., San Francisco
WHEN: Saturday, July 14, 2007, 9pm-?
WHO: The Friends, and Friends-of-Friends, of Fandango.
COST: $10 to $20, sliding scale.
WHY: Fundraiser for Fandango Village infrastructure at Burning
Man (Bars, Trucks, Booze, Trash, Furnishings, Booze, Lumber,
Trash)

How is the World going to End? Will it be the
seemingly-inevitable Zombie apocalypse? Will we all fight each
other to the death over a few precious drops of gasoline? Will
the world snuff it in a Biblical plague of locusts and
Hellfire? Will the toxic sludge of our corporate paymasters
give rise to a new brand of avenger? Or will we all have to
sprout gills after the ice caps melt, leaving us with nothing
but a horrible, watery-world?

We don't know, but we hope you'll help us figure it out at
Apocalypse!, Fandango's 2007 Fundraiser. Two different dance
floors will feature Fandango's Apocalypse DJs. You have limited
time, so make good use of it on the dancefloor.
______________________

Here's the Apocalyptic DJ Line-Up:

Barroom Breakdown:
TSAE Labs- Live Set (Toddberticus Labs, Motown)
DJ Steve.J (Motown, Fandango)
DJ Island Girl (Fandango)
Skye (Chill Syndicate, Ambient Mafia, Stargaze)
The Captain (Chill Syndicate, Ambient Mafia, Snorgaze)
Shane (FnF, Ambient Mafia)

Dungeon of Doom:
Actual Rafiq (the dRow, Ambient Mafia)
Olde Nasty (Butterzone, Ambient Mafia)
Redstickman (FnF, Ambient Mafia)
Malderor (Fandango)
Mo Corleone (Want It, Ambient Mafia)
Powerlounger (Fandango, Qool)

Visuals by: Junktronix

http://www.fandango.net/index.php/site/comments/fundraiser_flyer_mk_3/

We hope to see you there!

"Is the world ending because of God? The Devil? Or is it
something YOU did?"

-----------------------------------------------------
 www.redstickman.com

 new downtempo mix online, you should check it out.
-----------------------------------------------------

Subject: Re: [sfraves] a special thanks from CaliGrown Events

Osby, Eric, Marco, other listees, etc,  et al, etc.

You all have pretty much said it.  Fun party, great music, and100% super nice people.  Great to meet Eric and Tiffany from Vegas!

I attended with my friend Mark who immediately proceeded to start ordering extremely strong drinks for me. But I avoided the Frenet.

We heard some great music...I especially enjoyed High Caliber and the Mario bros.  I also liked the Fingermonsters!   Although I understand they were missing one finger or something.  Interesting to watch them work it live!  It was more entertaining than I expected having seen other "laptop" bands previosuly.

At some point the bar closed and Mark and I were too inebriated to remain at the party so it was time to go.  I got extremely drunk on cheap vodka and I was feeeling *NASTY* for a couple of days afterrward.  Hoo boy.  The mind is willing but the liver ain't...

Osby --  :P

That is all.

Peter


----- Original Message ----
From: Eric Spire <ericspire@yahoo.com>
To: SFR <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Wednesday, July 11, 2007 6:57:22 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] a special thanks from CaliGrown Events


You guys did a great job with all the logistics. Setup
was dope, sound was nice, and everyone I met that had
anything to do with BACK ON TRACK was totally fuckin
cool. I hope it is a nice building block for you guys.

It was rad meeting all kinds of old SFRAVERS... Dug
the LIVE sets in the back room. I was wondering how
they were going to be set up, and it was cool to see a
bunch of different technologies being sync''d and
lynk'd the way they were. Said hi to everyone there
while they were playing, but I doubt they had the time
to realize I was introducing myself.... and Marco
never bought me a beer ( or two for that matter....)
Terry's setup has "evolved" since I lasty saw it, so
that was great to see too... and of course meeting the
infamous Osby was perfect. Mr. Stickman ;) .... and
actually quite a few more...

My friends from Vegas had a great time kickin it with
everyone upstairs. I was stoked to have some people
drive from Tahoe and Monterey to say hello and support
the show...

We just basically had a good time and felt very
welcome.

Thanks Chuck.

E

Subject: [sfraves] Wicked analog studio gear for sale

Sorry I wouldn't normally repost but this looks kinda big. I 
recognize some of the components but that's about it. That 
Powermac 7100 is worth nothing, I still have 1 in my garage 
collecting dust.

Anyways....

Garth's Analogue Studio Gear For Sale
Body: 	Want to own a piece of San Francisco DJ history?

After much soul-searching I've decided to let go of my analogue 
studio setup.

This is the same gear I produced all of the Wicked and Grayhound 
singles on.

I'm looking for a serious buyer/collector. Ideally I'd like to 
sell it in one go as a working studio.

Here's a list of the gear for sale...

ROLAND CHORUS ECHO RE 501 (ANALOGUE TAPE DELAY/ECHO/REVERB)
ROLAND 303 (ANALOGUE ACID BASS SYNTH MODULE)
ROLAND R8 (ANALOGUE RHYTHM COMPOSER W/SOUND CARDS)
2 X ENSONIQ DP2S (PARALLEL EFFECTS PROCESSOR)
2 X BEHRINGER COMPOSERS (DYNAMICS PROCESSOR)
EMU E64 (DIGITAL SAMPLER W/FULLY EXPANDED MEMORY)
NOVATION DRUM STATION (ANALOGUE 909 & 808 SYNTH RACK)
EMU CLASSIC KEYS (ANALOGUE SYNTH RACK)
SOUNDCRAFT GHOST (24 CHANNEL/8 BUS ANALOGUE MIXING CONSOLE)
DESIGNER MIXER & KEYBOAD STAND (CUSTOM BUILT IN STEEL)
POWERMAC 7100 (DESKTOP COMPUTER W/SOUNDCARD)
* ALL MANUALS/WIRES & LEADS INCLUDED

Everything is in good working condition. The studio has always 
been smoke-free and all the gear looks like new except for the 
Roland bits which are vintage. They work wonderfully but look 
like they've seen some action in the 30 years they've been in 
service (and they ain't lying).

$15,000 OBO is the asking price for everything. Sold as-is. No 
time wasters please.

Want this? Go find him on MySpace here: 
http://www.myspace.com/garthgrayhound

------------------------------------------
terry estioko     | terry@hyperreal.org
SFRaves moderator | http://www.sfraves.org

Hehe...  I love Garth, but this sale, it is to laugh.

Here's a breakdown of the most this gear is worth:

ROLAND CHORUS ECHO RE 501       $4-500
ROLAND 303                                               $1000
ROLAND R8                                                 $50-100
2 X ENSONIQ DP2S                                 $50-100 x 2
2 X BEHRINGER COMPOSERS            $40 x 2
EMU E64                                                         $300 (but tough to find a buyer these days)
NOVATION DRUM STATION                     $150-200
EMU CLASSIC KEYS                                    $50-100
SOUNDCRAFT GHOST                                 $1000
DESIGNER MIXER & KEYBOAD STAND $200?
POWERMAC 7100                                            $50
Cables 'n' junk                                                        $50

Which, at its most blown-out and crazy, comes to $3780, which is still far more than he'll ever fetch for this.

Poor guy, he's better off keeping the best bits, selling off all the junk and getting a new laptop and audio interface to work with.  He's gonna miss that space echo and 303.
-GC

Subject: Re: [sfraves] what ringing?

So... I've wondered this for some time....

I have used "Ear Candles" on occasion to clean my
ears. I can never tell if there is a difference in
hearing afterward. Sometimes there is yellowy wax at
the candle base when I have finished burning the
candle.

So here's the question... Is the wax a bi-product of
the candle, or is it really drawn-out ear wax?

I honestly think it is wax from the candle itself...
But am not convinced enough that I haven't ruled out
there use. I thought of turning it over to
Myth-Busters.

Anyone know?

E
