Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 45189 invoked from network); 13 Jul 2007 00:02:38 -0000
X-ClientAddr: 127.0.0.1
Date: Thu, 12 Jul 2007 17:02:28 -0700
To: "Eric Spire" <ericspire@yahoo.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.org
From: "Nathan Seven" <n7@nathanseven.com>
Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed; delsp=yes; charset=iso-8859-15
MIME-Version: 1.0
References: <704647.23893.qm@web36803.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Message-ID: <op.tvdmeeb2d6u6mu@incitatus.local>
In-Reply-To: <704647.23893.qm@web36803.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
User-Agent: Opera Mail/9.21 (MacPPC)
X-FiveAngle-MailScanner-Information: Please contact FiveAngle for more information
X-FiveAngle-MailScanner: Found to be clean
X-MailScanner-From: n7@nathanseven.com
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] what ringing?

Think about it for just a sec-

The claim is that the candle creates a vacuum, but unless you've got a  
punctured eardrum your ear is sealed.
So without any air movement nothing can be drawn out, which is what would  
happen if you make a tight seal- the candle burning only in the air it can  
pull around the top.
If you *don't make a tight seal, then air will get sucked in from around  
the base of it.
In other words, they're entirely full of shit.
But take a pic next time you use one!

-- 
NUNQUAM NON PARATUS - Jupiter accepts your offer...
AIM: IMFDUP

> Think about it for just a sec-
> 
> The claim is that the candle creates a vacuum, but
> unless you've got a  
> punctured eardrum your ear is sealed.
> So without any air movement nothing can be drawn
> out, which is what would  
> happen if you make a tight seal- the candle burning
> only in the air it can  
> pull around the top.
> If you *don't make a tight seal, then air will get
> sucked in from around  
> the base of it.
> In other words, they're entirely full of shit.
> But take a pic next time you use one!

Subject: Re: [sfraves] what ringing?

Stephen Colbert, and more 2 the point, Mr. Wizard might have a thing 2 
say about that:

http://www.ifilm.com/video/2867766/show/17677

On another note, though still health related, George C. Scott's "The 
Hospital" is on TCM @ 8pm tmw night.

Set yr DVR.

http://www.tcmdb.com/title/title.jsp?stid=17589

When the director and writer of "The Hospital" got together they asked 
themselves:

'what is the most improbable thing we can put in this pic, that no one 
would *ever* believe?!?'

and their answer was,

'nobody will ever believe that someone was allowed to die in an American 
hospital because they couldn't pay for their treatment.'

So they put it in, and in the course of a generation, it's become a 
daily reality, in all 50 States.

How cool is that?

God Bless America.

All others, see the cashier on your way out.

Thank you.

On a personal note, I first saw this movie in my Grandparents kitchen in 
Slovenia, (the country, that, like Cuba today, is right about on par 
with where the USA USA USA is on the the global healthcare rankings, the 
high 30s, how pathetic is that?), on a crappy 13" b&W TV.

For some reason the very last scene of dude on a gurney while the world 
passed him by has left an indelible, lifetime, impression.

Not bad for a "B" from the early 1970s.

Who knew?

..

Here's the deets:

Temple Nightclub & Compression SF Present


*Drum & Bassment*



The first installment of many to come at a premiere new night club in the
SOMA.
For those who have not experienced Temple Nightclub, you're in for a very
special treat featuring the local talent of the Compression Crew!
Come out and support a new concept of how the way Drum & Bass should be
with your friends from Temple Nightclub and Club Compression SF. This is a
FREE EVENT so try to come out early, grab a drink, and shake that ass till
4am! Doors open up at 10pm Located in the Catacombs this will NOT
dissapoint!



Catacombs

(n) An underground network of passages tunnels & chambers.

Our Catacombs resemble that of an ancient underground ritual chamber
evoking thoughts of civilizations past. With sculptors of stone, carvings
of wood and cave like pillars and ceilings throughout the room you will
feel like youve been transported back in time. Other features represent
the future of sound and technology with our state of the art digital DJ
Studio booth and an all Martin Audio Sound system that makes the ground
shake. Walls of light are used as partitions to divide the room to
accommodate multiple floor plans depending on the needs of the night. Each
partition if fitted with LED lighting and different images that reflect a
wide array of ancient symbolism. Two bars and multiple couch seating areas
surround the dance floor and provide many options for conversation,
intimate moments and relaxation. Antiquities mounted in the walls seem to
be suspended in air as the darkness envelopes. The Catacombs are sure to
make an impact and intrigue all who venture into it.

Capacity - 300
2 Full Service Bars
Multiple Couch areas can be arranged to accommodate any floor plan
Large Dance Floor
DJ Booth - 2 Technic 1200 turntables, 2 Pioneer CDJ 1000 CD turntables,
Allen & Heath Xone 92 Mixer
Sound System - Martin Audio 14 speaker system
2 - 50" Plasma TV's available for custom visuals
Video/Movie Screen available upon request
Multiple partitions can be arranged to accommodate any floor plan and can
display any logo/brand

Compression Crew


2 Cents



Sharp



Ivry (TBC)




Colonel MC


Temple Nightclub SF
55 Natoma St/ 540 Howard
10pm- 4am

Subject: [sfraves] Google SMS / text messaging

------=_Part_41553_7026960.1184347088032
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

I've been using this for awhile to look up local restaurant listing.  I
finally tried searching it on google, and it's crazy how much stuff you can
do by just texting Google.  Just a little FYI for those of you who weren't
aware of this kick ass technology.

http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/

Here's a list of the things you can search:


Local <http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#> sushi
94040<http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#>
Weather <http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#> weather
boston<http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#>
Glossary <http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#> define
zenith<http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#>
Sports <http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#>* score red
sox<http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#>
Movies <http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#> movies
94110<http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#>
Stocks <http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#> stock
tgt<http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#>  Zip
Codes <http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#> zip code
72202<http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#>
Directions <http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#> directions
pasadena ca to 94043 <http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#>
Maps<http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#> map
5th avenue new york <http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#>
Flights<http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#>
** flight aa 2111 <http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#>  Area
Codes <http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#> area code
650<http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#>
Products <http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#> price ipod player
40gb <http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#>
Q&A<http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#> abraham
lincoln birthday <http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#>

in french <http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#>  Web

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Cow Hollow Muggings on the Rise

>From a friend:

Hello All-

For those that don't know Matt and I were mugged at gun point Monday night 
at 10:30 in front of our house.  We are OK and Jake was inside with the baby 
sitter, thank goodness, but we wanted to share our story so our friends and 
neighbors could also be aware that this could happen at any time to any of 
us and to be alert, especially at night.

Here are the details of what happened to us:

As we rounded the corner of Octavia from Greenwich and approached the front 
of our house, two men wearing skeleton masks, black hooded sweatshirts, and 
carrying what looked like a semi-automatic weapon (we don't know guns well 
but it had a clip), approached us and told us to give them our valuables.  
We were caught a little off-guard, not expecting something like this to 
happen, and sort of hesitated.  They started yelling that they would shoot 
us in the face and I handed over my purse.  Matt reached for his wallet and 
they knocked his hand away and went through his pockets and took his wallet. 
  They finally took off down Greenwich St, at which point we called the 
police.  It all happened so fast and we honestly never saw it coming until 
the gun was in our faces.  Thank God that we were not hurt and Jake was not 
with us but this could have been any one of us and it could have been worse. 
  The next day there was a report of a 65 yr old man that was shot in the 
900 block of Filbert (a few blocks away) in a botched burglary about 30 
minutes after we were held up.  He is still in the hospital.

We want to inform our friends and neighbors of this incident and let them 
know that we should all be careful.  We believe they were watching from a 
hidden spot and picked us out as targets.  We weren't paying particular 
attention as we were walking and had our guard down.  We also believe they 
most likely had a get away car around the corner because they disappeared 
quickly.  We were told that gangs 'work' this area as it's considered 
affluent and it's assumed that most people are carrying some money with 
them. Since we've started sharing our story with others we've heard back 
other accounts of recent muggings, hold ups, and even an attempted 
kidnapping of a woman that happened in broad daylight on Union and Lyon 
Streets.  Attached is even another account of a recent hold up sent to us by 
a friend.

Please be careful out there and remember that even though we all live in 
relatively safe neighborhoods, we are not immune to the perils of living in 
a big city!!


SFR: Ranger
San Francisco
plurranger@hotmail.com
Who knows where the night leads
It's dark and no one can see - Ranger

"I hate to advocate drugs, alcohol, violence or insanity to anyone, but it 
worked for me." -Hunter S. Thompson

Subject: [sfraves] Hyphy jungle?

Where have the twain met in the bay area?

I mean, you hear hyphy everywhere. You can go to a bar in a suburban
neighborhood and hear the thizzle dance. And I've been seeing the
hyphy kids at plurtard parties for years. I remember a skinny white
kid at the dungeon showing me the 'cupertino thizz' handshake and
thoroughly filthifying my hands in the process... and the young hoods
selling shitty ecstasy have been patrolling the same subscene for as
long as I can remember.

But how about musically? I've heard of a couple club nights, and heard
some hyphy stuff being dropped with ragga and jungle at a spot called
The Hatch... but is there any serious hyphy-jungle hybrid being
germinated in some dark corner of Oakland? Maybe some crossover MCs?

----- Original Message ----
From: Ben Haus <benhaus@gmail.com>

Subject: [sfraves] Google SMS / text messaging


I've been using this for awhile to look up local restaurant listing.  I
finally tried searching it on google, and it's crazy how much stuff you can
do by just texting Google.  Just a little FYI for those of you who weren't
aware of this kick ass technology.

http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/

Here's a list of the things you can search:


Local <http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#> sushi
94040<http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#>
Weather <http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#> weather
boston<http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#>
Glossary <http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#> define
zenith<http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#>
Sports <http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#>* score red
sox<http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#>
Movies <http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#> movies
94110<http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#>
Stocks <http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#> stock
tgt<http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#>  Zip
Codes <http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#> zip code
72202<http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#>
Directions <http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#> directions
pasadena ca to 94043 <http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#>
Maps<http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#> map
5th avenue new york <http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#>
Flights<http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#>
** flight aa 2111 <http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#>  Area
Codes <http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#> area code
650<http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#>
Products <http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#> price ipod player
40gb <http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#>

lincoln birthday <http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#>

Translation <http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#> translate hello
in french <http://www.google.com/intl/en_us/mobile/sms/#>  Web

Ranger - wrote:
>>>From a friend:
>
> Hello All-
>
> For those that don't know Matt and I were mugged at gun point Monday night
> at 10:30 in front of our house.  We are OK and Jake was inside with the
> baby
> sitter, thank goodness, but we wanted to share our story so our friends
> and
> neighbors could also be aware that this could happen at any time to any of
> us and to be alert, especially at night.
>
> Here are the details of what happened to us:
>
> As we rounded the corner of Octavia from Greenwich and approached the
> front
> of our house, two men wearing skeleton masks, black hooded sweatshirts,
> and
> carrying what looked like a semi-automatic weapon (we don't know guns well
> but it had a clip), approached us and told us to give them our valuables.
> We were caught a little off-guard, not expecting something like this to
> happen, and sort of hesitated.  They started yelling that they would shoot
> us in the face and I handed over my purse.  Matt reached for his wallet
> and
> they knocked his hand away and went through his pockets and took his
> wallet.
>   They finally took off down Greenwich St, at which point we called the
> police.  It all happened so fast and we honestly never saw it coming until
> the gun was in our faces.  Thank God that we were not hurt and Jake was
> not
> with us but this could have been any one of us and it could have been
> worse.
>   The next day there was a report of a 65 yr old man that was shot in the
> 900 block of Filbert (a few blocks away) in a botched burglary about 30
> minutes after we were held up.  He is still in the hospital.
>
> We want to inform our friends and neighbors of this incident and let them
> know that we should all be careful.  We believe they were watching from a
> hidden spot and picked us out as targets.  We weren't paying particular
> attention as we were walking and had our guard down.  We also believe they
> most likely had a get away car around the corner because they disappeared
> quickly.  We were told that gangs 'work' this area as it's considered
> affluent and it's assumed that most people are carrying some money with
> them. Since we've started sharing our story with others we've heard back
> other accounts of recent muggings, hold ups, and even an attempted
> kidnapping of a woman that happened in broad daylight on Union and Lyon
> Streets.  Attached is even another account of a recent hold up sent to us
> by
> a friend.
>
> Please be careful out there and remember that even though we all live in
> relatively safe neighborhoods, we are not immune to the perils of living
> in
> a big city!!
>
>

Subject: [sfraves] [BSP] Sat 7.14:: 5 Hr DJ Set by Kontakt :: Fri 7.27 Adjunct-Audio Night w/ Apendics.Shuffle at Anu

Both Anu and the Retox Lounge are quickly becoming fast favorites for
intimate, affordable techno get togethers. Check out these events
Saturday at the Retox Lounge and Friday, July 27 at Anu:


SAT 7/14 :: Kontakt 5 Hour MNML Techno DJ Set:: No Cover
Saturday, July 14, 2007
9:00 PM to 2:00 AM
Retox Lounge
620 20th St X 3rd Street in S.F.
More Info: www.freqbox.net

BABD/Filter resident Kontakt will take us on a five hour psychotropic
minimal techno tour this Saturday at the Retox Lounge's monthly Low
End party.

About Kontakt:

Kontakt is BABD's co-founder and resident DJ, dedicated to bringing a
deeper, more abstrakt sound to the Bay Area's rediscovered techno
scene. In the past year alone, he has launched seven one-off events,
two weeklies (Fukwerk Friday + Low End Saturdays) and one monthly
(FilterSF at Fat City).

He has played alongside internationally acclaimed techno innovators
Pheek, Miskate, Someone Else, Mikael Stavostrand, Butane, Fumiya
Tanaka and Joel Mull.

Enjoy ample parking, no cover and cheap drinks plus live bands
downstairs in the basement.


Then, on FRIDAY, July 27, head to Anu for LA's [a]pendics.shuffle +
guests where laptops are sure to go wild in a digital orgy of freaky
beat madness:

[a]pendics.shuffle (live PA) + Konstantin Gabbro [Adjunct-Audio/LA]
Friday, July 27, 2007
9:00 PM - 2:00 AM
Cover: $5

Anu
43 Sixth St
San Francisco, California 94102

West Coast minimal techno label Adjunct-Audio label features founders
[a]pendics.shuffle and Konstantin Gabbro (Los Angeles)

Plus opening DJ sets by Kontakt + Solekandi (BABD, Filter.SF)

One of the early West Coast evangelists of minimal techno, Konstantin
Gabbro is the founder of Seattle's homegrown Orac Records, a label
that launched Bruno Pronsato and Kenneth James Gibson's
[a]pendics.shuffle moniker into the realm of the international
techorati.

In 2003 Konstantin moved down the Pacific Coast to Los Angeles where
he and Gibson (KJG) launched another label =96 Adjunct - a forward
thinking techno outlet that releases critically acclaimed collectibles
from names such as John Tejada, Pheek and newcomer Altiply.

A combination of Gabbro's well-schooled knowledge of deconstructed,
experimental techno with Gibson's mojo-laden epic Live PA sets goes
well beyond their description of "funky computer music" into the
sublime.

More information:

www.adjunct-audio.com
www.myspace.com/filtersf
http://www.anu-bar.com/
http://www.retoxsf.com/

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Its Word Of Mouth, this Sunday, July 15th, 12:00p - 7pm
FULLY PERMITTED!!!!!

Jerry Garcia Amphitheater @ John McLaren Park


This Sunday we'll be bringing you another monthly installment of fun in the sun. This time we have gone ahead and gotten a fully permitted location at Jerry Garcia Amphitheater in John McLaren Park. We'll have Chris and Ana Sia joining us on the wheels of steel alongside Space Invader and Niles of MK2 fame along with the illustrious Ganucheau and City Maverick coming out from Southern California for this event only!

Bring out some BBQ and beers, we'll be providing the beats and the vibes. For directions, check:

Directions: www.mclarenpark.org/Directions.htm

For public transportation, get yourself to the Glen Park BART station and we'll be running a shuttle bus courtesy of our friends at Down Low. The shuttle will be doing pick ups every hour on the 45.

11:45
12:45
1:45
2:45
3:45
4:45
and then a flurry of drop offs at the end of the party.

Here are the pick up coordinates:
maps.google.com/maps

Sound and Live Percussion will be provided by Alex Rojas.
Donations are GRATEFULLY accepted throughout the event.
We look forward to seeing you all in the SUn and the fun ..without a Nun.


For more information on this event or to sign up for our events list, check out womsound.com

From: "Nyc W. Alberts" <digitalcomponents@gmail.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Cow Hollow Muggings on the Rise

Wow, this is totally messed up. Some of my fondest and happiest memories 
of when I first moved to SF and was a live aboard a 27 foot sail boat on 
Marina Green, (unlimited, abundant, FREE parking!!!), and Cow Shallow 
and The Bermuda Triangle @ Fillmore & Greenwich was my stomping ground. 
I never once felt unsafe.

In counterpoint, I offer this recent true story of a robbery that went 
in an unexpected direction: http://tinyurl.com/23yl6p

.

Ranger - wrote:
>> From a friend:
>
> Hello All-
>
> For those that don't know Matt and I were mugged at gun point Monday 
> night at 10:30 in front of our house. We are OK and Jake was inside 
> with the baby sitter, thank goodness, but we wanted to share our story 
> so our friends and neighbors could also be aware that this could 
> happen at any time to any of us and to be alert, especially at night.
>
> Here are the details of what happened to us:
>
> As we rounded the corner of Octavia from Greenwich and approached the 
> front of our house, two men wearing skeleton masks, black hooded 
> sweatshirts, and carrying what looked like a semi-automatic weapon (we 
> don't know guns well but it had a clip), approached us and told us to 
> give them our valuables. We were caught a little off-guard, not 
> expecting something like this to happen, and sort of hesitated. They 
> started yelling that they would shoot us in the face and I handed over 
> my purse. Matt reached for his wallet and they knocked his hand away 
> and went through his pockets and took his wallet. They finally took 
> off down Greenwich St, at which point we called the police. It all 
> happened so fast and we honestly never saw it coming until the gun was 
> in our faces. Thank God that we were not hurt and Jake was not with us 
> but this could have been any one of us and it could have been worse. 
> The next day there was a report of a 65 yr old man that was shot in 
> the 900 block of Filbert (a few blocks away) in a botched burglary 
> about 30 minutes after we were held up. He is still in the hospital.
>
> We want to inform our friends and neighbors of this incident and let 
> them know that we should all be careful. We believe they were watching 
> from a hidden spot and picked us out as targets. We weren't paying 
> particular attention as we were walking and had our guard down. We 
> also believe they most likely had a get away car around the corner 
> because they disappeared quickly. We were told that gangs 'work' this 
> area as it's considered affluent and it's assumed that most people are 
> carrying some money with them. Since we've started sharing our story 
> with others we've heard back other accounts of recent muggings, hold 
> ups, and even an attempted kidnapping of a woman that happened in 
> broad daylight on Union and Lyon Streets. Attached is even another 
> account of a recent hold up sent to us by a friend.
>
> Please be careful out there and remember that even though we all live 
> in relatively safe neighborhoods, we are not immune to the perils of 
> living in a big city!!
>
>
> SFR: Ranger
> San Francisco
> plurranger@hotmail.com
> Who knows where the night leads
> It's dark and no one can see - Ranger
>
> "I hate to advocate drugs, alcohol, violence or insanity to anyone, 
> but it worked for me." -Hunter S. Thompson
>
> _________________________________________________________________
> http://liveearth.msn.com
>

Subject: [sfraves] [recommended] Andy Slate :: Wed :: Anu

During the 90's, German producer, remixer and DJ Andy Slate was
responsible for bringing the biggest names in techno such as Josh Wink
and Jeff Mills to new audiences in Hungary.

With a heavy collection of releases and remixes under his belt, Slate
works with Tim Taylor (Missle Records London) on studio projects in
both New York and Budapest, producing club-wise stompers worthy of
notice.

Slate takes a well-seasoned approach to dance-floor friendly techno
and minimal that will keep your feet moving. His intuitive track
progression allows for both ruff techno riffs, emotive moments and
deeper moods of house.


Wednesday, August 18
Anu
43 Sixth Street
San Francisco, CA
No cover (?)

www.satellitesf.com
www.andyslate.com

-- 

www.myspace.com/filtersf

Ok, well - downtown I'd suggest:

Rye on 688 Geary Street

or it's sister bar

Swig on 561 Geary St.

Or House of Shields on 39 New Montgomery St.

Beyond that I am more familiar w/ the Richmond Disctrict and it's haunts, 
which there quite a few of in the vein you are lookin' for. Lemme know if 
you want my suggestions there...

MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative; 
	boundary="----=_Part_76454_25673183.1184625249206"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Question for the vinyl-only nazis

------=_Part_76454_25673183.1184625249206
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

I understand your undying affinity for vinyl, but why do you constantly
write off any other form of dj'ing/live remixing???

When house/techno came about through the use of samplers, drum machines, and
sequencers, several people including many prominent musicians tried to tell
us the creation was somehow not worthy of being titled as "music."   The
people who were responsible for creating and innovating these sounds
embraced the new technology of the era.  With dance music's foundation for
the producer and dj alike in high technology, I find it at peculiar so many
old school jocks automatically shun so much new technology.   I guess I just
hear similar hypocrisy now days when I compare it to our critics 20 years
ago.

-Ben

PS  Real dj's use phonographs with a crank arm to control the pitch!

------=_Part_76454_25673183.1184625249206--

My only gripe with digital formats was that it lost the natural feel of
playing with vinyl. I have Serato now, though, so that problem was solved
and with it my only real objection to digital formats.

I can't speak for anyone else, but that's why I don't like cdjs and other
not natural feeling formats.

Message-ID: <BAY110-F35739F6916AB1407D2D38C85F80@phx.gbl>
X-Originating-IP: [75.37.249.46]
X-Originating-Email: [electrofunk138@hotmail.com]
X-Sender: electrofunk138@hotmail.com
In-Reply-To: <000c01c7c7f3$599adc50$0201a8c0@smithpc>
From: "Van Mundegaarde" <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>
To: sf_smith@comcast.net, sfraves@hyperreal.org
Bcc: 
Date: Mon, 16 Jul 2007 15:55:13 -0700
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 16 Jul 2007 22:55:16.0540 (UTC) FILETIME=[6057C7C0:01C7C7FC]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] Ultimate DJ setup /w pix please!!!

You obviously have never had to lug huge bags of records around the country 
for gigs...

I was a vinyl purist all the way up until this year - until I kept getting 
sent exclusive promo tracks in MP3 format, and until I had access to a CDJ.

>From a working DJ's perspective - or at least THIS working DJ's perspective, 
the pros for CD FAR outweigh the cons.

I can get an entire SET in an afternoon of downloading.
I can carry several "crates" worth of tracks in a single CD book.
I don't have to wait for vinyl releases - and in fact, I can get material 
that will NEVER be released on vinyl.
I don't have to suck up all the available storage in my house with the black 
crack.
A 320KBPS MP3 or a WAV sounds every bit as good over a system as vinyl. I 
have tried this on more than one sized sound system, and I just can't tell 
any significant difference. (although lower bitrate files CAN sound like 
low-pressed records)
I can digitize my entire vinyl collection and have it in an archive until 
digital goes the way of the dinosaur - vinyl is slowly being phased out in 
dance music (the notable exception being hip-hop).

So, I may jump off a cliff for fun - but not because someone who is clinging 
to the musical equivalent of BetaMax says so ;)

X-OriginalArrivalTime: 16 Jul 2007 22:58:38.0252 (UTC) FILETIME=[D89296C0:01C7C7FC]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Question for the vinyl-only nazis

I find working on CDJ's to be almost comparable in every way to using vinyl 
- the notable exception being it's not a visual mixing experience, so much 
as just knowing how tracks are made and when to properly mix (w/o seeing the 
drops on the record). You "count" instead of "watch" - which is actually 
much more akin to using an actual musical instrument.

>>us the creation was somehow not worthy of being titled as "music."   The
>>people who were responsible for creating and innovating these sounds
>>embraced the new technology of the era.  With dance music's foundation for
>>the producer and dj alike in high technology, I find it at peculiar so
>>many
>>old school jocks automatically shun so much new technology.   I guess I
>>just
>>hear similar hypocrisy now days when I compare it to our critics 20 years
>>ago.
>>
>>-Ben
>>
>>PS  Real dj's use phonographs with a crank arm to control the pitch!
>>

_________________________________________________________________
http://liveearth.msn.com

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Ultimate DJ setup /w pix please!!!

 >vinyl is slowly being phased out in dance music (the notable exception 
being hip-hop)

Other than in competition (DMC, ITF, ect), working hip hop deejays are 
almost 100% digital. Serato has taken over.

Van Mundegaarde wrote:
> You obviously have never had to lug huge bags of records around the 
> country for gigs...
>
> I was a vinyl purist all the way up until this year - until I kept 
> getting sent exclusive promo tracks in MP3 format, and until I had 
> access to a CDJ.
>
>> From a working DJ's perspective - or at least THIS working DJ's 
>> perspective, 
> the pros for CD FAR outweigh the cons.
>
> I can get an entire SET in an afternoon of downloading.
> I can carry several "crates" worth of tracks in a single CD book.
> I don't have to wait for vinyl releases - and in fact, I can get 
> material that will NEVER be released on vinyl.
> I don't have to suck up all the available storage in my house with the 
> black crack.
> A 320KBPS MP3 or a WAV sounds every bit as good over a system as 
> vinyl. I have tried this on more than one sized sound system, and I 
> just can't tell any significant difference. (although lower bitrate 
> files CAN sound like low-pressed records)
> I can digitize my entire vinyl collection and have it in an archive 
> until digital goes the way of the dinosaur - vinyl is slowly being 
> phased out in dance music (the notable exception being hip-hop).
>
> So, I may jump off a cliff for fun - but not because someone who is 
> clinging to the musical equivalent of BetaMax says so ;)
>
>
>
>

On 7/16/07, Van Mundegaarde <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:
>
> I find working on CDJ's to be almost comparable in every way to using
> vinyl
> - the notable exception being it's not a visual mixing experience, so much
> as just knowing how tracks are made and when to properly mix (w/o seeing
> the
> drops on the record). You "count" instead of "watch" - which is actually
> much more akin to using an actual musical instrument.

and saw it. The man uses three CDJ1000s and no other input sources. Why

three CDJs).

> >My only gripe with digital formats was that it lost
> the natural feel of
> >playing with vinyl. I have Serato now, though, so
> that problem was solved
> >and with it my only real objection to digital
> formats.
> >
> >I can't speak for anyone else, but that's why I
> don't like cdjs and other
> >not natural feeling formats.
> >
> >On 7/16/07, Ben Haus <benhaus@gmail.com> wrote:
> >>
> >>I understand your undying affinity for vinyl, but
> why do you constantly
> >>write off any other form of dj'ing/live
> remixing???
> >>
> >>When house/techno came about through the use of
> samplers, drum machines,
> >>and
> >>sequencers, several people including many
> prominent musicians tried to
> >>tell
> >>us the creation was somehow not worthy of being
> titled as "music."   The
> >>people who were responsible for creating and
> innovating these sounds
> >>embraced the new technology of the era.  With
> dance music's foundation for
> >>the producer and dj alike in high technology, I
> find it at peculiar so
> >>many
> >>old school jocks automatically shun so much new
> technology.   I guess I
> >>just
> >>hear similar hypocrisy now days when I compare it
> to our critics 20 years
> >>ago.
> >>
> >>-Ben
> >>
> >>PS  Real dj's use phonographs with a crank arm to
> control the pitch!
> >>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Ultimate DJ setup /w pix please!!!

 
On Monday, July 16, 2007, at 04:05PM, "MOJO" <orfsound@yahoo.com> wrote:

>b)Carl COX is about the $$ from VESTAX I doubt he
>mixes on anything less than 4 channels and that would
>be compact in his book! 

Actually, its 8 inputs, 3 active mix channels, although you can route other inputs directly to main or secondary outputs too. 4 Phono and 4 Line. Each of these can be assigned to one of the three faders in any way you like. You can even do neat stuff like play the same track through all three faders at once, with different EQ and filter settings. Hours of endless entertainment tweaking :)

S.

To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

> >> >>

> >>machines,
> >> >>and
> >> >>sequencers, several people including many prominent musicians tried
> to
> >> >>tell
> >> >>us the creation was somehow not worthy of being titled as "music."
> >>The
> >> >>people who were responsible for creating and innovating these sounds
> >> >>embraced the new technology of the era.  With dance music's
> foundation
> >>for
> >> >>the producer and dj alike in high technology, I find it at peculiar
> so
> >> >>many
> >> >>old school jocks automatically shun so much new technology.   I guess
> I
> >> >>just
> >> >>hear similar hypocrisy now days when I compare it to our critics 20
> >>years
> >> >>ago.

From sfraves-return-140125-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Tue Jul 17 17:19:07 2007
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-140125-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org

Mime-Version: 1.0 (Apple Message framework v752.2)

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=WINDOWS-1252; delsp=yes; format=flowed

Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
From: Will Penna <w.penna@comcast.net>
Date: Tue, 17 Jul 2007 10:18:59 -0700
To: "The Twilight Laser Outpost (West)" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.752.2)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] NRR: The Progressive Apocalypse and Other Futurismic Delights, by Cory Doctorow

Cory Doctorow on lapsarianism, the apocalypse, progressivism, the =20
singularity and why the present matters more than the future.
http://www.locusmag.com/Features/2007/07/cory-doctorow-progressive-=20
apocalypse.html

Cory Doctorow: The Progressive Apocalypse and Other Futurismic Delights
from Locus Magazine, July 2007

Of course, science fiction is a literature of the present. Many's the =20=

science fiction writer who uses the future as a warped mirror for =20
reflecting back the present day, angled to illustrate the hidden =20
strangeness buried by our invisible assumptions: Orwell turned 1948 =20
into Nineteen Eighty-Four. But even when the fictional future isn't a =20=

parable about the present day, it is necessarily a creation of the =20
present day, since it reflects the present day biases that infuse the =20=

author. Hence Asimov's Foundation, a New Deal-esque project to think =20
humanity out of its tribulations though social interventionism.

Bold SF writers eschew the future altogether, embracing a futuristic =20
account of the present day. William Gibson's forthcoming Spook =20
Country is an act of "speculative presentism," a book so futuristic =20
it could only have been set in 2006, a book that exploits =20
retrospective historical distance to let us glimpse just how alien =20
and futuristic our present day is.

Science fiction writers aren't the only people in the business of =20
predicting the future. Futurists =97 consultants, technology =20
columnists, analysts, venture capitalists, and entrepreneurial =20
pitchmen =97 spill a lot of ink, phosphors, and caffeinated hot air in =20=

describing a vision for a future where we'll get more and more of =20
whatever it is they want to sell us or warn us away from. Tomorrow =20
will feature faster, cheaper processors, more Internet users, =20
ubiquitous RFID tags, radically democratic political processes =20
dominated by bloggers, massively multiplayer games whose virtual =20
economies dwarf the physical economy.

There's a lovely neologism to describe these visions: "futurismic." =20
Futurismic media is that which depicts futurism, not the future. It =20
is often self-serving =97 think of the antigrav Nikes in Back to the =20
Future III =97 and it generally doesn't hold up well to scrutiny.

SF films and TV are great fonts of futurismic imagery: R2D2 is a =20
fully conscious AI, can hack the firewall of the Death Star, and is =20
equipped with a range of holographic projectors and antipersonnel =20
devices =97 but no one has installed a $15 sound card and some text-to-=20=

speech software on him, so he has to whistle like Harpo Marx. Or take =20=

the Starship Enterprise, with a transporter capable of constituting =20
matter from digitally stored plans, and radios that can breach the =20
speed of light.

The non-futurismic version of NCC-1701 would be the size of a =20
softball (or whatever the minimum size for a warp drive, transporter, =20=

and subspace radio would be). It would zip around the galaxy at FTL =20
speeds under remote control. When it reached an interesting planet, =20
it would beam a stored copy of a landing party onto the surface, and =20
when their mission was over, it would beam them back into storage, =20
annihilating their physical selves until they reached the next =20
stopping point. If a member of the landing party were eaten by a =20
green-skinned interspatial hippie or giant toga-wearing galactic =20
tyrant, that member would be recovered from backup by the transporter =20=

beam. Hell, the entire landing party could consist of multiple copies =20=

of the most effective crewmember onboard: no redshirts, just a half-=20
dozen instances of Kirk operating in clonal harmony.

Futurism has a psychological explanation, as recounted in Harvard =20
clinical psych prof Daniel Gilbert's 2006 book, Stumbling on =20
Happiness. Our memories and our projections of the future are =20
necessarily imperfect. Our memories consist of those observations our =20=

brains have bothered to keep records of, woven together with =20
inference and whatever else is lying around handy when we try to =20
remember something. Ask someone who's eating a great lunch how =20
breakfast was, and odds are she'll tell you it was delicious. Ask the =20=

same question of someone eating rubbery airplane food, and he'll tell =20=

you his breakfast was awful. We weave the past out of our imperfect =20
memories and our observable present.

We make the future in much the same way: we use reasoning and =20
evidence to predict what we can, and whenever we bump up against =20
uncertainty, we fill the void with the present day. Hence the =20
injunction on women soldiers in the future of Starship Troopers, or =20
the bizarre, glassed-over "Progressland" city diorama at the end of =20
the 1964 World's Fair exhibit The Carousel of Progress, which Disney =20
built for GE.

Lapsarianism =97 the idea of a paradise lost, a fall from grace that =20
makes each year worse than the last =97 is the predominant future =20
feeling for many people. It's easy to see why: an imperfectly =20
remembered golden childhood gives way to the worries of adulthood and =20=

physical senescence. Surely the world is getting worse: nothing =20
tastes as good as it did when we were six, everything hurts all the =20
time, and our matured gonads drive us into frenzies of bizarre, self-=20
destructive behavior.

Lapsarianism dominates the Abrahamic faiths. I have an Orthodox =20
Jewish friend whose tradition holds that each generation of rabbis is =20=

necessarily less perfect than the rabbis that came before, since each =20=

generation is more removed from the perfection of the Garden. =20
Therefore, no rabbi is allowed to overturn any of his forebears' =20
wisdom, since they are all, by definition, smarter than him.

The natural endpoint of Lapsarianism is apocalypse. If things get =20
worse, and worse, and worse, eventually they'll just run out of =20
worseness. Eventually, they'll bottom out, a kind of rotten death of =20
the universe when Lapsarian entropy hits the nadir and takes us all =20
with it.

Running counter to Lapsarianism is progressivism: the Enlightenment =20
ideal of a world of great people standing on the shoulders of giants. =20=

Each of us contributes to improving the world's storehouse of =20
knowledge (and thus its capacity for bringing joy to all of us), and =20
our descendants and proteges take our work and improve on it. The =20
very idea of "progress" runs counter to the idea of Lapsarianism and =20
the fall: it is the idea that we, as a species, are falling in =20
reverse, combing back the wild tangle of entropy into a neat, tidy =20
braid.

Of course, progress must also have a boundary condition =97 if only =20
because we eventually run out of imaginary ways that the human =20
condition can improve. And science fiction has a name for the upper =20
bound of progress, a name for the progressive apocalypse:

We call it the Singularity.

Vernor Vinge's Singularity takes place when our technology reaches a =20
stage that allows us to "upload" our minds into software, run them at =20=

faster, hotter speeds than our neurological wetware substrate allows =20
for, and create multiple, parallel instances of ourselves. After the =20
Singularity, nothing is predictable because everything is possible. =20
We will cease to be human and become (as the title of Rudy Rucker's =20
next novel would have it) Postsingular.

The Singularity is what happens when we have so much progress that we =20=

run out of progress. It's the apocalypse that ends the human race in =20
rapture and joy. Indeed, Ken MacLeod calls the Singularity "the =20
rapture of the nerds," an apt description for the mirror-world =20
progressive version of the Lapsarian apocalypse.

At the end of the day, both progress and the fall from grace are =20
illusions. The central thesis of Stumbling on Happiness is that human =20=

beings are remarkably bad at predicting what will make us happy. Our =20
predictions are skewed by our imperfect memories and our capacity for =20=

filling the future with the present day.

The future is gnarlier than futurism. NCC-1701 probably wouldn't send =20=

out transporter-equipped drones =97 instead, it would likely find =20
itself on missions whose ethos, mores, and rationale are largely =20
incomprehensible to us, and so obvious to its crew that they couldn't =20=

hope to explain them.

Science fiction is the literature of the present, and the present is =20
the only era that we can hope to understand, because it's the only =20
era that lets us check our observations and predictions against reality.

Cory Doctorow's website is Craphound.com, and he is co-editor of =20
Boing Boing: A Directory of Wonderful Things. Cory Doctorow is one of =20=

a dozen Locus columnists and reviewers. Every issue, we review over =20
50 books and magazines, most before they appear in print. A =20
subscription will get you all those as well as the rest of the =20
magazine -- news, People & Publishing, commentary, reports on events, =20=

and a list of all books and magazines published that month.

Previous Cory Doctorow columns posted on Locus Online:
In Praise of Fanfic
You Do Like Reading Off a Computer
Blogging Without the Blog
The March of the Polygons: How High-Definition Is Bad News for SF Flicks
How Copyright Broke
Science Fiction is the Only Literature People Care Enough About to =20
Steal on the Internet.



---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: The Progressive Apocalypse and Other Futurismic Delights, by Cory Doctorow

Actually I think most science fiction is really the literature of the past.=
  The present is both too ephemeral and and at the same time too all pervas=
ive to be understood by most of us.  Its like a fish trying to understand t=
he physics of water while swimming.  And we only understand the present thr=
ought the filter of our past experiences. =0A=0A"We look at the present thr=
ough a rear-view mirror. We march backwards into=0Athe future."=0A=0AMarsha=
ll McLuhan=0A=0APeace,=0A=0APeter=0A=0A----- Original Message ----=0AFrom: =
Will Penna <w.penna@comcast.net>=0ATo: The Twilight Laser Outpost (West) <s=

writer who uses the future as a warped mirror for  =0Areflecting back the p=

 New Deal-esque project to think  =0Ahumanity out of its tribulations thoug=

=0Aand futuristic our present day is.=0A=0AScience fiction writers aren't t=
he only people in the business of  =0Apredicting the future. Futurists =97 =

=0Amatter from digitally stored plans, and radios that can breach the  =0As=
peed of light.=0A=0AThe non-futurismic version of NCC-1701 would be the siz=

rter,  =0Aand subspace radio would be). It would zip around the galaxy at F=

 =0Ait would beam a stored copy of a landing party onto the surface, and  =
=0Awhen their mission was over, it would beam them back into storage,  =0Aa=
nnihilating their physical selves until they reached the next  =0Astopping =
point. If a member of the landing party were eaten by a  =0Agreen-skinned i=
nterspatial hippie or giant toga-wearing galactic  =0Atyrant, that member w=
ould be recovered from backup by the transporter  =0Abeam. Hell, the entire=
 landing party could consist of multiple copies  =0Aof the most effective c=

erating in clonal harmony.=0A=0AFuturism has a psychological explanation, a=
s recounted in Harvard  =0Aclinical psych prof Daniel Gilbert's 2006 book, =
Stumbling on  =0AHappiness. Our memories and our projections of the future =
are  =0Anecessarily imperfect. Our memories consist of those observations o=
ur  =0Abrains have bothered to keep records of, woven together with  =0Ainf=
erence and whatever else is lying around handy when we try to  =0Aremember =
something. Ask someone who's eating a great lunch how  =0Abreakfast was, an=
d odds are she'll tell you it was delicious. Ask the  =0Asame question of s=
omeone eating rubbery airplane food, and he'll tell  =0Ayou his breakfast w=
as awful. We weave the past out of our imperfect  =0Amemories and our obser=
vable present.=0A=0AWe make the future in much the same way: we use reasoni=
ng and  =0Aevidence to predict what we can, and whenever we bump up against=
  =0Auncertainty, we fill the void with the present day. Hence the  =0Ainju=
nction on women soldiers in the future of Starship Troopers, or  =0Athe biz=
arre, glassed-over "Progressland" city diorama at the end of  =0Athe 1964 W=
orld's Fair exhibit The Carousel of Progress, which Disney  =0Abuilt for GE=
.=0A=0ALapsarianism =97 the idea of a paradise lost, a fall from grace that=
  =0Amakes each year worse than the last =97 is the predominant future  =0A=
feeling for many people. It's easy to see why: an imperfectly  =0Aremembere=
d golden childhood gives way to the worries of adulthood and  =0Aphysical s=
enescence. Surely the world is getting worse: nothing  =0Atastes as good as=
 it did when we were six, everything hurts all the  =0Atime, and our mature=
d gonads drive us into frenzies of bizarre, self- =0Adestructive behavior.=
=0A=0ALapsarianism dominates the Abrahamic faiths. I have an Orthodox  =0AJ=
ewish friend whose tradition holds that each generation of rabbis is  =0Ane=
cessarily less perfect than the rabbis that came before, since each  =0Agen=
eration is more removed from the perfection of the Garden.  =0ATherefore, n=
o rabbi is allowed to overturn any of his forebears'  =0Awisdom, since they=
 are all, by definition, smarter than him.=0A=0AThe natural endpoint of Lap=
sarianism is apocalypse. If things get  =0Aworse, and worse, and worse, eve=
ntually they'll just run out of  =0Aworseness. Eventually, they'll bottom o=
ut, a kind of rotten death of  =0Athe universe when Lapsarian entropy hits =
the nadir and takes us all  =0Awith it.=0A=0ARunning counter to Lapsarianis=
m is progressivism: the Enlightenment  =0Aideal of a world of great people =
standing on the shoulders of giants.  =0AEach of us contributes to improvin=
g the world's storehouse of  =0Aknowledge (and thus its capacity for bringi=
ng joy to all of us), and  =0Aour descendants and proteges take our work an=
d improve on it. The  =0Avery idea of "progress" runs counter to the idea o=
f Lapsarianism and  =0Athe fall: it is the idea that we, as a species, are =
falling in  =0Areverse, combing back the wild tangle of entropy into a neat=
, tidy  =0Abraid.=0A=0AOf course, progress must also have a boundary condit=
ion =97 if only  =0Abecause we eventually run out of imaginary ways that th=
e human  =0Acondition can improve. And science fiction has a name for the u=
pper  =0Abound of progress, a name for the progressive apocalypse:=0A=0AWe =
call it the Singularity.=0A=0AVernor Vinge's Singularity takes place when o=
ur technology reaches a  =0Astage that allows us to "upload" our minds into=
 software, run them at  =0Afaster, hotter speeds than our neurological wetw=
are substrate allows  =0Afor, and create multiple, parallel instances of ou=
rselves. After the  =0ASingularity, nothing is predictable because everythi=
ng is possible.  =0AWe will cease to be human and become (as the title of R=
udy Rucker's  =0Anext novel would have it) Postsingular.=0A=0AThe Singulari=
ty is what happens when we have so much progress that we  =0Arun out of pro=
gress. It's the apocalypse that ends the human race in  =0Arapture and joy.=
 Indeed, Ken MacLeod calls the Singularity "the  =0Arapture of the nerds," =

From: "Nyc W. Alberts" <digitalcomponents@gmail.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: The Progressive Apocalypse and Other Futurismic
 Delights, by Cory Doctorow

I believe Ray Kurzweil is right, it's change that we're going to have to 
deal with most.

Today's fastest computers run at about 5 ghz.

If Moore's Law holds at an 18 month doubling window, then by the year 
2020 the average machine will run at 1,000 ghz, and cost the same in 
real dollars.

There's no way that that won't have a profound effect on people in ways 
that we can't even begin to imagine right now.

Look at how much things have changed since Mosaic went live 12 years ago 
and gave birth to the commercial web. What do you think the next 12 
years are going to be like?

....

dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
> Actually I think most science fiction is really the literature of the past.  The present is both too ephemeral and and at the same time too all pervasive to be understood by most of us.  Its like a fish trying to understand the physics of water while swimming.  And we only understand the present throught the filter of our past experiences. 
>
> "We look at the present through a rear-view mirror. We march backwards into
> the future."
>
> Marshall McLuhan
>
> Peace,
>
> Peter
>
> ----- Original Message ----
> From: Will Penna <w.penna@comcast.net>
> To: The Twilight Laser Outpost (West) <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> Sent: Tuesday, July 17, 2007 10:18:59 AM
> Subject: [sfraves] NRR: The Progressive Apocalypse and Other Futurismic Delights, by Cory Doctorow
>
>
> Cory Doctorow on lapsarianism, the apocalypse, progressivism, the  
> singularity and why the present matters more than the future.
> http://www.locusmag.com/Features/2007/07/cory-doctorow-progressive- 
> apocalypse.html
>
> Cory Doctorow: The Progressive Apocalypse and Other Futurismic Delights
> from Locus Magazine, July 2007
>
> Of course, science fiction is a literature of the present. Many's the  
> science fiction writer who uses the future as a warped mirror for  
> reflecting back the present day, angled to illustrate the hidden  
> strangeness buried by our invisible assumptions: Orwell turned 1948  
> into Nineteen Eighty-Four. But even when the fictional future isn't a  
> parable about the present day, it is necessarily a creation of the  
> present day, since it reflects the present day biases that infuse the  
> author. Hence Asimov's Foundation, a New Deal-esque project to think  
> humanity out of its tribulations though social interventionism.
>
> Bold SF writers eschew the future altogether, embracing a futuristic  
> account of the present day. William Gibson's forthcoming Spook  
> Country is an act of "speculative presentism," a book so futuristic  
> it could only have been set in 2006, a book that exploits  
> retrospective historical distance to let us glimpse just how alien  
> and futuristic our present day is.
>
> Science fiction writers aren't the only people in the business of  
> predicting the future. Futurists  consultants, technology  
> columnists, analysts, venture capitalists, and entrepreneurial  
> pitchmen  spill a lot of ink, phosphors, and caffeinated hot air in  
> describing a vision for a future where we'll get more and more of  
> whatever it is they want to sell us or warn us away from. Tomorrow  
> will feature faster, cheaper processors, more Internet users,  
> ubiquitous RFID tags, radically democratic political processes  
> dominated by bloggers, massively multiplayer games whose virtual  
> economies dwarf the physical economy.
>
> There's a lovely neologism to describe these visions: "futurismic."  
> Futurismic media is that which depicts futurism, not the future. It  
> is often self-serving  think of the antigrav Nikes in Back to the  
> Future III  and it generally doesn't hold up well to scrutiny.
>
> SF films and TV are great fonts of futurismic imagery: R2D2 is a  
> fully conscious AI, can hack the firewall of the Death Star, and is  
> equipped with a range of holographic projectors and antipersonnel  
> devices  but no one has installed a $15 sound card and some text-to- 
> speech software on him, so he has to whistle like Harpo Marx. Or take  
> the Starship Enterprise, with a transporter capable of constituting  
> matter from digitally stored plans, and radios that can breach the  
> speed of light.
>
> The non-futurismic version of NCC-1701 would be the size of a  
> softball (or whatever the minimum size for a warp drive, transporter,  
> and subspace radio would be). It would zip around the galaxy at FTL  
> speeds under remote control. When it reached an interesting planet,  
> it would beam a stored copy of a landing party onto the surface, and  
> when their mission was over, it would beam them back into storage,  
> annihilating their physical selves until they reached the next  
> stopping point. If a member of the landing party were eaten by a  
> green-skinned interspatial hippie or giant toga-wearing galactic  
> tyrant, that member would be recovered from backup by the transporter  
> beam. Hell, the entire landing party could consist of multiple copies  
> of the most effective crewmember onboard: no redshirts, just a half- 
> dozen instances of Kirk operating in clonal harmony.
>
> Futurism has a psychological explanation, as recounted in Harvard  
> clinical psych prof Daniel Gilbert's 2006 book, Stumbling on  
> Happiness. Our memories and our projections of the future are  
> necessarily imperfect. Our memories consist of those observations our  
> brains have bothered to keep records of, woven together with  
> inference and whatever else is lying around handy when we try to  
> remember something. Ask someone who's eating a great lunch how  
> breakfast was, and odds are she'll tell you it was delicious. Ask the  
> same question of someone eating rubbery airplane food, and he'll tell  
> you his breakfast was awful. We weave the past out of our imperfect  
> memories and our observable present.
>
> We make the future in much the same way: we use reasoning and  
> evidence to predict what we can, and whenever we bump up against  
> uncertainty, we fill the void with the present day. Hence the  
> injunction on women soldiers in the future of Starship Troopers, or  
> the bizarre, glassed-over "Progressland" city diorama at the end of  
> the 1964 World's Fair exhibit The Carousel of Progress, which Disney  
> built for GE.
>
> Lapsarianism  the idea of a paradise lost, a fall from grace that  
> makes each year worse than the last  is the predominant future  
> feeling for many people. It's easy to see why: an imperfectly  
> remembered golden childhood gives way to the worries of adulthood and  
> physical senescence. Surely the world is getting worse: nothing  
> tastes as good as it did when we were six, everything hurts all the  
> time, and our matured gonads drive us into frenzies of bizarre, self- 
> destructive behavior.
>
> Lapsarianism dominates the Abrahamic faiths. I have an Orthodox  
> Jewish friend whose tradition holds that each generation of rabbis is  
> necessarily less perfect than the rabbis that came before, since each  
> generation is more removed from the perfection of the Garden.  
> Therefore, no rabbi is allowed to overturn any of his forebears'  
> wisdom, since they are all, by definition, smarter than him.
>
> The natural endpoint of Lapsarianism is apocalypse. If things get  
> worse, and worse, and worse, eventually they'll just run out of  
> worseness. Eventually, they'll bottom out, a kind of rotten death of  
> the universe when Lapsarian entropy hits the nadir and takes us all  
> with it.
>
> Running counter to Lapsarianism is progressivism: the Enlightenment  
> ideal of a world of great people standing on the shoulders of giants.  
> Each of us contributes to improving the world's storehouse of  
> knowledge (and thus its capacity for bringing joy to all of us), and  
> our descendants and proteges take our work and improve on it. The  
> very idea of "progress" runs counter to the idea of Lapsarianism and  
> the fall: it is the idea that we, as a species, are falling in  
> reverse, combing back the wild tangle of entropy into a neat, tidy  
> braid.
>
> Of course, progress must also have a boundary condition  if only  
> because we eventually run out of imaginary ways that the human  
> condition can improve. And science fiction has a name for the upper  
> bound of progress, a name for the progressive apocalypse:
>
> We call it the Singularity.
>
> Vernor Vinge's Singularity takes place when our technology reaches a  
> stage that allows us to "upload" our minds into software, run them at  
> faster, hotter speeds than our neurological wetware substrate allows  
> for, and create multiple, parallel instances of ourselves. After the  
> Singularity, nothing is predictable because everything is possible.  
> We will cease to be human and become (as the title of Rudy Rucker's  
> next novel would have it) Postsingular.
>
> The Singularity is what happens when we have so much progress that we  
> run out of progress. It's the apocalypse that ends the human race in  
> rapture and joy. Indeed, Ken MacLeod calls the Singularity "the  
> rapture of the nerds," an apt description for the mirror-world  
> progressive version of the Lapsarian apocalypse.
>
> At the end of the day, both progress and the fall from grace are  
> illusions. The central thesis of Stumbling on Happiness is that human  
> beings are remarkably bad at predicting what will make us happy. Our  
> predictions are skewed by our imperfect memories and our capacity for  
> filling the future with the present day.
>
> The future is gnarlier than futurism. NCC-1701 probably wouldn't send  
> out transporter-equipped drones  instead, it would likely find  
> itself on missions whose ethos, mores, and rationale are largely  
> incomprehensible to us, and so obvious to its crew that they couldn't  
> hope to explain them.
>
> Science fiction is the literature of the present, and the present is  
> the only era that we can hope to understand, because it's the only  
> era that lets us check our observations and predictions against reality.
>
> Cory Doctorow's website is Craphound.com, and he is co-editor of  
> Boing Boing: A Directory of Wonderful Things. Cory Doctorow is one of  
> a dozen Locus columnists and reviewers. Every issue, we review over  
> 50 books and magazines, most before they appear in print. A  
> subscription will get you all those as well as the rest of the  
> magazine -- news, People & Publishing, commentary, reports on events,  
> and a list of all books and magazines published that month.
>
> Previous Cory Doctorow columns posted on Locus Online:
> In Praise of Fanfic
> You Do Like Reading Off a Computer
> Blogging Without the Blog
> The March of the Polygons: How High-Definition Is Bad News for SF Flicks
> How Copyright Broke
> Science Fiction is the Only Literature People Care Enough About to  
> Steal on the Internet.
>
>
>
> ---------------------------------------------------------------------
> To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
> For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org
>
> ---------------------------------------------------------------------
> To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
> For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org
>
>
>

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

agazine, July 2007=0A>=0A> Of course, science fiction is a literature of th=
e present. Many's the  =0A> science fiction writer who uses the future as a=
 warped mirror for  =0A> reflecting back the present day, angled to illustr=
ate the hidden  =0A> strangeness buried by our invisible assumptions: Orwel=
l turned 1948  =0A> into Nineteen Eighty-Four. But even when the fictional =
future isn't a  =0A> parable about the present day, it is necessarily a cre=
ation of the  =0A> present day, since it reflects the present day biases th=
at infuse the  =0A> author. Hence Asimov's Foundation, a New Deal-esque pro=
ject to think  =0A> humanity out of its tribulations though social interven=
tionism.=0A>=0A> Bold SF writers eschew the future altogether, embracing a =
futuristic  =0A> account of the present day. William Gibson's forthcoming S=
pook  =0A> Country is an act of "speculative presentism," a book so futuris=
tic  =0A> it could only have been set in 2006, a book that exploits  =0A> r=
etrospective historical distance to let us glimpse just how alien  =0A> and=
 futuristic our present day is.=0A>=0A> Science fiction writers aren't the =
only people in the business of  =0A> predicting the future. Futurists =97 c=
onsultants, technology  =0A> columnists, analysts, venture capitalists, and=
 entrepreneurial  =0A> pitchmen =97 spill a lot of ink, phosphors, and caff=
einated hot air in  =0A> describing a vision for a future where we'll get m=
ore and more of  =0A> whatever it is they want to sell us or warn us away f=
rom. Tomorrow  =0A> will feature faster, cheaper processors, more Internet =
users,  =0A> ubiquitous RFID tags, radically democratic political processes=
  =0A> dominated by bloggers, massively multiplayer games whose virtual  =
=0A> economies dwarf the physical economy.=0A>=0A> There's a lovely neologi=
sm to describe these visions: "futurismic."  =0A> Futurismic media is that =
which depicts futurism, not the future. It  =0A> is often self-serving =97 =
think of the antigrav Nikes in Back to the  =0A> Future III =97 and it gene=
rally doesn't hold up well to scrutiny.=0A>=0A> SF films and TV are great f=
onts of futurismic imagery: R2D2 is a  =0A> fully conscious AI, can hack th=
e firewall of the Death Star, and is  =0A> equipped with a range of hologra=
phic projectors and antipersonnel  =0A> devices =97 but no one has installe=
d a $15 sound card and some text-to- =0A> speech software on him, so he has=
 to whistle like Harpo Marx. Or take  =0A> the Starship Enterprise, with a =
transporter capable of constituting  =0A> matter from digitally stored plan=
s, and radios that can breach the  =0A> speed of light.=0A>=0A> The non-fut=
urismic version of NCC-1701 would be the size of a  =0A> softball (or whate=
ver the minimum size for a warp drive, transporter,  =0A> and subspace radi=
o would be). It would zip around the galaxy at FTL  =0A> speeds under remot=
e control. When it reached an interesting planet,  =0A> it would beam a sto=
red copy of a landing party onto the surface, and  =0A> when their mission =
was over, it would beam them back into storage,  =0A> annihilating their ph=
ysical selves until they reached the next  =0A> stopping point. If a member=
 of the landing party were eaten by a  =0A> green-skinned interspatial hipp=
ie or giant toga-wearing galactic  =0A> tyrant, that member would be recove=
red from backup by the transporter  =0A> beam. Hell, the entire landing par=
ty could consist of multiple copies  =0A> of the most effective crewmember =
onboard: no redshirts, just a half- =0A> dozen instances of Kirk operating =
in clonal harmony.=0A>=0A> Futurism has a psychological explanation, as rec=
ounted in Harvard  =0A> clinical psych prof Daniel Gilbert's 2006 book, Stu=
mbling on  =0A> Happiness. Our memories and our projections of the future a=
re  =0A> necessarily imperfect. Our memories consist of those observations =
our  =0A> brains have bothered to keep records of, woven together with  =0A=
> inference and whatever else is lying around handy when we try to  =0A> re=
member something. Ask someone who's eating a great lunch how  =0A> breakfas=
t was, and odds are she'll tell you it was delicious. Ask the  =0A> same qu=
estion of someone eating rubbery airplane food, and he'll tell  =0A> you hi=
s breakfast was awful. We weave the past out of our imperfect  =0A> memorie=
s and our observable present.=0A>=0A> We make the future in much the same w=
ay: we use reasoning and  =0A> evidence to predict what we can, and wheneve=
r we bump up against  =0A> uncertainty, we fill the void with the present d=
ay. Hence the  =0A> injunction on women soldiers in the future of Starship =
Troopers, or  =0A> the bizarre, glassed-over "Progressland" city diorama at=
 the end of  =0A> the 1964 World's Fair exhibit The Carousel of Progress, w=
hich Disney  =0A> built for GE.=0A>=0A> Lapsarianism =97 the idea of a para=
dise lost, a fall from grace that  =0A> makes each year worse than the last=
 =97 is the predominant future  =0A> feeling for many people. It's easy to =
see why: an imperfectly  =0A> remembered golden childhood gives way to the =
worries of adulthood and  =0A> physical senescence. Surely the world is get=
ting worse: nothing  =0A> tastes as good as it did when we were six, everyt=
hing hurts all the  =0A> time, and our matured gonads drive us into frenzie=
s of bizarre, self- =0A> destructive behavior.=0A>=0A> Lapsarianism dominat=
es the Abrahamic faiths. I have an Orthodox  =0A> Jewish friend whose tradi=
tion holds that each generation of rabbis is  =0A> necessarily less perfect=
 than the rabbis that came before, since each  =0A> generation is more remo=
ved from the perfection of the Garden.  =0A> Therefore, no rabbi is allowed=
 to overturn any of his forebears'  =0A> wisdom, since they are all, by def=
inition, smarter than him.=0A>=0A> The natural endpoint of Lapsarianism is =
apocalypse. If things get  =0A> worse, and worse, and worse, eventually the=
y'll just run out of  =0A> worseness. Eventually, they'll bottom out, a kin=
d of rotten death of  =0A> the universe when Lapsarian entropy hits the nad=
ir and takes us all  =0A> with it.=0A>=0A> Running counter to Lapsarianism =
is progressivism: the Enlightenment  =0A> ideal of a world of great people =
standing on the shoulders of giants.  =0A> Each of us contributes to improv=
ing the world's storehouse of  =0A> knowledge (and thus its capacity for br=
inging joy to all of us), and  =0A> our descendants and proteges take our w=
ork and improve on it. The  =0A> very idea of "progress" runs counter to th=
e idea of Lapsarianism and  =0A> the fall: it is the idea that we, as a spe=
cies, are falling in  =0A> reverse, combing back the wild tangle of entropy=
 into a neat, tidy  =0A> braid.=0A>=0A> Of course, progress must also have =
a boundary condition =97 if only  =0A> because we eventually run out of ima=
ginary ways that the human  =0A> condition can improve. And science fiction=
 has a name for the upper  =0A> bound of progress, a name for the progressi=
ve apocalypse:=0A>=0A> We call it the Singularity.=0A>=0A> Vernor Vinge's S=
ingularity takes place when our technology reaches a  =0A> stage that allow=
s us to "upload" our minds into software, run them at  =0A> faster, hotter =
speeds than our neurological wetware substrate allows  =0A> for, and create=
 multiple, parallel instances of ourselves. After the  =0A> Singularity, no=
thing is predictable because everything is possible.  =0A> We will cease to=
 be human and become (as the title of Rudy Rucker's  =0A> next novel would =
have it) Postsingular.=0A>=0A> The Singularity is what happens when we have=
 so much progress that we  =0A> run out of progress. It's the apocalypse th=
at ends the human race in  =0A> rapture and joy. Indeed, Ken MacLeod calls =
the Singularity "the  =0A> rapture of the nerds," an apt description for th=
e mirror-world  =0A> progressive version of the Lapsarian apocalypse.=0A>=
=0A> At the end of the day, both progress and the fall from grace are  =0A>=
 illusions. The central thesis of Stumbling on Happiness is that human  =0A=
> beings are remarkably bad at predicting what will make us happy. Our  =0A=
> predictions are skewed by our imperfect memories and our capacity for  =
=0A> filling the future with the present day.=0A>=0A> The future is gnarlie=
r than futurism. NCC-1701 probably wouldn't send  =0A> out transporter-equi=
pped drones =97 instead, it would likely find  =0A> itself on missions whos=
e ethos, mores, and rationale are largely  =0A> incomprehensible to us, and=
 so obvious to its crew that they couldn't  =0A> hope to explain them.=0A>=
=0A> Science fiction is the literature of the present, and the present is  =
=0A> the only era that we can hope to understand, because it's the only  =
=0A> era that lets us check our observations and predictions against realit=
y.=0A>=0A> Cory Doctorow's website is Craphound.com, and he is co-editor of=

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: The Progressive Apocalypse and Other Futurismic
 Delights, by Cory Doctorow

dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
> See also http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Accelerating_change
>
> I am full of McLuhan quotations today...
>
> "The suddenness of the leap from hardware to software cannot but produce a period of anarchy and collapse, especially in the developed countries." 
>
> Marshall McLuhan
>
> Are we having fun yet? 
>
> Peter
>   
.
Yeah, I've read my McLuhan too, that's a major premise of his in 'The 
Medium Is The Massage.'

Short version, countries like those in Africa will be able to leap-frog 
past the West at a certain point because they won't have an installed 
technological infrastructure to scrap.

That's what the not-so-evil Negroponte is trying to do with his OLPC 
initiative.

Right now a Ghz of CPU power costs about $200 dollars, but in a few 
iterations of Moore's Law the price is going to drop dramatically, 
making that project a practical reality.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] jesus de christo. craigslist sucks

Craigslist, much like Kane's girlfriend/wife in Citizen Kane, is an 
accurate cross-section of the American Public, and a living indictment 
of the failure of our public school system.

I don't care how libertarian the Craigster styles himself to be, I'd 
like to see him pull the plug on the Rants& Raves section as a failed 
social experiment.

How much more evidence does one need that we've got a lot of fucked in 
the head people running around in this country?

Basta.

Enough, I say.

DKay is the shit, I dig some of Nu:Tone's shit as well.

And as for you seeing me play heaven scent at a party, the only party I
remember playing trance at (in this city anyway) was Osby's warehouse
jimmy-jam, and I was only playing trance because Osby told me to. That set
is not indicative of future results. Heh.

Also, it was Lost Tribe - Gamemaster that you heard most likely. Quite
possibly the gayest trance record in the world.

>Garth's Analogue Studio Gear For Sale
>Body: 	Want to own a piece of San Francisco DJ history?
>
>After much soul-searching I've decided to let go of my analogue studio 
>setup.
>
>This is the same gear I produced all of the Wicked and Grayhound singles 
>on.
>

>one go as a working studio.
>
>Here's a list of the gear for sale...

>ROLAND 303 (ANALOGUE ACID BASS SYNTH MODULE)
>ROLAND R8 (ANALOGUE RHYTHM COMPOSER W/SOUND CARDS)
>2 X ENSONIQ DP2S (PARALLEL EFFECTS PROCESSOR)
>2 X BEHRINGER COMPOSERS (DYNAMICS PROCESSOR)
>EMU E64 (DIGITAL SAMPLER W/FULLY EXPANDED MEMORY)
>NOVATION DRUM STATION (ANALOGUE 909 & 808 SYNTH RACK)
>EMU CLASSIC KEYS (ANALOGUE SYNTH RACK)
>SOUNDCRAFT GHOST (24 CHANNEL/8 BUS ANALOGUE MIXING CONSOLE)
>DESIGNER MIXER & KEYBOAD STAND (CUSTOM BUILT IN STEEL)
>POWERMAC 7100 (DESKTOP COMPUTER W/SOUNDCARD)
>* ALL MANUALS/WIRES & LEADS INCLUDED
>
>Everything is in good working condition. The studio has always been 
>smoke-free and all the gear looks like new except for the Roland bits which 
>are vintage. They work wonderfully but look like they've seen some action 
>in the 30 years they've been in service (and they ain't lying).
>

>please.

Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) S 1082 FDA Legislation

I am wondering if anyone on the list is following current  
legislation, the House a few days ago passed a bill without debate,  
HR 2900 that gives the FDA the power to remove supplements from the  
market based on their opinion.  The Senate's version of this bill is  
S 1082.  I just emailed Boxer and Feinstein about this, I don't know  
much about it but I thought the FDA was basically bought and paid for  
by the drug companies so why give them the power to mess with  
supplements.

From: "Nyc W. Alberts" <digitalcomponents@gmail.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] jesus de christo. craigslist sucks

Sarilion wrote:
> I figured out people were fucked up long before the internet.. So I'm 
> a little lost on why I shouldn't use craigslist for anything I can?  
> It's a great resource, found me jobs, houses, food, activities...
.
I don't take issue with the commercial end of the site, never have, my 
comments were inspired by the social end. Somehow, even with working for 
a spell at alt  I got to miss the whole online dating thing, but I've 
heard very few happy stories about hook-ups from there.

No, the thing I'm talking about is the Rants & Raves section. Doesn't 
matter which city it's in, it's uniformly awful from coast to coast and 
sea to shining sea, and while I see where Craig says he's coming from, I 
don't share his belief that the flagging system is all that great.

Dave Chapelle quit doing his show, and walked away from a nice contract 
on the grounds that his comedy was having the exact opposite effect that 
he was going for. I see what goes on on that end of the site as feeding 
the same monster that so alarmed Mr. Chapelle.

It's gratuitous.

.
>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) S 1082 FDA Legislation


On Wed, 18 Jul 2007, Deepfog wrote:
-&e->I am wondering if anyone on the list is following current legislation, the
-&e->House a few days ago passed a bill without debate, HR 2900 that gives the
-&e->FDA the power to remove supplements from the market based on their opinion.
-&e->The Senate's version of this bill is S 1082.  I just emailed Boxer and
-&e->Feinstein about this, I don't know much about it but I thought the FDA was
-&e->basically bought and paid for by the drug companies so why give them the
-&e->power to mess with supplements.

I'm sure they won't touch your Enzyte shipments Deepfog.

And honestly, not sure who should do this but... there's a RASH of "this 
is not evaluated" by the FDA shit out there that could feasibly be a 
problem.  Remember all the shit we got with ephedra being put in all kinds 
of stuff?  There *should* be controls on what people can put in stuff and 
label as whatever.

Organic *should* mean organic.  Free trade should mean free trade.  And 
that should be enforced, most likely at the federal level.  It should be 
illegal to say something is something or does something when it doesn't.  
It was a major problem back in the days of patent medicines, and we're 
almost at that point again.

Doctah, get me some laudnum, I'm havin a weak spell...
andyw

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Patent_medicine

> > label as whatever.

up that the price of some supplements is pretty minor, all things
considered.

you're getting upset about what the FDA has to say ABOUT SOME FUCKING
SUPPLEMENTS?

Tha fuck?

that's one for the calendars... soul of house + twitch of techno.  Eric is 
fucking BADASS.  For all of you who worry about folks who are producers 
first, who have great releases out, but suck as DJs... DJ Bone made it as 
a DJ first, and then started cranking out silly good tech-soul after his 
time in the trenches.  He 'gets' Detroit but he's not stuck in it like 
some form of robotic nostalgia, top shelf shit.  If you have any doubts, 
check http://www.7mzdt.com/subjectdetroit/

Highly Recommended.

Subject: [sfraves] Head bobbing destroys the rave?  (Darwin and The Evolution of Music)

"Suppose an ancestral group evolves a 'Rave' gene that makes them dance eve=
ry night, doing their group-bonding thing, enjoying their group-competitive=
 advantages over other less musical groups. Then, perhaps a 'Wallflower' mu=
tation emerges among these People of the Rave, which predisposes its posses=
sors to rest while their comrades dance. Because the wallflower mutant does=
 not pay the enormous time and energy costs of dancing all night, but still=
 enjoys the advantages its group has over other groups, the Wallflower muta=
nt inevitably spreads through the People of the Rave. Within a few generati=
ons, the music would go away, and we would back to a population of well-res=
ted wallflowers."=0A=0Ahttp://www.futurehi.net/archives/000870.html =0Ahttp=
