Subject: [sfraves] Did You Call?

 From another list.... pls forward....

MW wrote:

So ....

Didja call yet?

Why not?

Do you Hate Our Freedom, or something? ;->

You know, one of the reasons the Lunatic Religious Right has made such
headway in politics over the past thirty years, is their authoritarian
structure. When the Pastor or the Phone Tree Lady calls a rabid
Evangelical and asks him/her to jump, the proper answer is "How High, O
Representative of The Living Lord? Thy requests are the *LORD's*
requests!! Thy every brainfart and assburr is the Word of the Holy
Spirit!!" (I'm really not exaggerating much.)

If these folks don't do what the pastor suggests, it eats at them and
"convicts them in the spirit", until they either do it, or burst into
tears of holy repentance at the next church service (which is always
sometime within the next 48 hours, BTW.)

But, of course, real lovers of freedom don't roll like that.

Which is why I'm reduced to abject begging.

Manipulation doesn't work with Libertarians and Progressives, so I'm
just going to *ask* you guys, outright, and remind you how important
this is. Even if you don't partake, yourself, think of the nation's
precious children, the *future* children, who may someday want to
self-medicate with one of the oldest, safest, most effective medicinal
herbs known to man, without having their doors busted down, their
property seized, their bank accounts emptied (if not outright -- which
happens, BTW -- then by interminable expensive legal fees while they
fight for their freedom) and their faces on the evening news, described
as "terrorists" or "predators on the community".

Please. This is your future as well as mine.

It's two to five minutes out of your life.
Thank you.

> (Sent to me yesterday. I pass it on to you.   Please send it to anyone
> you know who is of voting age.)
> 
> Please, please, please, ask your Congressperson to vote for the Hinchey
> Amendment to the Justice spending bill.
> 
> PLEASE CALL YOUR CONGRESSMAN.. IT IS EASY TO DO.  TIME IS OF THE ESSENCE.
> 
> Would you please take one minute to call your member of Congress and ask
> him or her to vote in favor of the medical marijuana amendment that the
> U.S. House of Representatives will be voting on THIS week?
> 
> It's easy: Just call the Capitol switchboard operator at (202) 224-3121.
> Give the operator your zip code and ask to be connected to your U.S.
> House member; you don't even need to know your congresspersons name to
> do this.
> 
> When the receptionist for the congressperson  not the Capitol
> switchboard operator  answers, say something like: "Hi, this is [name].
> I live in [city], and I'm calling to ask that my representative vote for
> Rep. Maurice Hinchey's [HIN-chee's] medical marijuana amendment to the
> Justice Department's spending bill, which I understand will be
> considered on the House floor next week. The amendment would prohibit
> the Justice Department from spending taxpayer money to arrest medical
> marijuana patients in the 12 states where medical marijuana is legal."
> 
> Please call now: (202) 224-3121
> 
> Then, please follow up by using MPP's easy online legislative system
> (see mpp.org) to e-mail your member of Congress. Calling and e-mailing
> take only one minute each.
> 
> The House of Representatives has voted on this amendment the last four
> consecutive summers, but  since last Novembers midterm elections
> provided the most favorable conditions for passing federal medical
> marijuana legislation since MPP was founded 12 years ago  this year the
> amendment has the best chance it has ever had of passing.
> 
> If you agree that sick and suffering patients should not have to live in
> fear of armed federal agents breaking down their doors, this is your
> chance to do something about it. Please call your member of Congress now.
> 
> Please.

Why not?

Do you Hate Our Freedom, or something? ;->

You know, one of the reasons the Lunatic Religious Right has made such
headway in politics over the past thirty years, is their authoritarian
structure. When the Pastor or the Phone Tree Lady calls a rabid
Evangelical and asks him/her to jump, the proper answer is "How High, O
Representative of The Living Lord? Thy requests are the *LORD's*
requests!! Thy every brainfart and assburr is the Word of the Holy
Spirit!!" (I'm really not exaggerating much.)

If these folks don't do what the pastor suggests, it eats at them and
"convicts them in the spirit", until they either do it, or burst into
tears of holy repentance at the next church service (which is always
sometime within the next 48 hours, BTW.)

But, of course, real lovers of freedom don't roll like that.

Which is why I'm reduced to abject begging.

Manipulation doesn't work with Libertarians and Progressives, so I'm
just going to *ask* you guys, outright, and remind you how important
this is. Even if you don't partake, yourself, think of the nation's
precious children, the *future* children, who may someday want to

herbs known to man, without having their doors busted down, their
property seized, their bank accounts emptied (if not outright -- which
happens, BTW -- then by interminable expensive legal fees while they

as "terrorists" or "predators on the community".

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: 7-19-07: Tonight in SOMA & stuff 

Man.... Thursday nights fuckin' suck man... I mean.. I Love Thursday night
& all, but man... there's sooo much to do & shit like Hello 2Day... i'm
sooooooooooooooooooo damn confuzed w/ all the yummy goin' on!!!  BUt ya

Anywaze.. here's the haps tonight.. see you hopefully @ one of these
parties or maybe both :)
------------------------------------
As many of you know, Simon had to cancel the rest of his tour back in
April due to his Father passing away unexpectedly... Come show your love
and respect as he will be returning to make up the dates that were
cancelled.. This will be his first time in SF and after what he just went
thru everyone better come represent SF and show him why we are a staple in
US DNB....

SIMON BASSLINE SMITH


Simon was given the name Bassline after destroying the majority of the
speakers at the parties at which he played.

In the early 1990s Simon Bassline Smith was at the forefront, playing
for some of the biggest dance organizations in the country such as: -
Perception, Methology, Rain Dance, Dance 91 and World Dance.

As the underground rave scene progressed in the early 1990s Simon
Bassline Smith was at the forefront, playing for some of the biggest
dance organizations in the country along side such house hold names like
Grooverider, Fabio, Mickey Finn and Jumping Jack Frost.
Simon was spearheading the new musical form (Jungle) now known as Drum &
Bass.

Simon quickly set up his own label, called Absolute 2, which at the time,
was one of the only Drum & Bass labels in the world. He signed Doc Scott,
Nookie and Ray Keith and released their debut productions. With the
success of Absolute 2, under his belt Simon began his career as a
producer. He was an instant success with anthems such as:- Music and Life,
Jungle, Mine, Distinction,Palomino and Midnight which can still be heard
in sets across the globe today.

His musical style was, to say the least, ahead of its time.

Over the years Bassline Smith along with his partner Drumsound have
released tunes on their own labels Technique Recordings / Worldwide Audio
Recordings, the mighty Grooveriders Prototype with the 2004 number one
club smash  Odyssey, Renegade Hardware, V Recordings, Formation, Urban
Takeover, Grid, Flex, CIA. Future projects include Bukems Good Looking
Records and Fabios Creative Source showcasing a formidable mix and blend
of all styles of cutting edge Drum and Bass.

Simon has gone from strength to strength utilizing his knowledge to build
an imprint of global proportions. His success has spread the Technique
sound over every continent the world. Technique recordings as the label
has moved from respected underground drum and bass label to one of the
leading labels in the industry.

Bassline Smiths heavyweight DJ style is a full on assault of cutting edge
Drum & Bass set to smash up the dancefloors.

With local support from the Crunkpression crew!


Located @ The Cellar 685 Sutter St. @ Taylor. 21 & Up $ 5 all night...
-------------------------------
& the next event
-------------------------------------

SUPPORT! SUPPORT! SUPPORT!

Come be yourself, bring your friends and be treasured! xoxo

(at) gmail (dot) com.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Did You Call?


This language is totally disgusting.  Found it difficult to get to the 
bottom, being an insult to my intelligence, totally pointless, lacking any 
reference material, utterly polarizing, etc.  It sounds like it was 
written by Bill and Ted behind the Circle K.  That type of grandstanding 
shit is why partisan politics are so fucking bad.  Don't fuel the fire by 
making it *us and them*.  Plenty of supporters of compassionate use are 
christian, republican, conservative democrat, etc... and anybody who cares 
about people at some of the most diffiuclt periods in life can be 
convinced.  Make it a one issue issue without namecalling and all that 
crap.  All it takes for someone to support medicinal marijuana laws is 
realizing that for some people it is the absolutely best medicine for 
symptoms/apetite/etc, that Marinol is *not* the same as having access to 
actual pot (especially for anti-nausea), that it's adverse health effects 
have been grossly distorted, and these dispensaries require a prescription 
so the "kids" are protected.

http://www.google.com/search?q=Hinchey+Amendment+2007

>From that link you should be able to find background, past voting history 
on the amendment, etc.

Basically, this strategy is *not* the best means by which to do this, as 
it merely bars fed funds from being used to act against medicinal 
dispensaries.  As such, it is a "rider" on the budget, can easily be 
reversed year to year, does not serve as precedent, can be easily 
circumvented through weird non-fiscal appropriation of resources, and is 
somewhat annoying because I don't think shit like this belongs there.

But it's the best we have on the table for now so I'll be placing my 
little phone call.

andyw - mutorsoundsystem - saturn5.com/andy
/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\_________________

-&e->this is. Even if you don't partake, yourself, think of the nation's
-&e->precious children, the *future* children, who may someday want to
-&e->self-medicate with one of the oldest, safest, most effective medicinal
-&e->herbs known to man, without having their doors busted down, their
-&e->property seized, their bank accounts emptied (if not outright -- which
-&e->happens, BTW -- then by interminable expensive legal fees while they
-&e->fight for their freedom) and their faces on the evening news, described
-&e->as "terrorists" or "predators on the community".

-&e->

-&e->> you know who is of voting age.)

-&e->> Amendment to the Justice spending bill.
-&e->>

-&e->> ESSENCE?.

-&e->> him or her to vote in favor of the medical marijuana amendment that the
-&e->> U.S. House of Representatives will be voting on THIS week?
-&e->> 
-&e->> It's easy: Just call the Capitol switchboard operator at (202) 224-3121.
-&e->> Give the operator your zip code and ask to be connected to your U.S.
-&e->> House member; you don't even need to know your congressperson?s name to
-&e->> do this.
-&e->> 
-&e->> When the receptionist for the congressperson ? not the Capitol
-&e->> switchboard operator ? answers, say something like: "Hi, this is [name].
-&e->> I live in [city], and I'm calling to ask that my representative vote for
-&e->> Rep. Maurice Hinchey's [HIN-chee's] medical marijuana amendment to the
-&e->> Justice Department's spending bill, which I understand will be
-&e->> considered on the House floor next week. The amendment would prohibit
-&e->> the Justice Department from spending taxpayer money to arrest medical
-&e->> marijuana patients in the 12 states where medical marijuana is legal."
-&e->> 
-&e->> Please call now: (202) 224-3121
-&e->> 
-&e->> Then, please follow up by using MPP's easy online legislative system
-&e->> (see mpp.org) to e-mail your member of Congress. Calling and e-mailing
-&e->> take only one minute each.
-&e->> 
-&e->> The House of Representatives has voted on this amendment the last four
-&e->> consecutive summers, but ? since last November?s midterm elections
-&e->> provided the most favorable conditions for passing federal medical
-&e->> marijuana legislation since MPP was founded 12 years ago ? this year the
-&e->> amendment has the best chance it has ever had of passing.
-&e->> 
-&e->> If you agree that sick and suffering patients should not have to live in
-&e->> fear of armed federal agents breaking down their doors, this is your
-&e->> chance to do something about it. Please call your member of Congress now.

Subject: [sfraves] Memory Lane

So, in trying to rebuilt a broke system, oof missing fonts, I was doing 
a bit of hardware manipulation.

FYI- You can hook an internal ZIP drive to an External IDE drive 
interface and it will work perfectly.  In fact, VERY fast. 

So, in going through some old zip looking for some obscure font, and 
found disks with my 90's MP3s.  Specifically, the Thunderdome series.

Memories...  omg.

So, in digging around to post teh track listing, I found this:

http://www.mybittorrent.com/info/240946/

Enjoy Gerriravers.  We may have traded out O2 for N2O we we still like 
the old classics.  ;)

On 7/19/07, Osby Oi Oi Jamz <osby@viberation.com> wrote:
>
> Man.... Thursday nights fuckin' suck man... I mean.. I Love Thursday nigh=
t
> & all, but man... there's sooo much to do & shit like Hello 2Day... i'm
> sooooooooooooooooooo damn confuzed w/ all the yummy goin' on!!!  BUt ya
> know... that just makes a scene stronger, right???
> (LoL.. Sorry for my thinking/ typing outloud)
>
> Anywaze.. here's the haps tonight.. see you hopefully @ one of these
> parties or maybe both :)
> ------------------------------------
> As many of you know, Simon had to cancel the rest of his tour back in
> April due to his Father passing away unexpectedly... Come show your love
> and respect as he will be returning to make up the dates that were
> cancelled.. This will be his first time in SF and after what he just went
> thru everyone better come represent SF and show him why we are a staple i=
n
> US DNB....
>
> SIMON BASSLINE SMITH
>
>
> Simon was given the name 'Bassline' after destroying the majority of the
> speakers at the parties at which he played.
>
> In the early 1990's Simon 'Bassline' Smith was at the forefront, playing
> for some of the biggest dance organizations in the country such as: -
> Perception, Methology, Rain Dance, Dance '91 and World Dance.
>
> As the underground rave scene progressed in the early 1990's Simon
> 'Bassline' Smith was at the forefront, playing for some of the biggest
> dance organizations in the country along side such house hold names like
> Grooverider, Fabio, Mickey Finn and Jumping' Jack Frost.
> Simon was spearheading the new musical form (Jungle) now known as Drum &
> Bass.
>
> Simon quickly set up his own label, called Absolute 2, which at the time,
> was one of the only Drum & Bass labels in the world. He signed Doc Scott,
> Nookie and Ray Keith and released their debut productions. With the
> success of Absolute 2, under his belt Simon began his career as a
> producer. He was an instant success with anthems such as:- Music and Life=
,
> Jungle, Mine, Distinction,Palomino and Midnight which can still be heard
> in sets across the globe today.
>
> His musical style was, to say the least, ahead of its time.
>
> Over the years Bassline Smith along with his partner Drumsound have
> released tunes on their own labels Technique Recordings / Worldwide Audio
> Recordings, the mighty Grooverider's Prototype with the 2004 number one
> club smash ' Odyssey', Renegade Hardware, V Recordings, Formation, Urban
> Takeover, Grid, Flex, CIA. Future projects include Bukem's Good Looking
> Records and Fabio's Creative Source showcasing a formidable mix and blend
> of all styles of cutting edge Drum and Bass.
>
> Simon has gone from strength to strength utilizing his knowledge to build
> an imprint of global proportions. His success has spread the Technique
> sound over every continent the world. Technique recordings as the label
> has moved from respected underground drum and bass label to one of the
> leading labels in the industry.
>
> Bassline Smith's heavyweight DJ style is a full on assault of cutting edg=
e
> Drum & Bass set to smash up the dancefloors.
>
> With local support from the Crunkpression crew!
>
>
> Located @ The Cellar 685 Sutter St. @ Taylor. 21 & Up $ 5 all night...
> -------------------------------
> & the next event
> -------------------------------------
> a Message from Audio Angel:
> Hello My Lovelies!
>
> Check out a new monthly (every 3rd Thursday) I'm putting together. Be
> prepared for all styles! And yes, this month, there will be d-n-b! If you
> can come to both here and Compression/El Rincon, definitely DO IT!
> SUPPORT! SUPPORT! SUPPORT!
>
> THURSDAY JULY 19, 2007
> Audio Angel Presents: TREASURE
> :: in the light of love, everything shines! ::
>
> downtempo/electro from JONESY (Cat Club)
>

> > Man.... Thursday nights fuckin' suck man... I mean.. I Love Thursday
> > night

> >
> > Anywaze.. here's the haps tonight.. see you hopefully @ one of these
> > parties or maybe both :)
> > ------------------------------------
> > As many of you know, Simon had to cancel the rest of his tour back in
> > April due to his Father passing away unexpectedly... Come show your lov=
e
> > and respect as he will be returning to make up the dates that were
> > cancelled.. This will be his first time in SF and after what he just
> > went
> > thru everyone better come represent SF and show him why we are a staple
> > in
> > US DNB....
> >
> > SIMON BASSLINE SMITH
> >
> >
> > Simon was given the name 'Bassline' after destroying the majority of th=
e
> >
> > speakers at the parties at which he played.
> >
> > In the early 1990's Simon 'Bassline' Smith was at the forefront, playin=
g
> > for some of the biggest dance organizations in the country such as: -
> > Perception, Methology, Rain Dance, Dance '91 and World Dance.
> >
> > As the underground rave scene progressed in the early 1990's Simon
> > 'Bassline' Smith was at the forefront, playing for some of the biggest
> > dance organizations in the country along side such house hold names lik=
e
> >
> > Grooverider, Fabio, Mickey Finn and Jumping' Jack Frost.
> > Simon was spearheading the new musical form (Jungle) now known as Drum =
&
> > Bass.
> >
> > Simon quickly set up his own label, called Absolute 2, which at the
> > time,
> > was one of the only Drum & Bass labels in the world. He signed Doc
> > Scott,
> > Nookie and Ray Keith and released their debut productions. With the
> > success of Absolute 2, under his belt Simon began his career as a
> > producer. He was an instant success with anthems such as:- Music and
> > Life,
> > Jungle, Mine, Distinction,Palomino and Midnight which can still be hear=
d
> > in sets across the globe today.
> >
> > His musical style was, to say the least, ahead of its time.
> >
> > Over the years Bassline Smith along with his partner Drumsound have
> > released tunes on their own labels Technique Recordings / Worldwide
> > Audio
> > Recordings, the mighty Grooverider's Prototype with the 2004 number one
> > club smash ' Odyssey', Renegade Hardware, V Recordings, Formation, Urba=
n
> > Takeover, Grid, Flex, CIA. Future projects include Bukem's Good Looking
> > Records and Fabio's Creative Source showcasing a formidable mix and
> > blend
> > of all styles of cutting edge Drum and Bass.
> >
> > Simon has gone from strength to strength utilizing his knowledge to
> > build
> > an imprint of global proportions. His success has spread the Technique
> > sound over every continent the world. Technique recordings as the label
> > has moved from respected underground drum and bass label to one of the
> > leading labels in the industry.
> >
> > Bassline Smith's heavyweight DJ style is a full on assault of cutting
> > edge
> > Drum & Bass set to smash up the dancefloors.
> >
> > With local support from the Crunkpression crew!
> >
> >
> > Located @ The Cellar 685 Sutter St. @ Taylor. 21 & Up $ 5 all night...
> > -------------------------------
> > & the next event
> > -------------------------------------

> > Hello My Lovelies!
> >

> > prepared for all styles! And yes, this month, there will be d-n-b! If
> > you
> > can come to both here and Compression/El Rincon, definitely DO IT!
> > SUPPORT! SUPPORT! SUPPORT!

Just a few comments about this quote, I found it on a video that I =20
downloaded that talks about the strength of the AIPAC lobby in =20
Washington.  I found the video interesting, and it said part 2 was =20
coming, but then it also had the cover of one of David Duke's books in =20
there, too, so I'm puzzled who made it, and I can't say I'm =20
particularly fond of David Duke.  Anyway, Tony Judt man is Jewish, he =20
says so in the video.  I think it's food for thought, that's all.

--

It wasn't always like this.  It started back in the 70's.  With the
rise of identity politics in this country, where it became
fashionable, and eventually politically and economically normal for
people to think of themselves as Black Americans, Italian Americans,
Irish Americans ... no one says 'I'm a Jewish American'.

Someone says  'I'm a Jewish American', it has a slightly uncomfortable =20
air to it. But they have to have an identity, the sense of the need to =20
have the same kind of cultural identity as Italian Americans or Black =20
Americans, or Hispanic Americans have, has created in the American =20
Jewish Community two external identification tags:  one is Israel, the =20
other is Auschwitz.

So to speak one in space and one in time, to be Jewish is to be moved =20
by the Holocaust, and to identify with Israel, even if you have no =20
personal connection to the Holocaust and you've never been to Israel, =20
which is true for most of them.  The result is that they are =20
extrodinarily sensitive both politically and personally - it's not an =20
invented thing, people feel this - to any suggestion
that there is criticism of Israel, or forgetting of the Holocaust, =20
because it touches the core identity of American Jews.

- Tony Judt, Historian

Subject: [sfraves] [BSP] FRI :: Adjunct-Audio's Apendics.Shuffle + Konstantin Gabbro [$5 show]

This Friday, Filter resident Apendics.Shuffle plus Konstantin Gabbro
of LA's premier experimental techno label Adjunct-Audio showcase their
unique brand of hed-funked beats.

Friday, July 27, 2007
9:00 PM - 2:00 AM

Anu
43 Sixth St - S.F.
Cover: $5

Opening DJ sets from Filter femmes Saya + Solekandi

About this show:

One of the early West Coast evangelists of minimal techno, Konstantin
Gabbro is the founder of Seattle's homegrown Orac Records, a label
that launched Bruno Pronsato and Kenneth James Gibson's
[a]pendics.shuffle moniker into the realm of the international
techorati.

In 2003 Konstantin moved down the Pacific Coast to Los Angeles where
he and Gibson (KJG) launched another label =96 Adjunct - a forward
thinking techno outlet that releases critically acclaimed collectibles
from names such as John Tejada, Pheek and newcomer Altiply.

A combination of Gabbro's well-schooled knowledge of deconstructed,
experimental techno with Gibson's mojo-laden epic Live PA sets goes
well beyond their description of "funky computer music".

More information:

www.adjunct-audio.com
www.myspace.com/filtersf
http://www.anu-bar.com
www.freqbox.net

Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr: Forum/Message Board Software Recommendations

------=_Part_178117_571248.1185231128667
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

If you are looking for something free, check out phpBB @ www.phpbb.com. The
problem with phpBB, however, is that security holes often are found, and the
boards can be tampered with... just make sure to keep them updated
frequently if you choose to use phpbb.  Two other message board systems that
I really like are Invision power boards(http://www.invisionpower.com) and
vBulletin (www.vbulletin.com).  There is also a free version of invision
power board (IPB) available at
www.invisionfree.com<http://invisionfree.com/>.
The free version has virtually the same features as the paid version, with
some limitations. You will have to take a look @ the features on each
individual website to choose which one would best fit the purpose of your
message board.  Hope this helps!

Jeff

On 7/23/07, CHUCK G <chuckg_421@yahoo.com> wrote:

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Business 2.0: Burning Man Grows Up

I'll just post this with no comment as I am sure others will comment fully.=
 =0A=0APeace,=0A=0APeter=0A=0ABurning Man grows up=0AAmerica's biggest coun=
terculture jamboree is also a $10 million business. Now, Business 2.0 repor=
ts, it's trying to leverage its brand -- and save the planet -- by (gasp!) =
inviting corporate participants.=0A=0ABy Chris Taylor, Business 2.0 Magazin=
e senior editor=0AJuly 1 2007: 2:51 PM EDT=0A=0A(Business 2.0 Magazine) -- =
Marian Goodell, 44, is a no-nonsense blond with a voice that sounds like it=
's barking orders out of a walkie-talkie. She's a veteran of seven industri=
es, including law, advertising, software development, and Department of Def=
ense contract work. =0AToday she's seated at a large, polished conference t=
able with an antique gavel, taking inventory of her current endeavor. "We r=
ent buildings, trucks, light towers, cranes, boom lifts, Bobcats, forklifts=
," she says. "We've got four properties in Nevada, totaling more than 200 a=
cres. And three full-time people in accounting managing a budget of $10 mil=
lion." =0A=0AIt sounds like a modestly successful construction company in L=
as Vegas or Reno. But then you look out the door and see a psychedelic cate=
rpillar perched atop a giant mushroom. Where Good-ell works is, in fact, th=
e global headquarters of Burning Man. Yes, that Burning Man, America's prem=
ier counterculture festival, the one that makes headlines every Labor Day. =
=0A=0ABut while most of us were looking at the pictures of people in body p=
aint, Burning Man did something it wasn't supposed to do. It grew up. It be=
came a sustainable business. How it did that says a lot about both the Sili=
con Valley culture that helped spawn it and where that culture is heading. =
=0ABurning Man started as a half-baked idea in the fevered mind of Goodell'=
s boss, Larry Harvey. A reclusive man who favors long pauses between his gu=
rulike pronouncements, he's a legend among burners, as Burning Man devotees=
 call themselves. =0A=0AIn 1986, Harvey and his friend Jerry James built a =
giant wood man on San Francisco's Baker Beach, and then set it on fire. The=
 gathering drew such interesting people that Harvey has repeated it every y=
ear since. When the event outgrew Baker Beach, he moved the whole thing to =
Nevada's Black Rock Desert, the largest stretch of flatland in the United S=
tates, for a weeklong jamboree. =0A=0AHarvey, however, is almost never in t=
he office. "Larry's no Steve Jobs," Goodell says. "He's not running the bus=
iness. He didn't even have a checking account until a couple of years ago."=
 In his absence, Goodell manages the money, the business side, the construc=
tion, the communications. Marian Goodell - known to burners as Maid Marian =
- is Burning Man's resident adult. Think of her as its CEO. =0A=0AThis is t=
he year Burning Man comes of age. It's 21 years old as a festival and 11 ye=
ars old as a limited liability company now called Black Rock City LLC. In t=
hat time it has learned more lessons than many companies three times its ag=
e. It has beaten threats of shutdown from government officials, both local =
and national, coped with two fatal accidents, and suffered weeklong "whiteo=
ut" dust storms. It has staved off bankruptcy three times. And it has found=
 the magic formula for creating a temporary city of 40,000 souls from scrat=
ch and running the whole thing - from security to sanitation - almost entir=
ely with volunteer labor. =0A=0ABut no challenge has been greater than deal=
ing with the complaints from veteran burners - the hypernetworked old-timer=
s at the core of the community - that Burning Man has grown too big and has=
 lost touch with its anticommercial roots. That it is too much like, well, =
a business. =0A=0AThe event is supposed to run on what participants call a =
"gift economy." They have no truck with U.S. currency once inside the event=
's trash fence. Even bartering is frowned upon. The fact that the organizat=
ion sells coffee and ice is controversial enough. Imagine the reaction, the=
n, when Burning Man makes the riskiest business move in its history: It's g=
oing to allow companies to exhibit products at the 2007 event. =0A=0AEach B=
urning Man has a different theme, chosen by Harvey. This year's theme is "T=
he Green Man." Burning Man, an extravaganza characterized by the consumptio=
n of huge quantities of fossil fuel, has discovered environmentalism. It is=
 attempting to offset the 28,000 tons of carbon it estimates the event gene=
rates (counting all those flights and long drives for its far-flung attende=
es), and the organization is belatedly switching to biodiesel generators to=
 provide most of the event's electricity. =0AMost controversially, the orga=
nization wants to bring as many green-energy companies as possible into wha=
t Harvey calls a world's fair of clean tech. Google (Charts, Fortune 500) i=
s going to help produce an online 3-D search service called Burning Man Ear=
th. =0A=0AA venture capitalist is bringing a vast solar-power array. Four w=
ind-power companies will be placing turbines around the Man. PR maven Melod=
y Haller of the Antenna Group will be bringing a campful of her clean-tech =
CEOs. "We're inviting the Greeks into the heart of Troy," says Tom Price, B=
urning Man's new environmental director. "Burning Man may have to destroy i=
tself to save the planet." =0A=0ADestroy itself? Well, possibly. Those 40,0=
00 attendees are Burning Man's only tangible asset. Without their entry fee=
s - $250 in January, $400 at the gate in August - there's no $10 million bu=
dget. "It's a good business," says one venture capitalist who has examined =
the company's financial record, "but it's even more seasonal than a ski res=
ort." Other than those tickets, the organization has no real source of reve=
nue. The coffee just about pays for itself - it's more an excuse for newcom=
ers to mingle than a vending enterprise - while the proceeds from the sales=
 of ice are donated to charity. =0A=0AIn other words, as Harvey says, Disne=
yland this ain't: "Theirs is a spectacle entirely for consumption; ours is =
based on interaction and communal effort. It's Disneyland turned inside out=
." =0A=0ANevertheless, the Burning Man community is an unusually smart, wel=
l-knit, and well-heeled social network. Larry Page and Sergey Brin of Googl=
e are regular attendees; they chose Eric Schmidt as their CEO because he wa=
s the only candidate for the job who had been a burner. =0A=0ASo many VCs s=
how up that Silicon Valley entrepreneurs like to joke that you can't get an=
y funding during the week of Burning Man. Celebrities like Robin Williams, =
Sting, and Joan Baez often arrive incognito. Thousands of lesser-known arti=
sts spend up to 10 times the ticket price, mostly drawn from their own pock=
ets, to create the spectacles at the center of the experience: the Burning =
Man art, in all its neon-lit, fire-spewing glory. =0A=0AYou really have to =
want to be there to truck yourself and your gallons of drinking water in an=
d out of the desert, an environment so extreme that dehydration and other s=
erious bodily harm are real possibilities. As it says in large letters on t=
heir tickets, attendees voluntarily assume the risk of death. (Indeed, sinc=
e 1996, two have died in art-car accidents.) =0A=0ABut not only do people s=
till come, they create content and provide their own services with an enthu=
siasm that puts even Wikipedia to shame. According to Black Rock City's ann=
ual census, 80 percent of attendees volunteer at some point during the even=
t. Burning Man, it seems, was Web 2.0 before that label existed. =0ABurner =
volunteers solve their own disputes (through the Black Rock Rangers) and li=
ght their own gas lamps (through the Lamplighters). A few hundred even stay=
 to clean up the desert for at least a month after the event. "Our budget i=
s in the millions," Harvey says, "but if you include everything people give=
 to the city, it's three times what we invest." =0A=0AIt's just as well tha=
t there's all this goodwill and free labor. Black Rock City has already suf=
fered three times from cost overruns that threatened to bury it in debt, an=
d not just to pay for all those rented portable toilets. The federal Bureau=
 of Land Management charges $4 per person per day for use of the desert. Ne=
vada's Washoe County makes the organization cover the cost of all the extra=
 police it insists on bringing to the event. =0A=0AThose charges alone add =
up to roughly $800,000. This year the Denver office of the BLM is threateni=
ng to add on a 19 percent fee, or $120,000, for administrative costs. Burni=
ng Man is currently protesting this new surcharge in Washington. (Since it =
is the largest single customer on federal land, the organization usually ge=
ts a sympathetic hearing in the halls of power - especially with San Franci=
sco's Nancy Pelosi and Nevada's Harry Reid.) =0A=0AYou can think of the eco=
nomics of Burning Man as a delicate ecosystem in itself. Goodell won't reve=
al exactly how much profit the event clears, only that most of the money is=
 spent on donations to artists, and the remainder has been "comfortably abo=
ve $50,000" since 2005. If the corporate experiment triggers a drop in atte=
ndance, Burning Man could find itself in debt for a fourth, and perhaps fin=
al, time. =0A=0AThis community is a dream for anyone looking at demographic=
s," Goodell says. "We have kids who work in coffee shops and we have billio=
naires. To ignore the value of our brand, the buying power it has, is silly=
. But it's a ritual for these people, which is why it's going to be hard fo=
r them seeing businesses out there." Burning Man's customers keep coming ba=
ck to Black Rock precisely because it's so far outside the scope of the cor=
porate culture - and its incessant marketing - that most of them live with =
the other 51 weeks of the year. =0A=0ASo the organization decided that the =
companies that come this summer will have to play by Burning Man's rules. T=
he first letter inviting corporate participants was pulled off the website =
after only a few days; Harvey says it made the event sound too much like a =
trade fair. The revision stated explicitly that no marketing whatsoever wou=
ld be allowed at the event. =0A=0AClean-tech companies can exhibit their te=
chnologies, but their products can't display a logo. No marketing material =
will be allowed. Company reps can't even demonstrate their wares in the pav=
ilion; they have to turn them over to Burning Man, which will demonstrate t=
he technologies in whatever artistic form it chooses. =0AGiven these restri=
ctions, why would a company want to come? For one thing, there's evidence t=
hat simply bringing your product to Burning Man and letting it speak for it=
self can pay rich rewards. Goodell cites the example of Current TV, the San=
 Francisco video content company that came to the event in 2006 and did a s=
how every day but didn't display its brand. The response, both at Burning M=
an and from viewers afterward, was overwhelmingly positive. =0A=0A"Branding=
's important, "Goodell says," but there's a middle ground between having it=
 all over the place and just knowing that it's Current TV and feeling good =
about the way they're treating you. That's a very interesting potential for=
 companies that see a value in Burning Man culture." =0A=0APlenty of compan=
ies do, it seems, and at the front of the line this year is Google. Its eng=
ineers are building software for unbranded kiosks at the pavilion where par=
ticipants can zoom in to a virtual version of Burning Man. Just click on a =
given technology or art project and Google will take you directly to its we=
bsite.=0A"A lot of Google people come to the event, and the reason is that =
their corporate culture has similarities to ours," Harvey says. "They do wh=
at they're interested in. They have fun and worry about monetizing it later=
." =0A=0AAfter the invitations went out in May, Burning Man started getting=
 inquiries from about three corporations a day. Some executives were slow t=
o understand exactly what kind of event they were dealing with. At an early=
 meeting, one CEO was surprised to learn that there's no cell-phone service=
 in the desert. (The organization, however, does supply Wi-Fi.) But most ar=
e optimistic. "I'm curious to see what happens at the intersection of art a=
nd technology," says B.J. Stanbery, CEO of Austin-based Heliovolt, a maker =
of thin-film photovoltaic solar cells. =0A=0AThen there's Matt Cheney, CEO =
of MMA Renewable Ventures, which funds clean technologies around the globe =
and offered to provide Black Rock City with enough solar cells - 270 kilowa=
tts' worth - to light the Man and power the pavilion. After the event, thos=
e solar panels will be installed at no cost - remember that free Burning Ma=
n labor? - in the nearby town of Gerlach. =0A=0ACheney will be getting very=
 generous rebates from the state of Nevada. Not enough to cover the $1.5 mi=
llion tab, he says, but the good publicity will more than make up the diffe=
rence. "There's a tremendous alignment here," Cheney says. Enough, he adds,=
 to do it again in future years. =0A=0AStill, some attendees fear that the =
arrival of corporations - even without business cards - is the death knell =
for Burning Man. "I'm sure the corporations are thinking, OK, this year tho=
se are the terms," says one prominent Burning Man artist involved in buildi=
ng the Man itself. "But now the door's open. In the end, the money wins." =
=0AOther erstwhile naysayers, however, have embraced the green theme. Jim M=
ason and Chicken John are two artists who led a rebellion against what they=
 saw as Burning Man's arrogant arts patronage at the event two years ago. N=
ow both are building art cars that use gasification technology - meaning th=
ey can turn trash into hydrogen gas, which they run on. Chicken John's car =
was a showcase exhibit at Cleantech 2007, an industry conference held in Sa=
n Jose in May. =0A=0AAnd what of Burning Man itself? Harvey sees the event =
continuing for another decade or so, at which point spinoffs - the so-calle=
d regional burns - can take over. By then, he says, there'll no longer be a=
 need for a single, central Burning Man organization. But Goodell demurs. "=
The business model can totally function without Larry Harvey," she says. "A=
s long as the LLC exists, the event exists." As if to underscore her point,=
 the enigmatic sign above the door to her conference room reads, "Larry Har=
vey does not exist." =0A=0AChris Taylor is a senior editor at Business 2.0 =
and a seven-time burner. He blogs at business2.com/futureboy=0A=0Ahttp://mo=
ney.cnn.com/magazines/business2/business2_archive/2007/07/01/100117064/inde=
x.htm

waaaayyy too seriously.  If you don't like burning man, just don't go.  There

On Tue, Jul 24, 2007 at 07:49:39AM -0700, dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
> I'll just post this with no comment as I am sure others will comment fully. 
> 
> Peace,
> 
> Peter
> 
> Burning Man grows up
> America's biggest counterculture jamboree is also a $10 million business. Now, Business 2.0 reports, it's trying to leverage its brand -- and save the planet -- by (gasp!) inviting corporate participants.
> 
> By Chris Taylor, Business 2.0 Magazine senior editor
> July 1 2007: 2:51 PM EDT
> 
> (Business 2.0 Magazine) -- Marian Goodell, 44, is a no-nonsense blond with a voice that sounds like it's barking orders out of a walkie-talkie. She's a veteran of seven industries, including law, advertising, software development, and Department of Defense contract work. 
> Today she's seated at a large, polished conference table with an antique gavel, taking inventory of her current endeavor. "We rent buildings, trucks, light towers, cranes, boom lifts, Bobcats, forklifts," she says. "We've got four properties in Nevada, totaling more than 200 acres. And three full-time people in accounting managing a budget of $10 million." 
> 
> It sounds like a modestly successful construction company in Las Vegas or Reno. But then you look out the door and see a psychedelic caterpillar perched atop a giant mushroom. Where Good-ell works is, in fact, the global headquarters of Burning Man. Yes, that Burning Man, America's premier counterculture festival, the one that makes headlines every Labor Day. 
> 
> But while most of us were looking at the pictures of people in body paint, Burning Man did something it wasn't supposed to do. It grew up. It became a sustainable business. How it did that says a lot about both the Silicon Valley culture that helped spawn it and where that culture is heading. 
> Burning Man started as a half-baked idea in the fevered mind of Goodell's boss, Larry Harvey. A reclusive man who favors long pauses between his gurulike pronouncements, he's a legend among burners, as Burning Man devotees call themselves. 
> 
> In 1986, Harvey and his friend Jerry James built a giant wood man on San Francisco's Baker Beach, and then set it on fire. The gathering drew such interesting people that Harvey has repeated it every year since. When the event outgrew Baker Beach, he moved the whole thing to Nevada's Black Rock Desert, the largest stretch of flatland in the United States, for a weeklong jamboree. 
> 
> Harvey, however, is almost never in the office. "Larry's no Steve Jobs," Goodell says. "He's not running the business. He didn't even have a checking account until a couple of years ago." In his absence, Goodell manages the money, the business side, the construction, the communications. Marian Goodell - known to burners as Maid Marian - is Burning Man's resident adult. Think of her as its CEO. 
> 
> This is the year Burning Man comes of age. It's 21 years old as a festival and 11 years old as a limited liability company now called Black Rock City LLC. In that time it has learned more lessons than many companies three times its age. It has beaten threats of shutdown from government officials, both local and national, coped with two fatal accidents, and suffered weeklong "whiteout" dust storms. It has staved off bankruptcy three times. And it has found the magic formula for creating a temporary city of 40,000 souls from scratch and running the whole thing - from security to sanitation - almost entirely with volunteer labor. 
> 
> But no challenge has been greater than dealing with the complaints from veteran burners - the hypernetworked old-timers at the core of the community - that Burning Man has grown too big and has lost touch with its anticommercial roots. That it is too much like, well, a business. 
> 
> The event is supposed to run on what participants call a "gift economy." They have no truck with U.S. currency once inside the event's trash fence. Even bartering is frowned upon. The fact that the organization sells coffee and ice is controversial enough. Imagine the reaction, then, when Burning Man makes the riskiest business move in its history: It's going to allow companies to exhibit products at the 2007 event. 
> 
> Each Burning Man has a different theme, chosen by Harvey. This year's theme is "The Green Man." Burning Man, an extravaganza characterized by the consumption of huge quantities of fossil fuel, has discovered environmentalism. It is attempting to offset the 28,000 tons of carbon it estimates the event generates (counting all those flights and long drives for its far-flung attendees), and the organization is belatedly switching to biodiesel generators to provide most of the event's electricity. 
> Most controversially, the organization wants to bring as many green-energy companies as possible into what Harvey calls a world's fair of clean tech. Google (Charts, Fortune 500) is going to help produce an online 3-D search service called Burning Man Earth. 
> 
> A venture capitalist is bringing a vast solar-power array. Four wind-power companies will be placing turbines around the Man. PR maven Melody Haller of the Antenna Group will be bringing a campful of her clean-tech CEOs. "We're inviting the Greeks into the heart of Troy," says Tom Price, Burning Man's new environmental director. "Burning Man may have to destroy itself to save the planet." 
> 
> Destroy itself? Well, possibly. Those 40,000 attendees are Burning Man's only tangible asset. Without their entry fees - $250 in January, $400 at the gate in August - there's no $10 million budget. "It's a good business," says one venture capitalist who has examined the company's financial record, "but it's even more seasonal than a ski resort." Other than those tickets, the organization has no real source of revenue. The coffee just about pays for itself - it's more an excuse for newcomers to mingle than a vending enterprise - while the proceeds from the sales of ice are donated to charity. 
> 
> In other words, as Harvey says, Disneyland this ain't: "Theirs is a spectacle entirely for consumption; ours is based on interaction and communal effort. It's Disneyland turned inside out." 
> 
> Nevertheless, the Burning Man community is an unusually smart, well-knit, and well-heeled social network. Larry Page and Sergey Brin of Google are regular attendees; they chose Eric Schmidt as their CEO because he was the only candidate for the job who had been a burner. 
> 
> So many VCs show up that Silicon Valley entrepreneurs like to joke that you can't get any funding during the week of Burning Man. Celebrities like Robin Williams, Sting, and Joan Baez often arrive incognito. Thousands of lesser-known artists spend up to 10 times the ticket price, mostly drawn from their own pockets, to create the spectacles at the center of the experience: the Burning Man art, in all its neon-lit, fire-spewing glory. 
> 
> You really have to want to be there to truck yourself and your gallons of drinking water in and out of the desert, an environment so extreme that dehydration and other serious bodily harm are real possibilities. As it says in large letters on their tickets, attendees voluntarily assume the risk of death. (Indeed, since 1996, two have died in art-car accidents.) 
> 
> But not only do people still come, they create content and provide their own services with an enthusiasm that puts even Wikipedia to shame. According to Black Rock City's annual census, 80 percent of attendees volunteer at some point during the event. Burning Man, it seems, was Web 2.0 before that label existed. 
> Burner volunteers solve their own disputes (through the Black Rock Rangers) and light their own gas lamps (through the Lamplighters). A few hundred even stay to clean up the desert for at least a month after the event. "Our budget is in the millions," Harvey says, "but if you include everything people give to the city, it's three times what we invest." 
> 
> It's just as well that there's all this goodwill and free labor. Black Rock City has already suffered three times from cost overruns that threatened to bury it in debt, and not just to pay for all those rented portable toilets. The federal Bureau of Land Management charges $4 per person per day for use of the desert. Nevada's Washoe County makes the organization cover the cost of all the extra police it insists on bringing to the event. 
> 
> Those charges alone add up to roughly $800,000. This year the Denver office of the BLM is threatening to add on a 19 percent fee, or $120,000, for administrative costs. Burning Man is currently protesting this new surcharge in Washington. (Since it is the largest single customer on federal land, the organization usually gets a sympathetic hearing in the halls of power - especially with San Francisco's Nancy Pelosi and Nevada's Harry Reid.) 
> 
> You can think of the economics of Burning Man as a delicate ecosystem in itself. Goodell won't reveal exactly how much profit the event clears, only that most of the money is spent on donations to artists, and the remainder has been "comfortably above $50,000" since 2005. If the corporate experiment triggers a drop in attendance, Burning Man could find itself in debt for a fourth, and perhaps final, time. 
> 
> This community is a dream for anyone looking at demographics," Goodell says. "We have kids who work in coffee shops and we have billionaires. To ignore the value of our brand, the buying power it has, is silly. But it's a ritual for these people, which is why it's going to be hard for them seeing businesses out there." Burning Man's customers keep coming back to Black Rock precisely because it's so far outside the scope of the corporate culture - and its incessant marketing - that most of them live with the other 51 weeks of the year. 
> 
> So the organization decided that the companies that come this summer will have to play by Burning Man's rules. The first letter inviting corporate participants was pulled off the website after only a few days; Harvey says it made the event sound too much like a trade fair. The revision stated explicitly that no marketing whatsoever would be allowed at the event. 
> 
> Clean-tech companies can exhibit their technologies, but their products can't display a logo. No marketing material will be allowed. Company reps can't even demonstrate their wares in the pavilion; they have to turn them over to Burning Man, which will demonstrate the technologies in whatever artistic form it chooses. 
> Given these restrictions, why would a company want to come? For one thing, there's evidence that simply bringing your product to Burning Man and letting it speak for itself can pay rich rewards. Goodell cites the example of Current TV, the San Francisco video content company that came to the event in 2006 and did a show every day but didn't display its brand. The response, both at Burning Man and from viewers afterward, was overwhelmingly positive. 
> 
> "Branding's important, "Goodell says," but there's a middle ground between having it all over the place and just knowing that it's Current TV and feeling good about the way they're treating you. That's a very interesting potential for companies that see a value in Burning Man culture." 
> 
> Plenty of companies do, it seems, and at the front of the line this year is Google. Its engineers are building software for unbranded kiosks at the pavilion where participants can zoom in to a virtual version of Burning Man. Just click on a given technology or art project and Google will take you directly to its website.
> "A lot of Google people come to the event, and the reason is that their corporate culture has similarities to ours," Harvey says. "They do what they're interested in. They have fun and worry about monetizing it later." 
> 
> After the invitations went out in May, Burning Man started getting inquiries from about three corporations a day. Some executives were slow to understand exactly what kind of event they were dealing with. At an early meeting, one CEO was surprised to learn that there's no cell-phone service in the desert. (The organization, however, does supply Wi-Fi.) But most are optimistic. "I'm curious to see what happens at the intersection of art and technology," says B.J. Stanbery, CEO of Austin-based Heliovolt, a maker of thin-film photovoltaic solar cells. 
> 
> Then there's Matt Cheney, CEO of MMA Renewable Ventures, which funds clean technologies around the globe and offered to provide Black Rock City with enough solar cells - 270 kilowatts' worth - to light the Man and power the pavilion. After the event, those solar panels will be installed at no cost - remember that free Burning Man labor? - in the nearby town of Gerlach. 
> 
> Cheney will be getting very generous rebates from the state of Nevada. Not enough to cover the $1.5 million tab, he says, but the good publicity will more than make up the difference. "There's a tremendous alignment here," Cheney says. Enough, he adds, to do it again in future years. 
> 
> Still, some attendees fear that the arrival of corporations - even without business cards - is the death knell for Burning Man. "I'm sure the corporations are thinking, OK, this year those are the terms," says one prominent Burning Man artist involved in building the Man itself. "But now the door's open. In the end, the money wins." 
> Other erstwhile naysayers, however, have embraced the green theme. Jim Mason and Chicken John are two artists who led a rebellion against what they saw as Burning Man's arrogant arts patronage at the event two years ago. Now both are building art cars that use gasification technology - meaning they can turn trash into hydrogen gas, which they run on. Chicken John's car was a showcase exhibit at Cleantech 2007, an industry conference held in San Jose in May. 
> 
> And what of Burning Man itself? Harvey sees the event continuing for another decade or so, at which point spinoffs - the so-called regional burns - can take over. By then, he says, there'll no longer be a need for a single, central Burning Man organization. But Goodell demurs. "The business model can totally function without Larry Harvey," she says. "As long as the LLC exists, the event exists." As if to underscore her point, the enigmatic sign above the door to her conference room reads, "Larry Harvey does not exist." 
> 
> Chris Taylor is a senior editor at Business 2.0 and a seven-time burner. He blogs at business2.com/futureboy
> 
> http://money.cnn.com/magazines/business2/business2_archive/2007/07/01/100117064/index.htm
> 
> ---------------------------------------------------------------------
> To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
> For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Minimal sucks, glad Bone is coming to SF

Well, you're in good company. One stat tossed out by a promoter
recently claimed there are 800 fans of techno in the Bay Area whereas
there are only about 300 for minimal.

But one person's minimal is another person's microtrance is another's
electro and so it goes, with various meanings and associations
prescribed to each. This is obviously the problem with attempting to
utilize one terminology "minimal" to describe anything 4x4 with an
experimental flare.

Blame beatport...really. They tend to lump alot of the new,
experimental dance music into minimal when it's really sounds mostly
like ambiant, IDM, trance or electro...

A fun test of Beatport's shortcomings is to pick tracks from both
"techno" and "minimal" categories and ask a techno DJ which genre they
think it really is.

-SK

On 7/24/07, nico <nico@viberation.com> wrote:
> What can I say?  Minimal, micro-house, whatever the fuck these scensters call it, is pretty boring and un-danceable.  Maybe if I did a full 8th of mushrooms this genre be fun.
>
> Looking forward to some real techno.
>
> love always
>
> n i c o
>
>


-- 

www.myspace.com/filtersf

Date: Wed, 25 Jul 2007 18:43:40 -0700 (PDT)
From: "Osby Oi Oi Jamz" <osby@viberation.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] WR last weekend: Treasure, TELIC, & Robot Rave

OK.. sorry a lil late.. but i've been mad busy tryin' to catch up w. my
homework & well.. since i'm in a mondo writing block slump like right now
now... hopefully writing about my weekend will help my creative, noctunral
brain focus :)

By the way... 2 weeks Shelter @ The Top, I mean.. Underground SF.. the new
Jungle weeklie that took over Phuturo... so Dope!!  Like I mean.. I talk
to the owner & he said that it's bee a steady night... there been alota
people comiing & like yeah.. it was pretty ill... good time3s!!!  It was
like a 3rd packed, good music all night long.. yummy jungle... it was Dope
being' w/ my Jungle Familia again :)

So last Thursday i went to Pier 23 instead of Beer Cellar & ya know.. it
was really fun!!!  It was nice dancing on like this deck thingie over the
water & oooh.. the YUmmy Beats all night long!!!  Jonesy (sp) spun this
bad ass like she went from 2 Step, to breaks, to prog house, minimal
techno (sorry Nico), back to breaks... it was a really fun set!  Pam The
Funkstress was so Fuckin' Ill!!!  She played this old 90's hip hop set 7
oooh.. she juggled so sweet & she fucki'n scratched records w/ her
boobs!!!  Hello 2day!!  Kiro, My Hero, played this bad ass fuckin' Dope
Junlge set... like his 1st trafck was this Rock infused Jungle song...
like what's his name from the Phuturo crew plays alots rock/ jungle
ch00ns, but when Kiro dropped this.. So teh_yummeh!!!  It was A good small
crowd... alota Familia passed by & OOooh.. Yaaay... Kiro brought me home!!
 So Dope!!!  therre were several points during the night when I danced to
like hella tired!!!!

OK.. Saturday was Soooo FUN!!!  Woke up way mondo Hella fuckin' early from
barely even sleeping 'cause i didn't wanna walk to the bus stop & catch a
ride from the rents...  So i ended up havin a mini breakfast @ Jack in the
Box where I ran into my classmate from 2nd grade.. LoL.. so that was kinda
Dope!!! :)

B4 I went to Lake Elizabeth for the day party, i stopped over Unka's to
check on her :)   Love U Girl!!  Well.. it was 9AM & I dunno... by 1PM.. i
made it out to the TELIC day party & oooooooooh.. it was sooo Dope!!!  My
Gosh man... it was good to see that part of my Familia & spend the day
with them & eat all this yummy bbq food!!!  Like there was alota ummm..
Breaks, Jungle, Trance, deep house, & yes... Happy Hardcore there!!!  I'm
tellin' ya man.. Lake Elizabeth is getting fucki'n HUGE now!!!  I would
love to go there again this summer for something again!!!  Love it!  Oh
yeah.. i spent 2 hours workin' on my robot costume there & it turned out
pretty Groovy!!!

Come night time... like ok... so a few things kinda got fucked up &
weird... in the early Morn when i was @ Unka's, I realized I forgot
well;... my HOmie JBL was out from NYC & like wanted to kick it.. so i
took a chance & PMed him a message on IRC hoping he got it telling him to
meet me @ the park... but that mever happned.. so since i had no access to
a compie @ the park, I ended up taking bart back to Unka's in Berk &
see... there was no VM for the Robot Rave... it was all online.. info,
etc... anywaze... so like got the info & it was different from the
location the promoter gave me the night before... so i copied & pasted the
location & yahoo mapped it.. Unka was Dope enough to drive me instead of
me taking BART again, & when we got to the address & she dropped me off,
it was a fuckin' Yogart shop...

For like an hour & 1/2 almost i was confuszed & thought maybe that was a
map point & I kinda waited around for people who went to the Yogart shop
to see if there was a like password or something.... but nothing :(  So
after walking around for hella long... & watching Charlie & The Chocolate
Factory on the side of this Church (awesome btw)... I walked back to the
yogart shop  it was closed by now.. so i asked 1 of the works who was
standing outside if they knew were a pay phone was so i can make a call..
then this stranger, Danny, asked me if it was a local call & he called
Unka for me on his phone.. Hello 2Day!  So Unka checked the address on the
website again for me & it was sooooo different from where i was!  I was in
48## Piedmont & it was @ 34## Piedmont!!!!  So i ened up talking to Danny
& his wife Mila (who's Filipina) & showed them my robot costume & it was
Dope!!!  They were soo Nice!!!

So Dubfarm 4, the Robot Rave, was Dope!!!  Like this is the kinda
Underground I Love... roughly 200 people, intamite, & ooooh.. the music..
so Dope!!!  Breaks, 80s & 90s, DubStep, & Jungle!!! YUM!!!  The venue was
this room in this old furniture warehouse from the 70s... oooh.. So Dope!!
 LoL.. that night... I reeeeeeally gotta talk to Wish & Odeed more than
like before... Love them!!!  Oh yeah.. they played this bad ass breaks set
of well... I knew from talkin' to Odeed on AIM that most the stuff they
played were ch00ns they made... but yeah.. it was a Dope crowd... alota
the Jungle & Dubstep Familia were there & alota random long time no see
folks :)  But yeah.. just what i needed!!
-- 
Take Care <3
Peace=->Jus' Me =-> O§bY {8O)

From: AndyW <andy@saturn5.com>

References: <000c01c7ce81$79e2fad0$420a010a@NICO1>
 <347df33a0707250912g47c79769wf473fd574dedf7a2@mail.gmail.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Minimal sucks, glad Bone is coming to SF


On Wed, 25 Jul 2007 filter.sf@gmail.com wrote:
-&e->Well, you're in good company. One stat tossed out by a promoter
-&e->recently claimed there are 800 fans of techno in the Bay Area whereas
-&e->there are only about 300 for minimal.

Most minimal, at least in the last couple years fails as creative sound 
design, fails as a statement, fails at being dance music, etc.  I just 
don't get it (and take this as someone who *worships* old dbx/danbell, 
stewart walker, timeblind/chris sattinger, had one of their favorite 
nights of dancing ever to Juan Atkins playing the most stripped down shit, 
has released some stuff that would be filed under 'minimal techno', knows 
how to get kooky noises out of Reaktor & MaxMSP, etc).  Plus a lot of the 
seriously cheesy shit by bored techno guys branching out into 
pop/experimental is just *bad* (like the last Matthew Dear full length... 
it's like child molester theme music... if I heard it blasting out of a 
van that was pulling up behind me I'd take off running before the door 
opened).

As for the 800 fans number... I miss playing donkey raping techno at peak 
hour for 2k+ revelers.  I miss Static when it was at Liquid, the place was 
assholes and elbows full and the bass would shake beers off the counter.  
I miss stores carrying the shit.  It seems like labels are just groups of 
people now that will put out anything made within that group of people 
(even old standbys like m-nus have released some seriously shitty 
pointless crap lately... but then even mister dexfx+909 himself bores the 
crap out of me now despite all the awesome work he did in the 90s).  I 
liked being told that people who claimed to hate techno liked what I 
played.

Yeah, ok, I'm that old fuck reminiscing about my days on the high school 
team.

Argh!  Should have called a screen play!  *throws beer can at tv*
andyw

---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Banking was conceived in iniquity and was born in sin. The bankers own
the earth. Take it away from them, but leave them the power to create
money, and with the flick of the pen they will create enough deposits
to buy it back again. However, take it away from them, and all the
great fortunes like mine will disappear and they ought to disappear,
for this would be a happier and better world to live in. But, if you
wish to remain the slaves of bankers and pay the cost of your own
slavery, let them continue to create money.

- Sir Josiah Stamp

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Minimal sucks, glad Bone is coming to SF

Andy, you asked me at the last FnF campout why I stopped regarding you as a 
hero, a techno god ...

The reason is is because you stopped playing the techno I love.  You kept 
verbally slamming into my head that there aren't any decent 'techno' records 
being put out, on several occassions.  I think that's bullshit, I think you 
and several other techno DJs in the area stopped looking.

I have to say you're all wrong. Chris, you, everyone in the bay area after 
about 2005.  I have no idea why this all came about but I had to leave SFBA 
to find good techno beats to dance to.  Trust me, those days in Cactus Club 
when we had that place to ourselves ... it was amazing.  But you didn't keep 
it going.  None of us did sadly.

Droid kids down south are persevering.  Los Angeles of all places FUCK!

What the fuck happened to dance-floor techno?  Yeah you can say that the 
drumcode 90s tainted it, but you all saw Bone chop it up in youtube clip.

It's not dead.  But for some reason the bay area wants to bury it.  BRING 
THE BEATS!!!!

love always

n i c o

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Minimal sucks, glad Bone is coming to SF

Sadly, I think us breaks heads got ahold of your precious techno, and 
started warping it to our own sick needs - hence the tech-funk explosion.

I hear more dance-floor techno coming from breaks heads than I do coming 
from the techno crowd. Seems the techno heads wanna keep it either minimal 
or play stuff that is just plain not that friendly to the ears - for the 
most part anyway - I am obviously generalizing a bit. I'd say folks like the 
KONTROL crew are offering up some different beats, and are some of the only 
folks really pushing it in this area big time.

But you can trust and believe that there'll still be some good ol' fashioned 
bangin' warehouse techno coming from the OW posse if not from anyone else. 
Keep your ears to the ground for more on that...

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] I like Schranz

Schranz is ultra hard techno. Chris Liebing coined the name a long time 
ago to describe some of his stuff. I don't like much of what they're 
calling schranz these days because it's way too fast (increasing an 
already fast-paced music's tempo has never made something harder in my 
mind) and sounds more like hardcore with the cheesy vocal snipets and 
synths.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] I also think I may have gone overboard

Nico, I sure wish I had the time to put into making and releasing  
music now-a-days.  I just have too much other stuff going on in my  
life right now to make time for production.  I wish I did.  I hope to  
once again find myself tediously sequencing tracks...programing  
percussion laced bangers!  I miss it.  With that said, I finally put  
Resource Records up on Myspace.  Lame??  Maybe, but it's the first  
step in my master plan to bring my label back to life.  There are  
unreleased tracks up there now.  Please take a listen.

http://www.myspace.com/resourcerecords

I feel as if I'm done with djing for good.  But that doesn't mean I  
can't put some new shit out!  Andy??  Do you have any new material  
worthy of RESO-OL3??  Hit me up son!

=)

c h r i s

Begin forwarded message:

> From: josh wilson <joshua@artsandmedia.net>
> Date: July 24, 2007 11:27:15 AM PDT
>
> Dear folks --
>
> ArtSF is one of those incredibly determined "little spaces that  
> could." Now they face the prospect of being shuttered forever, and,  
> worse still, actively punished for their good works with massive  
> debt from a bad lease.
>
> Joe Mama and many other amazing folks -- K2, Kim Carlson, Nate  
> Madhappys and many others -- have kept ArtSF alive for years,  
> packing the space with people for their multifaceted art/music/ 
> performance events, and give hundreds of artists their first  
> showing ever. They've also hosted live music -- including many  
> Noise Pancakes sessions -- and even have a new and growing  
> community of eight artists-in-residence. It would be such a loss to  
> see this productive space go down.
>
> We are honored to provide nonprofit fiscal sponsorship to ArtSF.  
> They are partners and peers, and it's not possible for us to say  
> how much we admire their perseverance and their determination to  
> create a non-elitist space for the arts directly in the heart of  
> the Mission -- 16th & Capp.
>
> ArtSF has been building a true community space in that patch of  
> gritty urban reality, for all flavors, against all odds. They've  
> overcome some highly problematic landlord issues in the past, but  
> now they really need our help. They need financial support and  
> legal support. They do NOT deserve to be punished for their good  
> works.
>
> See Joe's email below and contact them directly to lend your  
> support. Or drop us a line at 415/861-5302, and we'll pass along  
> your info to them.
>
> Please forward this widely, and thank you for your support of the  
> arts in our communities.
>
> Sincerely,
>
> Josh Wilson
> Independent Arts & Media
>
>  --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- ---
>
>  ** SAVE ARTSF **
>
> http://www.artsf.org/
>
> hey everyone, the community art space, ARTsf, that we run in the  
> mission,
> is in danger of going under!!!!!! we are throwing a party to raise  
> money
> to keep the space alive, right now there are 8 artists in residence  
> and a
> number of community events constantly taking place here. If we lose  
> the
> space, it would be horrible!!! please stop by this party and show your
> support, its going to be good, i promise....
>
> Friday, July 27th
> Doors @730 Music@800
> 110 Capp St @ 16th
>
> we are also looking for more artists to participate in the show. if  
> you
> would like to show some art, email jpegs of the pieces you would  
> like to
> show to the following email:
>
> artmagicsf@yahoo.com
>
> help keep art in the mission!!!

nothing but a bunch of X's between somebody's hands, and little kids

the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will  
gradually become visible."

Subject: [sfraves] Best Cafe! (with cool music)

The SF Bay Guardian just awarded Cafe Flore as having
received the most votes from their readers as "Best
Cafe".

I just started bartending there this past week and
work 3:30 -11pm sun-thurs. This place rocks! It
totally has an old S.F. vibe to it, real laidback and
comfy. Everyone here is very friendly and open. The
outdoor patio with tons of trees, plants, and big red
umbrellas is great, especially since we're on the
sunny side of market street (corner of market and
noe). 

At night we play some very good music that i think
most people on this list would enjoy alot. quite often
thru the night customers come up to me and ask what
music we're playing, so mix cd's will be on the menu
soon as well. (music includes mnml, detroit, house,
acid, neo-trance,indie, etc...)

Please come and say hi to me (theron k.) and i'll make
ya someting special to drink (we serve alcohol, mix
drinks, and wine until midnight) I just moved back
into town after living in mexico playing for the
puerto vallarta chamber orchestra and i'm hoping to
meet new people that enjoy the same kind of music and
people that i do. 

cheers!,
-theron k.

Cafe Flore (corner of market and noe in S.F.)

>>you didn't keep it going.  None of us did sadly.
>>
>>Droid kids down south are persevering.  Los Angeles of all places FUCK!
>>
>>What the fuck happened to dance-floor techno?  Yeah you can say that the 
>>drumcode 90s tainted it, but you all saw Bone chop it up in youtube clip.
>>
>>It's not dead.  But for some reason the bay area wants to bury it.  BRING 
>>THE BEATS!!!!
>>
>>love always

>>>On Wed, 25 Jul 2007 filter.sf@gmail.com wrote:
>>>-&e->Well, you're in good company. One stat tossed out by a promoter
>>>-&e->recently claimed there are 800 fans of techno in the Bay Area 
>>>whereas
>>>-&e->there are only about 300 for minimal.
>>>
>>>Most minimal, at least in the last couple years fails as creative sound
>>>design, fails as a statement, fails at being dance music, etc.  I just
>>>don't get it (and take this as someone who *worships* old dbx/danbell,
>>>stewart walker, timeblind/chris sattinger, had one of their favorite
>>>nights of dancing ever to Juan Atkins playing the most stripped down 
>>>shit,
>>>has released some stuff that would be filed under 'minimal techno', knows
>>>how to get kooky noises out of Reaktor & MaxMSP, etc).  Plus a lot of the
>>>seriously cheesy shit by bored techno guys branching out into
>>>pop/experimental is just *bad* (like the last Matthew Dear full length...
>>>it's like child molester theme music... if I heard it blasting out of a
>>>van that was pulling up behind me I'd take off running before the door
>>>opened).
>>>
>>>As for the 800 fans number... I miss playing donkey raping techno at peak
>>>hour for 2k+ revelers.  I miss Static when it was at Liquid, the place 
>>>was
>>>assholes and elbows full and the bass would shake beers off the counter.
>>>I miss stores carrying the shit.  It seems like labels are just groups of
>>>people now that will put out anything made within that group of people
>>>(even old standbys like m-nus have released some seriously shitty
>>>pointless crap lately... but then even mister dexfx+909 himself bores the
>>>crap out of me now despite all the awesome work he did in the 90s).  I
>>>liked being told that people who claimed to hate techno liked what I
>>>played.
>>>
>>>Yeah, ok, I'm that old fuck reminiscing about my days on the high school
>>>team.
>>>
>>>Argh!  Should have called a screen play!  *throws beer can at tv*

From: "G.A.M.M.A." <gamma@techno-truth.com>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
References: <000c01c7ce81$79e2fad0$420a010a@NICO1> <347df33a0707250912g47c79769wf473fd574dedf7a2@mail.gmail.com> <Pine.LNX.4.62.0707251912080.14551@atari> <000e01c7cf51$c85d5950$420a010a@NICO1>

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Minimal sucks, glad Bone is coming to SF

Over the last several years we've created a sweet little techno scene in 
Reno and Sacramento.

We've had Frankie Bones, Ian Lehman, Dustin Zahn, Chris Liberator, Aaron 
Liberator, Julian Liberator (twice), Ant, DDR (twice), Patrick DSP, DAVE the 
Drummer, Sarah FAB, Rachel Racket, Brad, Brian, Praxis and tons of other 
locals.

All since '02.

I love the floor stomping techno and we've got a pretty good crowd diggin it 
to.  For Frankie Bones we had just about 1000 people, one room.

Its still out there its just a different generation.

There's been so much interest in techno that I have started a new company to 
showcase techno on the west coast.  Over the last few years I've met a lot 
of cool people who are still pushing the sound. Anybody is welcome to have a 
link on there. I made stickers and am working on the main site which will 
have artist profiles, downloadable mixes, and event calendars for the artist 
and shows in general.

www.leftcoasttechno.com

:)

I'm already out of the stickers they went like hot cakes and were just the 
the image you seen on the site now.


Paul Plescov

G.A.M.M.A.
www.stilldream.org
www.techno-truth.com
www.movementnow.com
www.m13graphics.com

> Andy, you asked me at the last FnF campout why I stopped regarding you as 
> a hero, a techno god ...
>
> The reason is is because you stopped playing the techno I love.  You kept 
> verbally slamming into my head that there aren't any decent 'techno' 
> records being put out, on several occassions.  I think that's bullshit, I 
> think you and several other techno DJs in the area stopped looking.
>
> I have to say you're all wrong. Chris, you, everyone in the bay area after 
> about 2005.  I have no idea why this all came about but I had to leave 
> SFBA to find good techno beats to dance to.  Trust me, those days in 
> Cactus Club when we had that place to ourselves ... it was amazing.  But 
> you didn't keep it going.  None of us did sadly.
>
> Droid kids down south are persevering.  Los Angeles of all places FUCK!
>
> What the fuck happened to dance-floor techno?  Yeah you can say that the 
> drumcode 90s tainted it, but you all saw Bone chop it up in youtube clip.
>

> THE BEATS!!!!

>> shit,

>> pop/experimental is just *bad* (like the last Matthew Dear full length...

>> van that was pulling up behind me I'd take off running before the door
>> opened).

>> hour for 2k+ revelers.  I miss Static when it was at Liquid, the place 
>> was
>> assholes and elbows full and the bass would shake beers off the counter.
>> I miss stores carrying the shit.  It seems like labels are just groups of
>> people now that will put out anything made within that group of people
>> (even old standbys like m-nus have released some seriously shitty
>> pointless crap lately... but then even mister dexfx+909 himself bores the
>> crap out of me now despite all the awesome work he did in the 90s).  I
>> liked being told that people who claimed to hate techno liked what I
>> played.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Minimal sucks, glad Bone is coming to SF

We're trying to collect the main promoters around techno spectrum
together in one place, as is DEF. A short and growing list of Western
US outfits are on www.freqbox.net

58 Tehama/Microfon
Auralism Records
Bassaholics Anonymous
Blasthaus
Communikey Festival of Electronic Arts
Compression LA
Decibel Festival
Deeper Moods
Dope Recordings
Droid Behavior
Filter SF (BABD)
Kontrol
Omniscient Records
Staple
Technosol

So ya, we're just one of many dedicated souls who are evolving the
sound. Thanks everybody for all that you do to keep techno kicking
around here (supporting it, DJing it, promoting it or eating it after
midnight) and if we've left anybody off this list, let us know.

SK
Filter.SF
BABD

filter.sf@gmail.com wrote: We're trying to collect the main promoters around techno spectrum
together in one place, as is DEF. A short and growing list of Western
US outfits are on www.freqbox.net

58 Tehama/Microfon
Auralism Records
Bassaholics Anonymous
Blasthaus
Communikey Festival of Electronic Arts
Compression LA
Decibel Festival
Deeper Moods
Dope Recordings
Droid Behavior
Filter SF (BABD)
Kontrol
Omniscient Records
Staple
Technosol

So ya, we're just one of many dedicated souls who are evolving the
sound. Thanks everybody for all that you do to keep techno kicking
around here (supporting it, DJing it, promoting it or eating it after
midnight) and if we've left anybody off this list, let us know.

SK
Filter.SF
BABD
